column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90980,2019,Preparatory course Internship Pedagogical Sciences,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. AP Ringoot', 'dr. LAL de Meijer', 'RJ Zijderveld, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The internship is an introduction with the professional practice and an exercise in the skills which are relevant in the profession. The students gain experience in applying knowledge and at the same time acquire new knowledge and skills. During the internship 7 points for attention are central. These 7 points are important during the internship and the reporting of the internship. At each point of attention is formulated a number of objectives. These objectives apply to all forms of internship. The starting point is that all objectives be realized during the internship at the institution. However, due the nature of the different forms of internship certain objectives will be more or less on the foreground. The internship committee determines whether there can be met within the placement to the different objectives (based on the internship request).</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: <div>

column4: The Master internship is an important component of the Master Family Pedagogy. During the first phase of the Master you have gained pedagogicalal knowledge and skills, now is the time to apply this acquired knowledge and skills into practice. The internship is the opportunity to deepen or broaden your content. This internship can give you a good overview of the labor market, the field and the requirements of employers. You can gain work experience and make valuable contacts, which you can use in your future career.
The student has knowledge and insight of:

• work within the pedagogical and/or educational profession at local level and/or at (inter)national level and the way in which these activities are relate to other institutions that directly or indirectly deal with issues in education and parenting.
• current pedagogical and/or educational issues and the current state of science and/or practice.
• the policy, protocols and/or processes of professionals in the pedagogical and/or educational professions.
• diversity issues within the pedagogical and/or educational practice and/or science.
• ethical and legal frameworks for pedagogical and/or educational act.
• performing and interpreting scientific pedagogical and/or educational research.
• apply the scientific knowledge (acquired during the study) in the professional practice.
• translate complex pedagogical and/or educational problems to (potential for) suitable interventions, programs and/or policies and to carry a valid basis.
• share professional development with professionals in the field.
• reflect scientifically on pedagogical and/or educational ethical issues.
• reflect scientifically and ethical on the interaction between the interest of science, policy and practice.
• oversee the research process and the diagnostic cycle.
• make responsible ethical and procedural decisions during the diagnostic and research cycle.
• reflect critical on their own insights and skills and those of others.
• apply, under supervision, (diagnostic) instruments, even at individuals and groups with different cultural and socio-economic backgrounds.
• report, scientifically sound, in written and oral form about plans and research (both focused on treatment/ intervention and research itself) and resulting recommendations, problems and solutions.
• assume an academic / advisory role in a cooperative relationship with professionals.

• set up, execute and evaluate a research or intervention or training programme in the field of education and/or parenting problems, preferably also at individuals and groups with different cultural and socio-economic backgrounds.
• provides a scientific contribution to (developing) policy, practice or research within an pedagogical context.
• work in a multidisciplinary group in pedagogical and/or educational practice.
• cooperate and communicate with different target groups (such as children, parents, teachers, policymakers and scientists).
• cooperate and communicate effectively and respectful with individuals with different backgrounds (such as nationality, culture, socio-economic environment and scientific discipline).
• ask for feedback on the work carried out, and here to receive to deal adequate with it.
• reflect on their own learning (and development herein) and to determine what are personal goals and interests.
In addition to the objectives set out the course, the student will also formulate personal goals to encourage the professional development.

The domains, independence (ig. Mostly know him/her to do, take action itself), establish contacts (ig. Can cooperate professionally with different target groups), communication (ig. Has good listening and communication skills) and professionalism (ig. respects appointments, is open to and processed on an adequate feedback), are important aspects herein.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90979,2019,Preparatory course Thesis Pedagogical Sciences,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. AP Ringoot', 'dr. LAL de Meijer', 'dr. MHF Deutz', 'RJ Zijderveld, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: <div>

column4: The master’s thesis is the final part of the master program. During this final phase, students apply their knowledge and skills in the field of pedagogical and educational research. By formulating relevant academic research questions and carrying out a subsequent research, students contribute to the collective knowledge base of professionals and academics in the field of pedagogy and education.

The master thesis is an academic written product, an academic aptitude test in which students reflect their academic level. The master thesis describes empirical research in form of an academic article and contributes to the knowledge of pedagogical or educational science.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: <div>
<div>
<ul>

column5: current insights, key theories, empirical findings, and national and international developments, both within the chosen specialization and at the interface of the three specializations (i.e. ortho pedagogy, family pedagogy and educational sciences);

cultural (i.e. ethnic-cultural, ethical and/or legal), economic, social and/or political developments within the chosen specialization, and related issues, problems and findings (including empirical findings);

advanced methods and models used in the process of signaling and identifying complex, multi-problem pedagogical situations and providing appropriate guidance and support, both at the level of the individual and at the level of systems and institutions;

intervention (or treatment) models of complex, multiple pedagogical problems, including their effectiveness and their application in a diverse context (i.e. diversity in ethnic-culture, social-economic status, legislation, language, gender);
advanced designs and methods for social sciences research.

column3: <div>

column5: Students are able to:
<li>

column6: assess and translate complex pedagogical problems into interventions, programs and/or policy, and  analyze and evaluate them;

column5: <li>

column6: carry out research within the chosen specialization and at the interface with other related sub disciplines of the pedagogical sciences;

column5: <li>

column6: analyze complex questions, issues and developments in the field of upbringing and education and form a well-reasoned opinion by integrating existing knowledge and their own understanding with the ability to reflect on the limitations of their knowledge and on the influence of their own and other people’s culture-based norms and values;

column5: <li>

column6: carry out their pedagogic and scientific work with an awareness of ethical and culture-related aspects, in respect of clients as well as test subjects, and to oversee the consequences of their own professional actions;

column5: <li>

column6: work in a multidisciplinary group in a pedagogical context, and competently take on either a leading role or a team role;

column5: <li>

column6: communicate complex themes, either orally or in writing, in a clear and comprehensible way, with the ability to differentiate between different target groups (e.g. children, parents, teachers, policymakers, scientists and other professionals) and accounting for diversity;

column5: <li>

column6: keep up with subject-related developments and developments in society in order to contribute to change processes in pedagogic practice and to innovation in the field of pedagogy; independently engage in a further specialist study program and continue working on their professional development.

column2: </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Accounting is the language of business. Given that the role profile of financial managers has broadened substantially in recent years with a particular emphasis on management skills, accounting and financial management graduates from our programme more than ever need to be able to communicate the key implications of this (sometimes complicated) language to a variety of different audiences in a convincing and easy manner.

Therefore, the department of Accounting and Control offers this 1 ECTS course to provide students with the necessary tools for preparing a good presentation and communicating its key messages effectively. It is mandatory for all incoming students in accounting and financial management.

The course format will be multiple sessions with experienced coaches from the J-building and companies. To pass this course, students will need to attend the sessions. An alternative assessment format will be to prepare a presentation on a subject recorded on video.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • How to prepare a clear presentation structure
• How to create quality slides for different areas and audiences, such as research, real life cases, or executive summaries
• How to make impact on the audience
• How to present themselves effectively

<body>After this course students are able to:

column2: • To apply the technology-entrepreneurship-development perspective nexus to real life challenges in frugal innovation;
• To work in multidisciplinary groups, and relate this knowledge to and integrate into their own disciplinary background;
• From there, make a constructive contribution to the debate on frugal innovation and sustainable global development.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Part A of the minor is concluded with a pressure cooker in which students apply the acquired knowledge in Part A to arrive at a number of detailed ideas for a Frugal Innovation that can contribute to solving a concrete problem within one of the SDGs. In doing so, they have to consider and think through and combine elements from the Technology-Entrepreneurship- Development perspectives. Cases / problems are obtained from the practice of companies and NGOs that will be invited to do provide ‘challenges’. The outcome of the pressure cooker are reports, video presentations or any other different visual or written form (determined in consultation with the client), which is presented to the company or the NGO at the end of the pressure cooker. Outcomes of the pressure cooker can serve as preparation for and input of the internship for those students who do an internship. For students from the EUR for whom this minor is a 15 ECTS minor, the pressure cooker is the concluding part of the minor.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88267,2019,Preventie en bestraffing,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. G van Eijk', 'dr. TFC Fischer', 'IM Mooren, MSc', 'prof.dr. R van Swaaningen', 'SD Kruit, MSc', 'SR Matthijsse, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: ‘Preventie en bestraffing’ gaat over de verschillende manieren waarop we reageren op criminaliteit. Het gaat dan in de eerste plaats om straf. Straf is niet alleen een reactie achteraf, maar de dreiging van straf dient ook om criminaliteit te voorkomen. We bespreken in dit vak uitgebreid het onderzoek naar de effectiviteit van verschillende vormen van preventie van criminaliteit, zowel door straf, als door sociale en situationele interventies. We kijken ook naar ontwikkelingen in het bestraffingsbeleid, in historisch en internationaal perspectief. Hoe soft of streng is Nederland in vergelijking tot andere landen en hoe heeft het Nederlandse sanctiebeleid zich ontwikkeld in de afgelopen 30 jaar? Deze ontwikkelingen worden geduid met behulp van het begrip controlecultuur. De hoorcolleges bieden verdieping door een beeld te schetsen van de zwaarste detentie- en sanctieregimes, te weten TBS, levenslange gevangenisstraf, de Extra Beveiligde Inrichting en de ISD.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Studenten doen in dit vak kennis op van de verschillende strafdoelen en hun onderlinge relatie en de mate waarin zij in het huidige sanctiebeleid tot uitdrukking komen. Tevens biedt dit vak inzicht in de doelstellingen en effectiviteit van verschillende gedragsinterventies en andere mogelijkheden tot preventie van criminaliteit, met als doel voor verschillende criminaliteitsproblemen aanbevelingen te kunnen doen voor een effectieve interventie. Voorts kunnen studenten na afloop van dit vak de ontwikkelingen in het Nederlandse sanctiebeleid plaatsen in historisch kader en internationaal vergelijkend perspectief, en kunnen zij de huidige verhouding tussen dader, slachtoffers en maatschappij verklaren aan de hand van het begrip controlecultuur. Dat biedt het kader om diverse aspecten van het huidige sanctiebeleid met elkaar in verband te brengen en de maatschappelijke consequenties ervan te kunnen doorgronden.

column2: </body>

A. Beerthuizen', 'dr. A. van t Spijker', 'dr. A.I. Wierdsma', 'dr. W.G. Ista', 'prof. dr. J.J. van Busschbach', 'prof. dr. M.G.M. Hunink', 'S. Redeker, MSc']",,

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87470,2019,Pricing and Revenue Management,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['JL Zofio Prieto', 'prof.dr.ir. NAH Agatz']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Pricing and revenue management focuses on how a firm should set and update pricing and product availability decisions across its various selling channels in order to maximize its profitability. In this course you will learn to identify and exploit opportunities for revenue optimization in different business contexts and survey current practices in different industries. You will review the main methodologies that are used in each of these areas, understand key concepts including the interaction between supply and demand, opportunity costs, customer response, demand uncertainty and market segmentation. Within the broader area of pricing theory, the course places particular emphasis on tactical optimization of pricing and capacity allocation decisions, tackled using quantitative models of consumer behavior (e.g., captured via appropriate price-response relations), demand forecasts and market uncertainty, and the tools of constrained optimization – the two main building blocks of revenue optimization systems.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Upon completion of this course the students will:

column2: • be able to identify revenue management opportunities;
• understand the different revenue management levers and the corresponding optimization approaches;
• understand key revenue management concepts including the interaction between supply and demand, opportunity costs, customer response, demand uncertainty and market segmentation;
• be able to formulate and solve basic pricing and revenue management optimization problems.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87489,2019,Pricing: Creating and Capturing Value,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. AM Ferecatu'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Price setting is a crucial aspect of a marketing strategy, involving both supply-side factors (e.g., costs) and demand-side factors (e.g., consumer willingness to pay). Pricing approaches have evolved from very restrained economic and financial perspectives to a broader consumer-oriented framework. In this course, we will study different approaches to have a comprehensive understanding of the economic, strategic, and behavioral considerations that impact a pricing strategy. We will study theoretical concepts linked to economic and behavioral approaches to pricing, value pricing, price customization/discrimination, price bundling and multi-part tariffs, dynamic pricing, retail pricing strategies, pricing for goods/services with externalities, and pricing in two-sided markets. We will use examples and case studies from various product categories such as consumer packaged goods, financial services, and cell phone plans.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
Understand the economic and financial aspects of pricing: estimate the demand curve, estimate customer willingness-to-pay, calculate profit-maximizing prices.
<li>
Develop a value-based pricing strategy that also considers the effect of non-price factors on perceived value.
<li>
Understand the mechanisms at play in a two-sided market, and develop pricing strategies for such markets.
<li>
Learn to spot all relevant aspects of pricing in the marketplace, through business applications, examples, and case studies.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course provides a background in the fundamental principles of ecology, including concepts of natural selection, population and community ecology, biodiversity, and sustainability. Students will acquire an ""ecological literacy"" about how the natural world works, and develop an understanding of how scientific methods are used to construct ecological knowledge. The course will also explore some of today's major ecological challenges, and the important research that is being done to address these concerns. As the course description suggests, ecology is aimed at giving students an overview of the field of ecology and how it applies to the sustainability of human societies. If you are curious about how the interactions between individual organisms and their environments scale up to global ecosystems, this course will provide you with a good introduction to nested complexity of the natural world.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this course, you will be able to:

column2: • analyse how biotic and abiotic interactions give rise to patterns of abundance and distribution of organisms at several scales;
• design a management plan for the conservation of biodiversity in a world region by assessing the conflicts and opportunities on the use of natural resources by local populations.
• apply ecological principles to current environmental challenges and conservation concerns;
• characterize patterns and processes in nature through direct experience with local ecosystems;
• assess the effects of human disturbance on ecosystems through ecological succession and alternative-stable states theory;
• use ecological models to illustrate the abundance of organisms and the dynamics of populations over time;
• compare structural and functional features between different types of ecosystems;
<title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Does Okun’s law hold in practice? Does the Phillips curve really exist? In this course you will learn how to perform empirical analyses to answer this kind of questions. The course is strongly build upon what you have learnt in Basic Statistics and Intermediate Statistics I and is specifically aimed at students with a major in economics.

During the course we will discuss important concepts for time series such as stationarity, unit roots and autoregressive models. Moreover, you will learn how to perform the analyses in the software program Stata.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After succesful completion of this course, you:

column2: • Understand the main concepts related to simple and multiple regression;
• Are aware of common techniques and concepts for time series analysis;
• Are able to apply ordinary least squares;
• Can perform basic analyses in Stata and are able to interpret Stata output;
• Can formulate a research question and testable research hypotheses on the basis of previous research and economic reasoning;
• Can apply statistical methods to answer a research question;
• Are able to structure and discuss the research findings through a written report.

column1: The course Principles of Management will introduce you to the field of business administration and its various sub-disciplines. Business Administration is an interdisciplinary and a context-based field of study concerned with the organisation and the market environment of businesses. It is a problem-oriented discipline focusing on issues within organisations (how does an organisation set different goals and objectives?) and the interaction and relationship of the business with its surrounding (how do political factors affect the business?).

Similar to the discipline itself, this course will be context-based, using cases and examples presenting the latest business developments and current challenges business face for students to better understand the business world. Topics that will be discussed include the global context of business (business environments and business types), the business of managing, people in organisations (Human Resource Management, leadership and teams), managing information (IT), principles of marketing and finance, and political, social, economic, technological and ethical considerations affecting business. The course will provide basic knowledge on business therewith preparing you for more specialised 200 and 300 level Economics & Business major courses.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course, students are able to:

column2: • Understand the main theoretical perspectives on management and how they relate to the tasks, processes and content of managerial work in organizations;
• Understand the different elements that comprise an organization and relate these to organizational structure and organizational performance;
• Define and critically reflect on the (international) business environment;
• Discuss theories and applications of human resource management;
• Describe and explain the processes, tools and content involved in managing strategy;
• Explain how marketing can add value to the business, identify the marketing environment and its stakeholders;
• Discuss and critically reflect on generic methods of control and performance management, including financial measures to assess performance;
• Critically reflect on how information systems, and ERP systems in particular, can transform organizations and what the antecedents for its success are;
• Evaluate the significance of contemporary issues in business and management.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>De cursus Privaat- en ondernemingsrecht bevat een inleiding in het (privaat)recht. Er wordt aandacht besteed aan de verschillende soorten ondernemingsvormen in het eerste deel van de cursus. In het tweede deel van de cursus staat het verbintenissenrecht en vermogensrecht centraal. De voorgaande onderworpen worden getoetst door middel van een schriftelijk tentamen. Daarnaast maakt het individueel schrijven van een paper onderdeel uit van deze cursus. Het onderwerp daarvoor dient gelegen te zijn in het personen- en familierecht. De onderwerpen die in de cursus worden bestudeerd:

column2: • Inleiding recht (algemene begrippen)
• Personenvennootschappen
• Rechtspersonen (overwegend de besloten vennootschap en de naamloze vennootschap)
• Fusies en overnames
• Bronnen van verbintenisO
• Overeenkomst en onrechtmatige daad als bron verbintenis
• Niet-nakoming van verbintenissen
• Begrippen goederenrecht en overdracht (inclusief derdenbescherming)
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: <ul>

column5: Als econoom zal de student bij het nemen van beslissingen oog moeten hebben voor de bestaande juridische problemen en de oplossingen hiervoor. Met de behandelde stof op de colleges en de te bestuderen theorie moet de student derhalve niet alleen in staat zijn het juridische probleem te beschrijven, maar moet hij tevens de relevante rechtsregels kunnen vinden, waarmee het probleem tot een oplossing kan worden gebracht. De student wordt vertrouwd gemaakt met de belangrijkste grondslagen en begrippen op het gebied van het recht. In het bijzonder wordt in deze cursus aandacht besteed aan het verbintenissenrecht, het vermogensrecht, het personen- en familierecht en het ondernemingsrecht.
De basisbegrippen van het recht toepassen.
Ten aanzien van de personenvennootschappen de noodzakelijke rechtsregels ten aanzien van oprichting, vertegenwoordiging, aansprakelijkheid en verdelingen van winsten en verliezen toepassen.
De voorgeschreven theorie omtrent de rechtspersonen (in het bijzonder de besloten vennootschap en naamloze vennootschap) toepassen.
De verschillende vormen van fusie- en overnames toepassen.
De bronnen van verbintenis benoemen en de samenhangende begrippen hieraan relateren.
Beoordelen of er een rechtsgeldige overeenkomst tot stand is gekomen, wat de inhoud daarvan is en wat de gevolgen zijn als er niet aan de noodzakelijke voorwaarden is voldaan.
Beoordelen of er sprake is van een onrechtmatige daad of een kwalitatieve aansprakelijkheid.
Het leerstuk van de niet-nakoming toepassen om te beoordelen of een recht op schadevergoeding ontstaat en of ontbinding of opschorting mogelijk is.
De overdracht van verschillende soorten goederen (inclusief de derdenbescherming) toepassen.
Zijn kennis over het personen- en familierecht in een paper aantonen.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87970,2019,Privaatrecht in werking,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. MM van Campen', 'mr. MR Hebly', 'prof.mr. SD Lindenbergh', 'prof.mr.dr. HN Schelhaas']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit mastervak komen verschillende elementen uit de civielrechtelijke rechtenstudie bij elkaar. Het vak biedt mede aan de hand van actuele thema’s theoretische verdieping van het privaatrecht en bouwt tegelijkertijd voort op de vaardigheden die zijn verworven in bijvoorbeeld het mastervak Onderzoekspracticum Burgerlijk Recht (eerste blok, 15 ECTS). Wat de invalshoek betreft bouwt het vak verder voort op inzichten uit andere disciplines zoals rechtseconomie en rechtspsychologie. Inhoudelijk wordt in dit vak ook aangesloten op de onderzoekslijnen die binnen de sectie burgerlijk recht in ontwikkeling zijn. De sprekers zijn eigen docenten en ook gasten van buiten de sectie en faculteit.

LET OP: de ervaring wijst uit dat u grotere kans hebt om te slagen voor dit vak (met een hoger cijfer) als u volgens het boekje studeert en dus eerst Onderzoekspracticum volgt. De omgekeerde volgorde raden we daarom af.</body>

</style>
• Verdiepende kennis verwerven van het privaatrecht, mede aan de hand van de actualiteit.
• Het leren betrekken van relevante argumenten uit andere takken van de (rechts)wetenschap  bij het analyseren en beoordelen van privaatrechtelijke wetgeving, literatuur, rechtspraak.
• Het begrijpend lezen van (Engelse) teksten over privaatrecht en de multidisciplinaire benadering van het privaatrecht.

• Het schriftelijk onder woorden kunnen brengen van argumenten uit de bestudeerde literatuur en het synthetiseren van de verschillende invalshoeken uit die literatuur tot een afgewogen standpunt met betrekking tot een opgegeven stelling.
• Het toepassen van de bij Onderzoekspracticum Burgerlijk Recht verworven onderzoeks- en rapportagevaardigheden

column1: <body>Contemporary surveillance is a multi-directional, multifaceted and technologically-mediated phenomenon. Social media, mobile communications, sensor networks are already part of the surveillance activities of many public and private organizations. At the same time, privacy enhancing technologies and regulations as well as peer surveillance give people room for negotiation and action. In this course we will study and critically analyse these practices and associated technologies. This involves reflection on our relation to technologies and their role in our contemporary culture as well as on our understanding of surveillance and privacy and the way they are construed in different genres of media and in academic literature.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>This course aims to give students a broader understanding of surveillance and privacy in our technologically mediated culture. At the end of the course students can:

column2: • Discuss key surveillance concepts and metaphors.
• Understand and apply theories of privacy, surveillance, and technology to a variety of situations/contexts.
• Identify the role of new media technologies in contemporary global surveillance practices.
• Identify privacy issues in these practices and develop strategies for resilience and solutions to resolve them.
• Analyze contemporary practices of surveillance and of privacy protection.
• Present arguments defending or criticizing influential conceptualizations of surveillance.
• Integrate theoretical and practical knowledge on surveillance, privacy and new media technologies into a written paper.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89672,2019,Private Equity,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['AK Grzeszczak'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: From very humble beginnings in the 1980s, Private Equity has become a very large Asset Class. 2018 was another record year in terms of funds raised and invested into assets backed by Private Equity. As of the end of 2018, $2.5 trillion of funds globally are looking to be invested by PE funds.

This course aims to give students a solid introduction to the world of Private Equity (including Venture Capital and Buyouts). It focuses on the following (along with practical insight from prior transactions) main areas of knowledge that underpin the PE environment:
»        “Organizational” topics related to PE funds & investing;
»        Cash flow analysis & modeling (we will be using a PE/LBO model for that);

»        PE investment process (a complete cycle from a purchase idea to a completion of acquisition; and from putting the asset up for sale through to a complete exit) - we will follow a “live” (recently completed) transaction;
»        Negotiation of a Term Sheet/Letter of Intent and Share Purchase Agreement (SPA);
»        Finalization of the transaction price (Locked Box and Completion Accounts mechanisms);
»        Practical key lessons from prior transactions, i.e. practical experience;

With the exception of item 1 (above), where some theory and “informational” delivery (deliberately kept to a modest minimum) is scheduled, this course focuses on practical aspects and transaction based learning.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Understand PE general concepts, how PE funds are formed, how they are managed and operate, how they pursue value creation for their stakeholders.
• Be knowledgeable about the key attributes of private equity as an asset class; be able to apply specific Private Equity valuation and modelling techniques.

• Understand the PE process and all components needed to successfully complete a PE transaction (valuation, leverage, transaction structure, transaction due diligence SPA signing, closing and post-closing).
• Understand how market conditions impact the Private Equity industry: leverage & credit markets, equity market valuations.
• Anticipate events and trends within the Private Equity industry and gain deeper insight of advanced corporate finance

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87966,2019,Private International Law Moot,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. E Themeli, LL.M', 'dr. EA Ontanu', 'G Antonopoulou', 'PP Penasthika']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

You have been selected to participate in this years’ PAX Moot (Private International Law Moot Court) team for the Erasmus University! Together with your teammates and coaches you are about to embark on an exciting and challenging journey towards Paris in May and, hopefully, The Hague in June.

The Pax Moot is a young international moot competition for law students. Participating in the competition is a unique opportunity for law students to enhance their research and oral skills, as well as their knowledge of private international law, arbitration and other areas of law.
The competition revolves around a fictional case. The moot problem involves a dispute relating to private international law.
This manual has been designed to provide some insight in what you can expect for the coming months. Broadly speaking we can divide the coming period in two phases, research and oral phase.

As far as the research phase is concerned, you will have to get to know the ins and outs of the distributed problem and, if necessary, ask for clarifications. These should concern the facts (not the legal issues) of the case. After all, you should start doing your research to have the line of arguments for both Claimant and Defendant ready at the beginning of April 2018. In this phase, prepare to meet with your coaches once a week for approximately 6 weeks.

The oral phase will focus on preparing you for the pleading sessions. You will get intensive coaching on your pleading skills. In addition, we will schedule meetings with professors and possibly law firms so that you will be challenged on your arguments and manner of presentation. In this phase, be prepared to meet with your coaches twice a week for approximately 6 weeks.

And then, finally, the moot in Paris and, if successful, in The Hague. The moot in Paris takes place on May 22nd and in The Hague on June 1st. Should you have any exams during or shortly before or after this period, please contact your course coordinator (Alina Ontanu or Erlis Themeli) or the professor concerned (Xandra Kramer) as they may be able to reschedule.

In the coming months a lot will be asked from you. You will be pushed to excel and this requires hard work. You are not alone in all of this, we will be there to coach, guide and support you. But never forget that we cannot decide for you which arguments to use, or what stance to take. This is your own responsibility as a team. Team spirit should and will be one of the key factors in your life during The Moot.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>The aim of this course is to offer students an opportunity to:

column2: • enhance their knowledge of private international law, arbitration law and other areas of law;
• provide them with the necessary knowledge and a strategy to defend a private international law disputes;
• develop lawyer skills, namely choosing the relevant legal arguments to use, drafting of memoranda and pleading skills;
• develop analytical and research skills;
• learn to co-operate within a team.

column2: <title></title>

column1: The professional development track consists of a range of courses running through the whole Bachelor programme. It aims to provide students with the skills they will need as responsible management professionals in society and as such prepares students for the labour market. The track encompasses three consecutive years of training in essential competencies students have to master in order to meet the expectations required of managers in organizations and society. In this way students are prepared to become a force for positive change in the world by contributing to the prosperity and wellbeing of the people they affect through their decisions and actions both within and outside the organization they work for.

Managers have responsibilities that can be daunting at times. As representatives of an organization managers need to be acutely aware of the complexity of the environment they work in and of the impact they have on others within and outside the organization. To address the problems and challenges an organization faces at any point in its existence managers must possess strong analytical skills as well as the willingness and ability to take responsibility for and oversee the ramifications of their decisions for a variety of stakeholders involved. Only by taking such an encompassing viewpoint can professionals justify their ‘license to operate’ in society. In the educational vision of our school this capacity hinges on the four core values of being critical, creative, caring and collaborative. RSM students will always inquire into the foundations of and evidence for the knowledge they apply in business contexts, they will constantly strive for creativity in the solutions they devise for business problems, they will do so with care and compassion for those affected by their endeavors, and they realize that successful solutions are always dependent on constructive collaboration and partnerships with others. The professional development track is geared to take these values as the basis of students’ intellectual and professional education.

The first year of the professional development track is dedicated primarily to developing skills in self- and team management as well as communication and critical thinking skills, both for academic and professional purposes. The course follows an integrative approach by offering a training ground for various skills in close alignment with the needs of other courses in the programme. Meanwhile students are constantly challenged to reflect on the foundations of their role as future managers. Skills can be assessed both in the PD courses themselves and in the courses requiring the skills offered.

Next to preparing students for their future role as managers, the professional development track also has the purpose to develop and enhance the study skills of our students. The professional development track aims to cater the specific study needs of our student population. We will facilitate students to find their place within our programme and use the high diversity of our student body such as various educational backgrounds, living conditions, ethnicity, socio-economic situations, religion, gender orientation and sexuality to co-create with the students an inclusive educational environment where our students can excel.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• to effectively organize, plan and reflect on their studies and take responsibility for their study progress (goal setting, time management, adopt an active learning attitude, mindfulness),
• to understand the basic principles and types of interviews as a method of data collection and apply them competently in concrete business research settings,
• to constructively work in teams and address challenges like related to the sustainable development goals, inclusivity and community building in groups dynamics to optimize collaboration ,
• to demonstrate critical thinking skills and use them to evaluate (academic) sources and other texts,
• to recognize and develop cogent and persuasive arguments and organize them in a well-balanced paper or other presentation, applying rules of proper referencing,
• to organize and operate diverse forms of professional communication, like presentations, meetings and giving and receiving feedback and
• to compare, appraise and discuss diverse conceptions of managerial professionalism with a view to their implied requirements for professional practice and their impact on society at large.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86322,2019,Professional Development Part I: Research Design,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['AR Longman, MSc', 'dr. AT Zhelyazkova']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This module focuses on research design. The primary goal is to enable students to design social science research in the area of international public management and policy. We will split the design process in a number of steps including research question, concept and hypothesis specification and research design. For each step we will discuss tradeoffs and relevant quality criteria, such as relevance, internal validity and external validity. This will be done through a series of lectures. Students will make a number of weekly assignments that together will cover all elements of a research proposal. Assignments will be discussed in working groups. Note that there will be one or two sessions prior to block 3, to allow you to focus your assignment on the topic of your thesis. Although most students have had a proper introduction to social science methods, they should not underestimate the difficulty of developing a relevant and rigorous research project that meets the standards of a master program.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After passing the module professional development students will be able:
<ul>

column5: to develop a relevant, feasible, and rigorous research design;
to indicate the trade-offs in designing research and to defend their choices made in developing their research project;
to evaluate research in terms of relevance, specificity, measurement reliability and measurement validity, internal validity, and external validity (generalization).

column2: </body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: In dit vak draait het om advisering over strategische veranderingen in de organisatie, inrichting en besturing van de publieke sector. Hoewel verandering op het niveau van individuen en organisaties ook aan de orde komt, ligt de nadruk op veranderingen waar meerdere organisaties bij betrokken zijn (het interorganisatorische niveau). Het vak bouwt voort op onder meer Strategisch Management en Advisering (SMA) en Publiek Management Internationaal (PMI).

Het vak is als volgt vorm gegeven. De module omvat 7 weken. De eerste week staat in het teken van een inleidend college over achtergronden bij advisering over strategische veranderingen in de publieke sector. Vervolgens wordt wekelijks een thema aan de orde gesteld om theoretisch relevante concepten beter te doorgronden en dieper te doorleven. Daarbij valt te denken aan: de reorganisatie van de rijksdienst, gemeentelijke en provinciale samenwerking en fusies, maatschappelijk ondernemerschap en zelforganisatie in de publieke sector, verzelfstandiging van uitvoeringsorganisaties, professionalisering van toezicht, inspectie en controle, conflicthantering bij het organiseren in ketens, netwerken en allianties.

Het vak kent drie leerlijnen: conceptueel (abstract-theoretisch), experimenteel (concreet-casuïstisch) en reflexief (persoonlijk-biografisch). De onderwijsvorm is case-based en thema gericht. De opgedane kennis van de studenten wordt getoetst aan de hand van wekelijkse individuele en groepsopdrachten, gerelateerd aan een of meer cases passend bij de behandelde thema’s. Van de studenten wordt verlangd dat ze tijdens de collegedagen in groepen zelf aan het werk gaan en over de opbrengsten van dat werk terugkoppeling geven aan praktijkmensen die vooraf cases inbrengen.</mystyle></body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Na afloop van de cursus kan de student:

column1: Het vak professionele ontwikkeling bestaat uit een reeks workshops die het hele bachelorprogramma doorlopen. Het is bedoeld om studenten de vaardigheden te bieden die ze nodig hebben als verantwoordelijke managementprofessionals in de samenleving en bereidt als zodanig studenten voor op de arbeidsmarkt. Het traject omvat drie opeenvolgende jaren van training in essentiële competenties die studenten moeten beheersen om te voldoen aan de verwachtingen die managers in organisaties en de samenleving van hen verlangen. Op deze manier zijn studenten bereid om een ​​kracht te worden voor positieve verandering in de wereld door bij te dragen aan de welvaart en het welzijn van de mensen die ze beïnvloeden door hun beslissingen en acties zowel binnen als buiten de organisatie waarvoor ze werken.

Managers hebben verantwoordelijkheden die soms lastig kunnen zijn. Als vertegenwoordigers van een organisatie moeten managers zich sterk bewust zijn van de complexiteit van de omgeving waarin ze werken en van de impact die ze hebben op anderen binnen en buiten de organisatie. Om de problemen en uitdagingen aan te pakken waarmee een organisatie op elk moment in haar bestaan ​​wordt geconfronteerd, moeten professionals beschikken over sterke analytische vaardigheden en over de bereidheid en het vermogen om verantwoordelijkheid te nemen voor en toezicht te houden op de consequenties van hun beslissingen voor een verscheidenheid aan betrokken stakeholders. Alleen door zo’n houding aan te nemen, kunnen managers hun 'license to operate' in de samenleving rechtvaardigen. In het onderwijsklimaat van onze school draait dit vermogen om de vier kernwaarden kritisch, creatief, zorgzaam en collaboratief. RSM-studenten zullen altijd informeren naar de grondslagen van en bewijs voor de kennis die zij toepassen in zakelijke contexten, zij zullen voortdurend streven naar creativiteit in de oplossingen die zij bedenken voor zakelijke problemen, zij zullen dit met zorg en empathie doen voor degenen die geraakt worden door hun inspanningen, en ze beseffen dat succesvolle oplossingen altijd afhankelijk zijn van constructieve samenwerking en partnerschappen met anderen. Het vak professionele ontwikkeling is erop gericht om deze waarden te gebruiken als basis voor het intellectuele en professionele onderwijs van studenten.

Het eerste jaar van dit vak richt zich in de eerste plaats op het ontwikkelen van vaardigheden in zelf- en teammanagement en communicatie- en kritisch denkvermogen, zowel voor academische als professionele doeleinden. Het vak volgt een integrale aanpak door een oefenterrein aan te bieden voor verschillende vaardigheden in nauwe afstemming met de behoeften van andere cursussen in het programma. Ondertussen worden studenten doorlopend uitgedaagd om na te denken over de fundamenten van hun rol als toekomstige managers. Vaardigheden kunnen worden beoordeeld zowel in de PO cursussen zelf als in de cursussen waarvoor de aangeboden vaardigheden vereist zijn.

Het vak professionele ontwikkeling speelt in op de specifieke behoeften van de studentenpopulatie. We zullen studenten faciliteren om hun plaats binnen ons programma te vinden en de grote verscheidenheid aan termen zoals onderwijskundige achtergronden, leefomstandigheden, etnische, sociaaleconomische, religieuze, genderoriëntatie of seksualiteit gebruiken om gezamenlijk een onderwijsomgeving te ontwikkelen waar studenten kunnen excelleren.

column1: Ever done hundreds of repetitive actions on rows in tables? Ever copied daily update information from websites every day? Ever wondered how computer programs work, or how online shops keep track of all items for sale and their stock?

Then, this is the elective module for you! You will be learning the basic components of computer programs, write your own programs in Python, trace bugs and inspect variables in an integrated development environment (IDE).

“Why would I want to be able to write computer programs, or tiny helpers?”, you may ask. Customized computer programs tailored to specific business are used in many companies. Being able, as a manager, to communicate with in-house or hired computer programmers is an asset.

The course comprises of exercises online, so you can practice your skills in a web browser. The results of these exercises form part of your total grade. For the other part you will be asked to write a Python program during an examination.

• Design programs that interact with tables in spreadsheets or databases
• Simplify your (repetitive) daily tasks with (little) helper programs or scripts

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course aims to strengthen your abilities as future managers with one of the most important yet mostly missing skills for managers: the art of programming. Managers with programming experience are able to be involved in the decision-making process of their developers. They can also --at high level-- understand whether or not each developer is performing well. In this course, we will focus on one of the most widely used programming languages: Java. This course also lays the foundation for learning other important programming languages. You should not expect to be developers in few weeks. You should rather treat this course as an intense programming tutorial for absolute beginners. It is assumed that the registered students have no previous knowledge of programming. After taking this course, you will learn how to excel in Java even further or to start learning a new programming language from scratch. Java is greatly structured to be an easy-to-learn, yet a powerful programming language.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The main objective of this course is to develop comprehensive knowledge about the fundamental principles and concepts of modern computer programming. In this course, the students will gain a broad understanding of problem analysis, solution design, coding and debugging of computer programs. In particular, upon completion of the course, it is expected that you will be able to:

column2: • Translate well specified problems into pseudo-code solutions and then code them in Java
• Write small programs that allow you to accomplish useful goals
• Understand the fundamentals of the syntax and semantics of Java programming language.
• Define the necessary program structure in terms of the basic building blocks (classes, methods and properties)

column1: During this course students combine the skills gained over the past the year to undertake a research project from start to finish. Because students have the entire Quad to predominantly focus on their research, they are able to go in depth and do extensive research. The research project serves as a practice-run for the capstone. Students work in small teams to improve their collaborative skills, and receive guidance from their tutors in the form of several feedback sessions and teamwork coaching (including exercises).

The content of the course is aimed at honing students’ media literacy skills, by engaging with a diverse range of mass media images. As Gillian Rose, the author of the handbook that we will use throughout the course, argues,

‘We are almost constantly surrounded by visual technologies – photography, film, video, digital graphics, television, acrylics, for example – and the images they show us – TV programmes, advertisements snapshots, Facebook pages, public sculpture, movies, closed circuit television footage, newspaper pictures, paintings. All these different sorts of technologies and images offer views of the world; they render the world in visual terms. But this rendering, even by photographs, is never innocent. These images are never transparent windows onto the world. They interpret the world; they display it in very particular ways; they represent it’ (2012, p.2).

Students will have to use their critical thinking skills to analyse the images – or cultural texts – that circulate in, and are so central to, the ways we make sense of our everyday lives, by applying the key visual methodologies of the social sciences and the humanities: content analysis (i.e., coding and counting) and textual analysis (i.e., decoding and interpreting). The combination of both quantitative and qualitative research methodologies exposes students to mixed methods approaches, and encourages them to work in an interdisciplinary manner.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: At the end of the course, students have:

column2: • A basic understanding of the notion of ‘representation’
• A basic understanding of the sites and modalities of the production of images, images themselves and the audiencing of images
• A basic understanding of the visual methodology of content analysis
• A basic understanding of the visual methodology of textual analysis
• A basic understanding of the semiotic approach to analysing cultural texts
• Have improved their collaborative skills
• Performed a small-scale research project from start to finish

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87001,2019,Project: Applied Cultural Entrepreneurship,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. FJC Brouwer'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
In order to get prepared to be real cultural entrepreneurs for the labor market the course is divided in three parts:
(1) Conceptual Development: development of a business plan;
(2) Realization: effectuation of the project; and

(3) Reporting and Evaluation: beyond realization, students will write a critical essay discussing “what happened?"", “what I would have done differently?"", and “what I learned from this experience?”.
The requirements for this seminar are basic knowledge about culture in general (performing or visual arts), and entrepreneurship.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The aim of this seminar is to learn from real life entrepeneurial experiences. Master students will realize an artistic production, a consultancy report or a case study with entrepreneurial aspects within three months. They will act as junior agents, performing as programmers, economists, planners, managers, marketers, auditors, fundraisers, etc. in an entrepreneurial way (with innovative elements) and with a holistic approach. They will develop competencies such as creative and critical thinking, practical (group) working skills, coordinating, collaboration, self-reflection, critical controlling, independent decision making, and performing under stress.</body>

column1: In het vak Prudentieel toezicht & governance (PTG) wordt vanuit juridisch en economisch perspectief ingegaan op de vraag op welke wijze de financiële soliditeit van financiële ondernemingen, groepen van financiële ondernemingen en de stabiliteit van het financiële systeem als geheel wordt bevorderd. In dat verband wordt relevante regelgeving behandeld en worden zowel theoretische als praktische gezichtspunten besproken, mede aan de hand van literatuur. Voorts wordt aandacht besteed aan governance-vraagstukken en belangrijke aspecten van extern toezicht. Het accent ligt op de bancaire sector, maar ook de pensioen- en de verzekeringssector passeren de revue.

De prudentiële eisen waaraan financiële ondernemingen en financiële groepen moeten voldoen, vormen het hoofdonderwerp van dit vak. Dit betreft markttoegang, kapitaaleisen, maar ook de eisen die in het kader van een adequate governance worden gesteld aan de wijze waarop bestuur en toezicht zijn vormgegeven en de bedrijfsvoering is ingericht.

Verder zal er aandacht zijn voor systeemtoezicht, toezicht op gedrag en cultuur en de wet- en regelgeving en het toezichtinstrumentarium voor het geval een financiële onderneming in financiële problemen komt en moet worden afgewikkeld en de rol en opzet van garantiestelsels.
Regelmatig zullen gastdocenten college geven om inzichten uit de praktijk in te brengen. Ook zal er veel gebruik worden gemaakt van casusposities. Van studenten wordt een actieve inbreng verwacht.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: ·     U kunt de belangrijkste economische redenen en de politiek-maatschappelijke motieven voor de prudentiële regulering van en het prudentiële toezicht op financiële markten en hun actoren, alsmede in de historische ontwikkeling daarvan, in eigen woorden beschrijven.

·     U kent de redenen voor en de inhoud en structuur van de belangrijkste prudentiële regelgeving met betrekking tot banken, verzekeraars, pensioenfondsen en beleggingsondernemingen, waarbij het accent op banken ligt. U kunt deze kennis toepassen in het analyseren van concrete casussen. U kunt de prudentiële regels voor banken, verzekeraars en pensioenfondsen vergelijken en overeenkomsten en verschillen benoemen en toelichten.
·     U kunt in de belangrijkste Europese en nationale rechtsbronnen van en toezichtstructuren omtrent prudentieel toezicht uw weg vinden en u bent in staat deze toe te passen in concrete casussen.

·     U kunt een beargumenteerd oordeel geven van uitingen van (inter)nationale instituties die een rol spelen in het toezicht op de financiële sector en discussies daarover in de literatuur en media duiden.

·     U begrijpt de juridische en economische verhoudingen tussen het bestuur, de raad van commissarissen en de aandeelhouders. Daarnaast kent u de belangrijkste governance eisen vanuit het perspectief van het prudentiële toezichtrecht en het reguliere ondernemingsrecht.

Gelet op de complexiteit van het prudentiële toezicht zijn deze leerdoelen primair gericht op het ontwikkelen van begrip van de basis en systematiek van het prudentiële toezicht: doelstellingen, logica en de opbouw van het prudentiële toezicht. Het idee is dat als dit basisbegrip er is, de student daarmee zelfstandig een casus kan analyseren en kan uitwerken. Verworven kennis, inzicht en vaardigheden oefent u in de vorm van deelname aan discussie in de colleges, uitwerking van casusposities, het schrijven van een paper en het tentamen.

column1: During this course you will get acquainted with psychological testing and assessment, two separate but related components of a psychological evaluation. Psychological testing involves the use of formal tests such as questionnaires.  A psychological assessment can include tests, but also different other components. Cohen, Swerdlik, and Sturman (2013) define psychological assessment as ”the gathering and integration of psychology-related data for the purpose of making a psychological evaluation that is accomplished through the use of tools such as tests, interviews, case studies, behavioural observation, and specially designed apparatuses and measurement procedures” (p. 2). A psychologist determines what information to use based on the specific questions being asked. In clinical psychology, assessment is the process of gathering information about an individual’s symptoms and the possible causes of those symptoms (Nolen-Hoeksema, 2007). However, the use of psychological testing and assessment is not limited to clinical psychology, it stresses over all disciplines in psychology, human resources management, and educational science. The main types of psychological and educational tests are intelligence tests, personality tests, aptitude and interest tests, and neuropsychological tests.

The branch of psychology that is concerned with the use of tests in the evaluation of personality, intelligence and the determination of factors underlying human behaviour is called ‘Psychodiagnostics’. It is an important and rather intricate part of the work of many psychologists. The information collected with different tools of psychological assessment has to be combined in order to reach a final decision or diagnosis, which is the starting point for advice and/or treatment (Van der Molen et al., 2015).

This course must be regarded as an introduction to Psychodiagnostics. After an introduction to different assessment tools and some historical, cultural and ethical considerations, you will learn more about intelligence, personality tests, and interest tests. Next you‘ll get acquainted with diverse neuropsychological tests. You will learn how to administer, interpret and score different tests. In this course you will also get acquainted with the anamnestic (or clinical) interview. You will practice different phases of this interview in role plays.

• basic knowledge of personality testing, intelligence testing, neuropsychological testing and anamnesis
• skills in administering, scoring and interpreting some commonly used tests
• basic skills in anamnestic interviewing
• an experience in providing feedback to a client about his/her test results

<body>Door middel van het blok Psychologie van de opleiding Criminologie wordt een inleiding op verschillende perspectieven en thema’s binnen de psychologie gegeven. Daarbij ligt de nadruk op die perspectieven en thema’s die bij uitstek relevant zijn voor de criminologie. Bij de behandeling van deze onderwerpen wordt verwezen naar concrete maatschappelijke problemen en toepassingen in onderzoek. Er wordt in het blok bijvoorbeeld aandacht besteed aan de vraag: hoe kan antisociaal of crimineel gedrag worden verklaard aan de hand van psychologische mechanismen? Daarnaast wordt bekeken hoe psychologische mechanismen andere fenomenen uit de criminologie kunnen verklaren.</body>

column1: This course consists of two important domains in psychology as they are relevant for business:

column2: • human decision-making
• behaviour in teams

column1: The course is taught as a mixture of interactive lectures, in-class exercises, and workshops that allow students to explore key topics in organizational behaviour, e.g., essential concepts in judgement and decision-making, bias in decision-making, strengths and pitfalls in persuasion, cooperation and conflict, cognition and information processing, and diversity in teams.

Regarding human decision-making we will discuss the assumption of rational decision-making versus biases by normatively irrelevant factors. We will show that other people influence our choices. The course will give you an understanding of the psychology of judgment and decision-making, with the ultimate, overarching goal of making you a better decision-maker. How can you overcome your biases and improve your choices? How can you make sure that you and your collaborators finish your project on time? These are important challenges for anyone’s career, independent of your specific professional goals. Understanding these questions will help you improve your (personal) insights in the process of decision-making.

Regarding behaviour in teams, the course addresses the challenges associated with coordinating the efforts and expertise of different team members who are working towards a common team goal. Furthermore, we will explore different strategies that help teams overcome challenges and pitfalls in team collaboration. Special attention is given to diversity in teams and the impact it can have on team dynamics.

Complementing the lectures, the course includes a number of practical exercises and discussions of real-life cases that will allow you to engage with the course content on a more experiential basis and highlight how the theoretical concepts and models relate to management practice.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85703,2019,Psychometrics: An Introduction,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. J Jongerling', 'dr. MT Barendse']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Measuring features and skills plays an increasingly important role in everyday life. This course is about measuring in the social sciences. During this course students will discuss the meaning of measurement and how to evaluate the quality of psychological measurements. We emphasize that this course is not only about psychological tests, but includes all kinds of measurements that are used to say something about an underlying construct.

During this course, the most important psychometric attributes to be discussed are reliability and validity. These concepts will be explained according to classical test theory and their importance will be discussed in terms of psychological practice as well as scientific research.
This course will feature the following topics:

column2: • importance of psychological measurement
• scaling
• individual differences and correlations
• test dimensionality and factor analysis
• reliability
• validity
• threats to psychometric quality

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course aims at introducing students to psychometrics and measurement in psychology and pedagogical & educationa sciences. At the end of the course, students will have gained insights into various psychometric attributes, so they will be able to apply these attributes when working with psychological tests and doing psychological or pedagogical research. Finally, once students have completed this course they will master the SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences) skills needed to conduct psychometric data analysis.

Tijdens dit practicum zullen studenten leren om psychometrische data analyses uit te voeren in SPSS. Tijdens elke sessie zullen oefeningen worden doorlopen met betrekking tot bijv. gestandaardiseerde en genormaliseerde scores, betrouwbaarheid van een vragenlijst, factor analyse en het onderzoeken van test bias.

Ook zullen studenten in dit practicum werken aan 7 individuele praktijkopdrachten. Elke praktijkopdracht bevat o.a. vragen waarvoor een bepaalde SPSS procedure moet zijn doorlopen. De 7 praktijkopdrachten samen vormen het practicumverslag.

Het meten van kenmerken en vaardigheden speelt een grote rol in het dagelijks leven. Tijdens dit blok zal het meten binnen de sociale wetenschappen worden behandeld. De studenten zullen bespreken wat de betekenis is van meten en hoe de kwaliteit van psychologische metingen geëvalueerd moet worden. We benadrukken dat het in dit blok niet alleen om psychologische tests gaat, maar om alle soorten tests die gebruikt worden om iets te kunnen zeggen over een onderliggend construct.

Tijdens dit blok zullen de psychometrische eigenschappen betrouwbaarheid en validiteit centraal staan. Deze concepten zullen behandeld worden aan de hand van de klassieke testtheorie en het belang ervan bediscussieerd in het kader van zowel de pedagogische praktijk als wetenschappelijk onderzoek.
In dit blok komen de volgende onderwerpen aan bod:

column2: • het belang van psychologische metingen
• het schalen van scores
• individuele verschillen en correlaties
• test dimensionaliteit en factor analyse
• betrouwbaarheid
• validiteit
• uitdagingen van psychometrische kwaliteit

column4: In deze cursus passeren verschillende vormen van psychopathologie de revue, die ontstaan of aan het licht komen in de kindertijd en adolescentie. Voorbeelden hiervan zijn pervasieve ontwikkelingsstoornissen (bijv. autisme en desintegratie stoornis), aandachtstekort en gedragsstoornissen en de oppositioneel opstandige gedragsstoornis. Om het ontstaan en voortbestaan van zulke stoornissen, evenals de behandelmogelijkheden te kunnen begrijpen, is kennis van de normatieve en de abnormale ontwikkeling nodig. In dit blok integreren we daarom kennis van hersenontwikkeling, ontwikkelingspsychologie, cognitieve psychologie en klinische kinder- en jeugdpsychologie.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

International public opinions matter more and more. In order to influence them, nations, but also international organizations such as NGOs or IGOs must develop public relations campaigns in coordination with their policies. Confronted with a growing number of new media that allow anyone to speak their mind globally, the United States is perfecting the concept of Public Diplomacy, in order to ""Tell America's story"". The U.S. is not alone to practice Public Diplomacy; a number of countries are also developing strategic communication campaigns in order to win the global battle of public opinion. In this course, students will explore the importance of public opinions in international relations. Techniques of strategic communication will be discussed and analyzed along with case studies on today's Public Diplomacy. Students will regularly meet practitioners in Public diplomacy. For that reason, a reasonable level of professionalism and flexibility will be required.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Major perspectives on Public Diplomacy and its affiliates like Cultural Diplomacy, Nation Branding and Soft Power;
• Role and importance of public opinions and strategic communication campaigns in international relations.
• Critically review current research on Public Diplomacy;
• Apply theoretical concepts to real-life cases in Public Diplomacy;
• Analyze and reflect on the use and impact of strategic communication campaigns in international relations.
