column1: De minor Public Health is opgebouwd uit modules, die belangrijke probleemterreinen behandelen. Deze probleemterreinen zijn: infectieziekten, milieuzorg, geestelijke gezondheidszorg, jeugdzorg en zorg voor ouderen. Binnen elke module komen verschillende docenten aan het woord, waarvan een aantal werkzaam is in de dagelijkse praktijk in de grote stad, waardoor de diversiteit van de grootstedelijke problematiek duidelijk wordt.

Voorafgaand hieraan is er een introductieweek, waarin een algemeen beeld wordt geschetst van grootstedelijke gezondheidsproblemen en de aanpak hiervan en waarin de opzet van de minor nader wordt toegelicht.

De bestrijding van infectieziekten vormt de oorsprong van de huidige Public Health. Infectieziekten vormen historisch gezien een van de belangrijkste gezondheidsproblemen in de grote stad. Zij behoren wereldwijd nog steeds tot de grootste doodsoorzaken en ook in het westen is het probleem nog niet uitgeroeid. Vanwege hun besmettelijke karakter hebben de infectieziekten ook een belangrijke maatschappelijke dimensie.

Na een historisch overzicht worden de medische grondbeginselen van infectieziekten bestrijding uitgelegd. De omvang van de belangrijkste infectieziekten in Nederland wordt beschreven. Het gedrag van mensen als leden van een samenleving heeft grote invloed op infecties en wordt besproken. De belangrijkste soorten interventies en uitvoeringsaspecten worden gepresenteerd.

Milieu als fysieke leefomgeving – denk aan zaken zoals luchtkwaliteit, water, verkeer, groen, geluid, hoogspanningsmasten, bodemverontreiniging – vormt het onderwerp van de tweede module. Zowel het publiek, de politiek als de gezondheidsdiensten maken zich regelmatig ‘druk’ om dergelijke milieu gerelateerde onderwerpen. Voorbeeld is het thema ‘fijnstof’. In deze module wordt uitgelegd hoe blootstellingen gedefinieerd en gemeten kunnen worden en hoe maatregelen worden ontworpen en geëvalueerd.

De Openbare Geestelijke Gezondheidszorg betreft de preventie op het gebied van de geestelijke gezondheid van kwetsbare personen en risicogroepen. Het gaat daarbij vaak om zorg voor mensen die niet voor zichzelf kunnen zorgen, bemoeizorg genoemd. Daarbij komt het spanningsveld tussen maatschappelijke dwangmaatregelen en individuele vrijheden aan de orde. Klassieke terreinen van de OGGZ zijn de zorg voor verslaafden en aan dak- en thuislozen. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan andere speerpunten op het gebied van geestelijke gezondheid: problematiek die veel minder zichtbaar is zoals depressie en angststoornissen en gevoelens van onveiligheid, vaak gerelateerd aan problemen zoals agressie en geweld.

Nederland vergrijst, maar in de grote steden is het aantal kinderen en jongeren voorlopig nog relatief groot. Ongeveer de helft van de jongeren in de steden heeft een buitenlandse herkomst. De gemengde groep kinderen en jongeren in de grote steden vormt enerzijds een bron voor de toekomstige welvaart, maar is voor het algemene publiek en voor de politiek ook een bron van zorg. Er zijn grote sociale-, en gezondheidsverschillen tussen groepen jongeren in de steden. In de minor komen zaken aan bod zoals de aanpak van kindermishandeling en de epidemie van overgewicht bij kinderen.

Het verouderingsproces leidt tot toenemende kwetsbaarheid door een samenspel van slechte mobiliteit, balans en spierkracht; verminderde cognitie en (dreigende) ondervoeding. Daarnaast is eenzaamheid een belangrijk probleem. De kansen en belemmeringen (van programma’s gericht) op ‘healthy ageing’ zullen aan bod komen tijdens deze module. Er wordt aandacht gegeven aan de belangrijke gezondheidsproblemen onder ouderen, zoals dementie. Daarnaast wordt een overzicht gegeven van de gezondheid van ouderen met een migratie achtergrond.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: De minor Public Health richt zich op gezondheidsproblematiek, die typisch is voor grote steden zoals Rotterdam. Aan de hand van interactief onderwijs en interessante praktijkexcursies leer je de basisprincipes van het vakgebied Public Health. Aan de hand van casussen kom je veel te weten over recente ontwikkelingen op dit gebied en leer je om publieke gezondheidsproblemen zelfstandig te analyseren en erover te adviseren.
1. De student kan de basisprincipes en recente ontwikkelingen van de geselecteerde onderzoeksterreinen in de publieke gezondheid (Public Health) omschrijven.
2. De student kan zelfstandig een probleemgestuurde analyse van gezondheidsproblemen van de grootstedelijke bevolking toepassen.
Daarnaast zijn er per module de volgende leerdoelen:
3. De student kan de stappen van planmatige aanpak voor bestrijding van infectieziekten omschrijven en toepassen op een specifieke casus over infectieziekten.
4. De student kan de belangrijkste soorten interventies ter bestrijding van infectieziekten benoemen.
5. De student kan bevorderende en belemmerende factoren voor een succesvolle implementatie benoemen en toepassen op een casus/interventie.
6. De student kan omschrijven wat de invloed is van milieu op de volksgezondheid en hoe dit gemeten kan worden.
7. De student kan omschrijven hoe milieu-interventies worden ontwikkeld en worden beoordeeld op hun effectiviteit.
8. De student kan specifieke dilemma’s benoemen die spelen bij oplossingen voor problemen binnen de Openbare Geestelijke Gezondheid.
9. De student kan aan de hand van een specifieke casus verklaren en analyseren waarom een bepaalde aanpak voor een beleidsprobleem effectief is of niet.
10. De student kan de specifieke problemen bij de zorg voor de jeugd omschrijven.
11. De student kan aan de hand van een casus specifieke dilemma’s herkennen en benoemen waarmee zorgverleners in de praktijk mee te maken hebben.
12. De student heeft inzicht in effectieve beleidsinterventies in de zorg voor jeugd en kan deze toepassen op een casus.
13. De student kan de specifieke problemen benoemen die kunnen spelen bij de zorg voor ouderen.
14. De student kan voorbeelden noemen van effectieve interventies en kan aangeven wat de factoren zijn die de effectiviteit bevorderen/belemmeren.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88769,2019,Public Health Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. B Wouterse', 'MS Perry-Duxbury, MSc', 'prof.dr. PHM van Baal']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Good health policies are impossible to formulate without some understanding of the relation between public health policies, individual behaviour and population health. In this course students will be taught how to apply statistical methods and economic theory to answer questions like “How should we measure and summarize population health?”, “What are economic arguments for and against public health policies?”, “Should we collectively fund public health interventions?”, “How do increases in (healthy) life expectancy influence health care spending and pension entitlements?”.

Each week will consist of interactive lectures and workgroups. During the lecture, general concepts will be presented including practical examples. Students should bring a (fully charged!) laptop computer to the lectures. Students (sometimes in groups) will be required to:

column2: • do quantitative exercises/assignments at home in Excel and/or Stata using data that will be made available through Blackboard;
• present and discuss papers that focus on a particular connection between public health on the one side, and health economics and policy on the other.

column1: The following courses from the HEPL/HE programme are necessary prerequisites as a lot of knowledge gathered in these courses will be integrated in this course around the topic of public health:

column2: • Quantitative Methods for Applied Economics
• Economics and Financing of Health Care Systems
• Economics of Health and Health Care
• Health Technology Assessment
• Stata/SPSS or other similar statistical software
• Microsoft Excel

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After following this course, students will be able to:

column2: • calculate and explain the strengths and limitations of various summary measures of population health;
• explain the various relations between health policies and indicators of population health;
• recognize and explain the strengths and limitations of scientific research within the domain of public health economics.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The purpose of this course will be on the one hand to introduce students to main concepts of contemporary international law, such as sources and subjects of international law, sovereignty and international responsibility; and on the other hand to explore how we are governed globally by looking at ideas, legal doctrines, institutional and administrative structures developed over the last century to organize and legalize international economic and political life. The readings will focus on various ways to think about the legal organization of global order, and on the history of legal efforts to organize and institutionalize international affairs.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The course will contribute to the student attaining the following critical outcomes:

column2: • Collecting, analysing, organizing and critically evaluating information conveyed during lectures and further analyzed in the Tutorials;
• Identifying and solving legal practical problems;
• Demonstrating an understanding of the world as a set of related systems;
• Successfully completing given tasks without supervision;

column1: Students successfully completing this course should be able to:

column2: • Understand and appreciate the nature of the international system, how it is organized and how it works
• Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the key legal regimes operating in the international realm
• Demonstrate the ability to identify various factors and forces that shape the contemporary international community and how problem-solving contexts are interrelated
• Apply the knowledge gained from this cause to solve contemporary international problems

column2: <title></title>

column1: The important role played by public international law in current international relations is evident. International law offers a means for facilitating international cooperation, but also provides a barrier against international delinquencies such as the waging of unlawful wars and the perpetration of widespread and systematic violations of human rights. The course Public International Law focuses on the structure of international law and how that structure manifests itself in particular core regimes of international law such as the law on the use of force, human rights law, law of immunities, law of state responsibility, international criminal law and dispute settlement.
This course builds on the first year’s mandatory introductory course Inleiding Internationaal en Europees Recht (Introduction to International and European Law).
An E-learning environment will be made available for enrolled students. This will enable students to deepen and test their knowledge of public international law.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After following this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Read and analyse international case law and apply the analysis to specific legal situations. Connect secondary rules of public international law to situations where primary rules of public international law have been violated;

• To understand the doctrine of the law of treaties, the underlying rationale of the secondary rules of public international law and to apply these rules to treaties containing primary rules and applicable in fields of public international law such as human rights or international trade law;
• Understand and explain how national courts interpret and apply international law;
• Understand and explain the causes of the changing structure of public international law and how this manifests itself in core areas of international law;
• Understand, explain and give examples of the problem of proliferation of international courts and the fragmentation of international law;

• Understand various systems of international human rights law and be able to research multiple human rights instruments and enforcement mechanisms in order to understand the applicability and scope of human rights. Moreover, students will be able to analyse human rights in a particular context such as a case study or a news item and derive the human rights violations that are relevant;
• Understand the doctrine of state responsibility in public international law and to be able to apply the rules to a case study;

• Understand the difference between two doctrines of immunity: state immunity and immunity of high-ranking state officials. Moreover, students will be able to apply the rules to a case study and to understand the rationale behind the doctrine of immunity;

• Understand the regime of international criminal law under which individuals can be held responsible for acts such as war crimes and crimes against humanity. Moreover, students will be able to apply these rules in their institutional setting;
• Understand and explain how international dispute settlement works and to identify the different methods of dispute settlement in public international law;
• Understand the doctrine of the threat or use of force in public international law, including recent developments and to be able to apply this doctrine to various situations

column1: Public issues are issues of public contestation whose formation often coincides with the formation of previously non-existent publics. This introductory core course studies the historical, geographical, socio-political and socio-technical aspects of such issues. We ask how issues are publicly imagined, and by which technological mediations and infrastructure this occurs. We also focus on the ways issues are intertwined with (potential) publics. This requires also that we investigate contemporary conceptions of the public sphere in an interdisciplinary way. In order to do so, you are made familiar with a number of key contemporary public issues, such as: climate change, racism, smart urban technologies, global drone warfare, sexism and contemporary neoliberal capitalism and the precarization of life.

These issues are analyzed by means of a conceptual vocabulary that centers on the social and material infrastructures (policy and politics, media, the internet, energy supply lines etc.) that underlie many public issues; the social imaginaries through which public issues come into being; the identities at stake in public issues; the interfaces that allow people to engage with such issues; and the investments and interests that are entangled with them. By means of this conceptual vocabulary, the course seeks to highlight the importance of composition in making things public, and to move from ‘the public’ and ‘the public sphere’ to the ongoing and uncertain constitution of a plurality of publics (policy makers are one particular public, or they can be part of publics). Publics, in other words, are composed out of a variety of people and things.

The course provides room for the development of your own engagement with public life and allows you to experiment with ways of unpacking the complexities of a public issue of your choosing in a paper.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will:
1. have insight into the main sociological theories and analyses of the contemporary public sphere
2. be familiar with cutting edge sociological approaches to the ways publics and issues emerge
3. be able to apply these approaches to a variety of current public issues
4. be able to write an academic paper on a current public issue and analyze it in sociological terms

column1: This course brings together state-of-the-art theories on public knowledge, in-depth analyses of knowledge circulation in public issues, and exciting field experiments with inventive methods. The aim of this course is to develop your critical understanding of what knowledge can do in public issues. By studying exemplary cases and experimenting with methods, you will learn how research can itself be an intervention in and engagement with public issues.

As a start, you will become more familiar with a set of concepts and approaches that will allow you to analyze what knowledge can do. You will learn how methods, research and knowledge are performative: they do not disinterestedly describe but actively compose our common worlds and the issues through which we engage with it.

On this basis, you will be performing your own attempts at (re-)composing a public issue through social scientific research methods. Throughout the course you will be testing materials and methods as ways to intervene in public issues.

This course is expressly aimed at preparing you for your thesis trajectory. You’ll deepen your understanding of research methods, while also developing an initial mapping of the topic and field that you have chosen for your thesis. The final assignment of the course consists of a field exploration report that will become your launching pad into your master’s thesis research.

column2: <title></title>

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will:
1. be familiar with the main cutting edge sociological theories and analyses of knowledge and expertise
2. be familiar with the different modalities of public intervention
3. be able to make a sociological analysis of the ways knowledge figures in the staging of public interventions
4. be able to judge the performative role of knowledge claims in the public sphere
5. be able to set up and conduct a study of a public knowledge controversy</body>

column1: Hoe en waarom wordt een probleem een ‘beleidsprobleem’? Wat is beleid, en hoe wordt het ontwikkeld? Wie neemt er besluiten over beleid? Hoe kun je zorgen dat beleid ook echt wordt uitgevoerd? En op welke wijze kun je bepalen of beleid succesvol is geweest, of niet?

Deze vragen staan centraal in de cursus ‘Beleid’. De cursus laat studenten kennismaken met de ‘beleidscyclus’ en leert de student vanuit meerdere perspectieven (rationeel, politiek, cultureel en institutioneel perspectief) een analyse te maken van beleidsprocessen. Op deze wijze krijgt de student inzicht in de meervoudigheid van beleidsprocessen waarin kennis, macht, beeldvorming en instituties een rol spelen.

Ideaaltypisch worden maatschappelijke problemen geagendeerd (agendavorming), waarna politici doelen stellen en beleidsambtenaren bij deze doelen instrumenten selecteren (beleidsvorming en -besluitvorming), en uitvoerders deze instrumenten toepassen (beleidsimplementatie). Vervolgens wordt in de fasen toezicht, handhaving en evaluatie gecontroleerd of het beleid conform de intentie van beleidsmakers is uitgevoerd, respectievelijk of met het beleid het achterliggende maatschappelijke vraagstuk is opgelost. Tevens wordt aandacht besteed aan de factoren die ten grondslag liggen aan beleidsverandering.

Gedurende de cursus zullen de perspectieven op de beleidscyclus worden toegepast op diverse maatschappelijke problemen. Dit zal bijdragen aan een beter begrip van de weerbarstigheid en complexiteit van hoe beleidsprocessen in de realiteit plaatsvinden</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Na afloop van het vak kan de student:
<ul>

column5: de assumpties en kernelementen van het rationele, politieke, culturele en institutionele perspectief op beleidsprocessen benoemen;
een analyse maken van de rol van kennis, macht, beeldvorming en instituties in beleidsprocessen
de verschillende fasen van de beleidscyclus herkennen en toepassen op concrete maatschappelijke problemen;
een analyse maken van hoe en waarom beleidsproblemen op de maatschappelijke, politieke en beleidsagenda komen, of waarom agendavorming juist wordt voorkomen
een analyse maken van processen van beleidsvorming en besluitvorming rond een concreet beleidsprobleem
een analyse maken van hoe beleid wordt uitgevoerd, met aandacht voor aspecten van implementatie, toezicht en handhaving
een analyse maken van hoe de effecten van beleid kunnen worden bepaald (beleidsevaluatie) en welke factoren een verklaring bieden voor beleidsverandering.
strategisch adviseren aan beleidsactoren die een lobby strategie willen ontwikkelingen in het kader van beleidsprocessen

column1: In this course, we will examine public relations as a meaningful way for organizations to express themselves and engage with stakeholders through dialogue. The course will focus on the history, major theories, and contemporary issues and dilemmas in corporate public relations. Offline and online. Topics covered are: public relations theory, measuring and evaluating public relations, objectives in public relations, cases in crisis public relations, key performance indicators, public relations and social media, dilemmas in transparency. Critiques of public relations, especially on spin doctoring, are also presented.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The main theoretical approaches, perspectives and issues in the field of public relations;
• The role of public relations in the functioning and performance of organizations;
• How to evaluate public relations for organizations;
• The key dilemmas in being transparent as an organization.

column1: Students have the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • Systematically analyse and critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues in the field of public relations;
• To communicate their viewpoints clearly and constructively;
• Reflect on public relations as an instrument to manage corporate transparency.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: It is often (if not always) not what we communicate but how we communicate. Getting our message across (especially verbally, when having merely a limited amount of time), within the context of a highly internationalized (business) world, can be a cumbersome task from a personal or organizational perspective. Humans make a business run. Personal development (in this case learning ‘to speak out loud’), theoretical knowledge and practical skills as such, are essential aspects nowadays. Having an interview for a new job, speaking ‘out loud’, presenting or pitching in front of the class or in a future work-setting, and even ‘worse’, speaking in front of a group of people on a set ’stage’ or even in the board room during company meetings, can be very challenging. Not possessing public speaking skills (theory, strategy and practice) can nowadays truly make or break someone’s career (prospects) and can cause serious, unnecessary anxiety issues, not to mention hinder the ‘sales of knowledge, service or product’ with (personal, social, economic, stakeholder relation etc.) consequences to follow....

Public Speaking essentials, involve verbal and written storytelling and communication theories and practices; pitching/presentation training; all in all, based on the understanding and practice of effective verbal, written and body language strategies within a 21st century international business context. Several scientific fields / studies and work field practices are relevant in this case. To name a few: Leadership-, Management-, Organizational-, Entrepreneurial studies, Sociology, (Positive) Psychology and of course Communication sciences. This seminar is a strategy and implementation oriented ‘training’ with relevant and specifically selected theory as an additional solid backbone to accommodate university students in their next step towards ‘real life scenarios’.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• What we can consider public speaking (types)
• Why public speaking is essential in a globalized 21st century (individual and business) context
• What characteristics of verbal (and written) communication we can consider important when willing to be effective communicators
• The difference between public speaking and storytelling
• The importance of storytelling and other verbal, written and body language methods in public speaking
• Why cultural differences matter in public speaking
• The practice of public speaking: How to effectively speak in public
• To understand the difference between effective and less effective public speaking
• To use storytelling in public speaking
• To implement other, verbal, written and body language methods in public speaking
• To be confident when speaking in front of a smaller or larger group of (multi-cultural) individuals
• To be able to identify personal setbacks, fears and other blockages and potentially how to mitigate those to be effective in public speaking
• How to communicate a properly structured text in public speaking (writing and by heart)
• To evaluate the (inter-cultural) context within which public speaking takes place
• To evaluate and learn from other public speakers

column3: In het atelier wordt op een intensieve wijze gewerkt aan de koppeling van wetenschappelijke kennis in de praktijk van publiek management en de verwerving van professionele competenties. Op het programma staan onder meer werkbezoeken, praktijkgericht debat, workshops, oefeningen en opdrachten die de student - in aansluiting op de academiemodules - toerusten voor een succesvol afstudeertraject en vervolgens een professioneel functioneren op academisch niveau. Het atelier vormt daarmee een belangrijke integratiemodule in het curriculum.
In de eerste twee blokken staan twee elementen centraal:
<ul>

column5: benutten - maar ook kritisch beschouwen - van verworven kennis in concrete casus en in relatie tot actuele kernthema's van publiek management;
training in relevante competenties, zoals adviseren, presenteren, diagnosticeren, analyseren en argumenteren.

column3: In de tweede fase (blok 3 en 4) worden de opgedane kennis en vaardigheden in de praktijk gebracht in de stage en het verder opzetten en uitvoeren van het eigen afstudeeronderzoek. Dit wordt ondersteund door een aantal seminars en in de afstudeerkringen, waar studenten onder begeleiding van een docent met elkaar de verschillende onderzoeken bespreken.
Het Atelier Publiek Management kent een vast programma met vaste dagen en tijdstippen gedurende het gehele collegejaar (zie rooster op BSKweb).</body>

column1: Na het volgen van het atelier kan de student:
• beargumenteren hoe de diverse aspecten van Publiek Management onderling inhoudelijk samenhangen;
• kennis en inzichten uit de modules van het masterprogramma Publiek Management toepassen op praktijksituaties;
• zelfstandig wetenschappelijke literatuur selecteren en beoordelen op relevantie;
• een beredeneerde en verantwoorde keuze maken voor het onderzoeksontwerp en -methoden in de thesis;
• reflecteren op het eigen leerproces binnen de master.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85501,2019,Publiek Management en Organisatieverandering,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. FBL van der Meer', 'prof.dr. AJ Steijn', 'prof.dr. L den Dulk']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Publieke managers staan voor grote uitdagingen. Hervormingen (zoals op dit moment de decentralisatie in de zorg) vragen veel van deze managers zowel in de wijze waarop zij met externe stakeholders omgaan als de wijze waarop zij hervormingen vertalen binnen de organisatie. Vragen als ‘hoe past de verandering binnen onze strategie?’, ‘hoe geef ik het veranderproces vorm?’ en ‘hoe houd ik mijn medewerkers gemotiveerd’ spelen daarbij een belangrijke rol.

Dit vak bouwt verder op het vak “Organisatie & Gedrag”. In de module zal op verschillende manieren op de rol van publieke managers worden ingegaan. Thema’s die aan de orde zullen komen zijn gevorderde strategisch managementinstrumenten voor de vertaling van omgevingsontwikkelingen naar strategie alsook voor de implementatie en evaluatie van diezelfde strategie, leiderschap, vormgeving aan verandering, en effecten van verandering op medewerkers.

In de module wordt uitdrukkelijk de confrontatie gezocht tussen theoretische verdieping en actuele maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen. Van de studenten wordt gevraagd om op basis van de literatuur en collegestof te reflecteren op een eigen casus.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • inzicht in strategisch publiek-management benaderingen;
• inzicht in verschillende benaderingen van leiderschap en organisatieverandering;
• toepassen van theorie op actuele vraagstukken en concrete casus
• reflectie op theorie en praktijk van strategisch publiek management, leiderschap en organisatieverandering;
• op basis daarvan kunnen adviseren.

column1: Leiderschap is een ‘hot’ onderwerp, waarover tal van wetenschappelijke en niet-wetenschappelijke publicaties verschijnen. Ook binnen de bestuurskunde is veel aandacht voor het thema waarbij wordt beargumenteerd dat de positie en rol van publieke managers door allerlei (externe) ontwikkelingen is veranderd.

De module begint met een inleiding over leiderschapstheorie waarna vervolgens wordt ingezoomd op het effect van de publieke context op leiderschap. Aan de hand van het boek van 't Hart zal vervolgens nader worden ingegaan op de uitdagingen en paradoxen waarmee publiek leiderschap heden ten dage wordt geconfronteerd. Complexity leadership theory zal daarbij worden behandeld als een relevante moderne theorie om de huidige ontwikkelingen beter te begrijpen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Deze module kent de volgende leerdoelen. Na afloop van de module, kan de student:

column2: • De verschillende theorieën over leiderschap uiteenzetten en met elkaar vergelijken;
• Beredeneren welke consequenties een publieke context heeft voor het geven van leiding;
• Uitleggen op welke wijze de rol van publieke managers de afgelopen decennia is veranderd;
• Algemene leiderschapstheorie toepassen op publieke managers;
• onderzoek op dit terrein beoordelen op wetenschappelijke kwaliteit en toepasbaarheid voor de praktijk.

column1: In dit seminar zal het concept van Habermas aan de tand worden gevoeld voor wat betreft tijd, plaats, technologie en interactie tussen verschillende landen. Centraal hierbij staat de opkomst van de publieke sfeer in de 18e eeuw en het verval hiervan in de 19e en 20e eeuw, zoals uiteengezet in Habermas’, The structural transformation of the public sphere uit 1959, en de kritiek hierop en/of uitwerkingen hiervan door (cultuur)filosofen, sociologen en historici sindsdien. Habermas plaatst de transformatie van de publieke sfeer in de 18e eeuw als cruciaal onderdeel van de moderniteit toen in Europa een semi-publieke ruimte zou zijn ontstaan die grotendeels buiten de controle van de staat opereerde in de vorm van kranten, dagbladen, publieke opiniebladen, koffiehuizen, salons en lees- en geleerdengenootschappen. Deze theorie is een belangrijke aanzet geweest voor een nog steeds voortdurend internationaal debat onder filosofen, sociologen en historici over de aard en betekenis van ‘publieke opinie’ voor het functioneren van de moderne democratie. Daarnaast is het aanleiding geweest voor een nadere inkleuring of bijstelling van deze theorie, onder meer op basis van vergelijkend internationaal historisch onderzoek naar het ontstaan en functioneren  van ‘de publieke opinie’ in verschillende Europese landen, met name Frankrijk, Engeland, Nederland maar ook in de Verenigde Staten, evenals de doorwerking hiervan in de 19de en 20ste eeuw.  In dit seminar zullen de belangrijkste internationale theoretische debatten (Foucault, Koselleck en Habermas) en historisch-empirische publicaties op dit terrein worden bestudeerd en bediscussieerd. Vervolgens zullen de specifieke ontwikkelingen in ‘de publieke sfeer’ in de Republiek (later het koninkrijk Holland, daarna Nederland) worden vergeleken met de ontwikkelingen elders. Tenslotte zal de vraag worden gesteld of er thans sprake is van een globale publieke opinie.

Allereerst wordt uitvoerig ingegaan op de theorie van Habermas, de filosofische en sociologische tradities die van invloed zijn geweest op zijn werk en de kritiek op zijn these, onder meer op de vraag of Habermas’ ‘publieke sfeer’ in de praktijk ooit heeft bestaan of dat wat hij als de kern ziet van de moderne beschaving – de mogelijkheid van een machtsvrije en onbelemmerde dialoog tussen gelijken – als een utopie moet worden gezien. Daarnaast worden de uitdrukkingsvormen van ‘de publieke opinie’ in verschillende periodes en landen onder de loep gelegd, zoals geruchten, roddel, smaad, pamfletten, spotprenten, kranten en tijdschriften, ingezonden brieven, en persoonlijke getuigenissen. Hierbij wordt nagegaan welke rol en welke invloed de publieke opinie had op bijzondere momenten in de geschiedenis van Nederland vanuit een comparatief internationaal perspectief. Daarbij zullen onder meer aan de orde komen:

column2: • Het pamflet als strijdmiddel in burgeroorlogen in Europa in de 16de en de 17de eeuw in het algemeen en in de Republiek in het bijzonder.
• Vormen van mobilisatie bij revoltes in Europa in het algemeen en de Republiek in het bijzonder  in de 17de eeuw.
• Censuur in de Republiek vergeleken met die in andere Europese landen.
• De literaire onderwereld in Frankrijk vergeleken met die in de Republiek
• De publieke opinie in de Amerikaanse, Nederlandse en Franse Revoluties, 1770-1800.
• De opkomst van de moderne publieke intellectueel en de publieke persoonlijkheid in de 19e eeuw
• Morele bewegingen in Europa in de 19de eeuw, zoals die tegen slavernij of drankbestrijding.
• De persoonlijke getuigenis als mobilisatiemiddel.
• Actie- en protest-bewegingen in de jaren 60 van de 20ste eeuw (Nederland in vergelijking met andere Europese landen en de V.S.).
• Opinievorming ten aanzien van een actuele, globale kwestie (2019)

<body>

column3: In dit vak wordt eerst een summier overzicht gegeven van de geldende Nederlandse rechtsbronnen.

Vervolgens komt in algemene zin het Nederlandse staatsrecht en de juridische basis van de staatsinrichting aan de orde. Daartoe worden enkele algemene thema's belicht, zoals het juridisch staats- en wetsbegrip en de leerstukken rond bevoegdheid (legaliteitsbeginsel, attributie-delegatie-mandaat) en soevereiniteit. Bij de behandeling van het Nederlandse staatsrecht ligt de nadruk op de Grondwet, de functie van de staatsorganen en de grondrechten.
Bij het onderdeel strafrecht komen de centrale begrippen uit de wetboeken van strafrecht en strafvordering aan bod, waarbij de actoren in het strafproces centraal staan.

Bij bestuursrecht leert de student kennismaken met, en begrip krijgen van, de hoofdlijnen van het formele en materiële bestuursrecht en komt de toepassing van de Algemene wet bestuursrecht aan de orde.

Ten slotte wordt het Nederlandse recht bezien vanuit een context van internationaal publiekrecht. Meer specifiek wordt ingegaan op de verhouding tussen nationaal en internationaal recht en de plaats van de Nederlandse rechtsorde in de communautaire rechtsorde van de EU.</body>

column1: Na afloop van deze module kan de student:<ul>
• aangeven welke plaats de verschillende rechtsgebieden innemen in een snel veranderende samenleving;
• de juridische opbouw van de staat en het overheidsbestuur reproduceren;
• de juridische neerslag van staatsvormingsbeginselen als machtenscheiding en democratische rechtsstaat aangeven;
• de definities van publiekrechtelijke leerstukken en rechtsbeginselen herkennen;
• de juridische grenzen van bestuurlijk optreden aangeven;
• beredeneren waar beginselen en (grond)rechten onderling kunnen botsen;
• in een gegeven situatie de toepasselijke rechtsbeschermingsprocedures van bezwaar en beroep tegen bestuursorganen selecteren;
• aangeven op welke wijze internationaal publiekrecht doorwerkt in het Nederlandse recht;
• een wettenbundel hanteren, waaronder valt het identificeren van publiekrechtelijke rechtsgebieden, wetten en wetsartikelen.

column2: <title></title>

column1: In its very essence, purchasing involves everything one receives an invoice for. But what is the more substantive definition of this business process, particularly from a management point of view? Over the years, numerous definitions have been provided for Purchasing and Supply Management (PSM). In broad strokes, one could depict the development of definitions over time as moving from more operational, to tactical, to more strategic. We define PSM as “The design, initiation, control and evaluation of activities within and between organisations aimed at securing inputs from suppliers at the most favourable conditions.” (Van Raaij, 2016; Wynstra, 2006).

Central in any definition of purchasing and supply management is the process (at least as final objective) of acquiring inputs. As such, the economic transactions between actors are at the heart of purchasing and supply management. This is also the core difference with logistics or supply chain management, which focus on planning and controlling the amounts, routes and timing of flows of goods and services and associated information.

As a management activity, purchasing and supply has a quite rich history. In the 18th century, the United East India Company (in Dutch: Vereenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie) already conducted make-or-buy analyses. While at a general level, the principles of purchasing and supply management may thus have remained largely the same; there are some particular areas of development in the last decade or so.

There is a growing realization that purchasing and supply management can contribute not only to the ‘bottom-line’ of organisations, but also to the ‘top-line’. In other words, the buying organisation does not only seek to reduce costs but also to increase the revenue-generating potential of the acquired inputs.  Another development is that organisations place growing emphasis on strategy development at the level of so-called purchasing ‘categories’. More and more organisations apply an explicit approach to segmenting their spend in terms of characteristics such as financial importance and supply or technological risks, and apply explicitly differentiated strategies for the different segments.

Last, but not least, PSM is changing due to the increasing digitalization. Digital procurement, or Procurement 4.0, brings new opportunities to the organisations, such as streamlined and simplified processes, data-driven purchasing decisions, and overall increased time for strategic activities. However, it also brings challenges: a complicated task to develop a suitable digital PSM strategy and choose appropriate IT solutions, but above all the need to rethink roles and skills of PSM professionals.

column1: The objective of this core course is to provide students with the key concepts regarding purchasing and supply management. This course will cover the whole purchasing cycle, including strategic, tactical, and operational purchasing activities. Upon completing this course, students can:
•    Explain the role of purchasing and supply management in the value chain;
•    Analyse the relationships between buyers and supplier in a supply chain;
•    Compare and apply different outsourcing and purchasing (category) strategies;
•    Identify alternative approaches to enhance the sustainability of supplier relationships;
•    Select appropriate types of contracts and justify their applicability;
•    Define and apply supplier selection criteria and negotiation strategies;
•    Explain the importance of the effective an efficient organization of  operational purchasing process for organizations;
•    Select effective organizational forms and performance indicators for purchasing given the business context.

<body>Deze module bouwt voort op de module ‘Ontwerpen van Sociaal Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek’ waarin studenten kennis hebben gemaakt met methoden en technieken van bestuurskundig en sociologisch onderzoek. Het vak bestaat uit hoorcolleges en werkgroepen. De module geeft studenten inzicht in het gebruik, de mogelijkheden en de beperkingen van kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethoden. Studenten verwerven kennis over het verrichten van kwalitatief onderzoek, en zij oefenen met diverse onderzoeksmethoden in de werkgroepen. Behandeld worden onder meer het opzetten van een goed onderzoeksdesign; de keuze voor en gebruikmaking van bronnen en methoden zoals interviews, audiovisuele data en digitale bronnen; dataverzameling, analyse en codering van het empirische materiaal en de rol daarbij van hulpmiddelen zoals memo’s, kwalitatieve datamatrices en computerprogramma’s zoals Atlas.ti.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na afloop van deze module kan de student:

column2: • de keuze voor kwalitatief onderzoek onderbouwen op basis van wetenschapsfilosofische en methodologische overwegingen;
• de sterkten en zwakten benoemen van een breed scala aan kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethoden;
• alle stappen noemen die gezet moeten worden bij het maken van een onderzoeksopzet;
• beredeneren welke kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethode het beste past bij een gegeven probleemstelling;
• systematisch data verzamelen (o.a. interviews of geschreven bronnen)
• verschillende kwalitatieve analysetechnieken toepassen;
• de structuur en criteria van een onderzoeksrapportage benoemen.

column1: The following topics are covered in this course in 4 consecutive weeks: (1a) qualitative “versus” quantitative research; (1b) measurement and operationalization in qualitative research settings; (2a) data collection: interviews, participant observation, textual documents, unobtrusive data, and visual materials; (2b) data analysis: data reduction, causal inference, and qualitative data analysis software (NVivo, Atlas.ti, fs/QCA, et cetera); (3a) ethnography; (3b) grounded theory methods; (4a) case study methods; and (4b) content analytical methods and discourse analysis.

Central to this course is that students acquire an advanced understanding of the qualitative research process in general, and of several commonly used qualitative research designs in particular. Students are also expected to get acquainted with and learn how to use qualitative data analysis programs, such as NVivo, (www.qsrinternational.com), Atlas.ti (www.atlasti.de), DICTION (https://www.dictionsoftware.com), fs/QCA, (http://www.socsci.uci.edu/~cragin/fsQCA/software.shtml), or MAXCDQ (https://www.maxqda.com).

column1: The goal of this course is to equip students with the intellectual baggage necessary for the design, execution, and publication of truly excellent qualitative research studies. The emphasis in this course will be on getting acquainted with: (a) the canonical steps of the qualitative research process in general, and (b) four exemplary qualitative research designs in particular.

column1: In order to understand, analyze and make sense of diverse changes in the social world, research is paramount. This course aims to provide theoretical and applied knowledge in the different methods of qualitative social scientific research and an understanding of how to analyse and interpret the data gathered through these methods. This course first focuses on methods of qualitative data collection (e.g., focus groups, interviews, observation) and then on different forms of qualitative data analysis and interpretation. Within a qualitative tradition students will increase their skills in developing a comprehensive qualitative research plan and should be able to critically assess the methodological approaches of published qualitative research. The focus within this course is on developing students’ abilities to design their own research using qualitative methods for use in their future research courses and thesis development.
Note: Students should have completed the course Introduction to Social Science Research (CM1002) before they may enter the courses Quantitative and Qualitative Methods in Media and Communication.

column1: <body>Why do people do what they do? People can have many different motives for doing things and often construct their life worlds with others. Qualitative research is specifically suited to study the meaning systems of the participants in social life. In this course you will take the approach of the qualitative researcher. We will introduce you to the fundamentals of qualitative research and different qualitative research methods. Like all skills courses, we use a hands-on approach: in teams of 3-4 students you will think of a research problem, write an interview protocol and then go out to conduct interviews. For data analysis, you will learn about analytical methods, start to code your own data using the software program Atlas.ti, and identify and analyse patterns across the data. At the end of the course you will outline your findings in a research report and also present them to your fellow students in our mini-conference.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of the course, you will be able to:

column2: • Connect your research question to relevant theory
• Discuss the appropriateness of different data collection methods for qualitative research questions
• Design, conduct and analyze semi-structured interviews
• Analyze semi-structured interviews using the software program Atlas.ti
• Write your own research report

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89120,2019,Qualitative research in Strategic Management & Strategic Entrepreneurship,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. FH Wijen', 'W Liu, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The challenges of qualitative research such as case studies are widely underestimated. While it is obvious that quantitative research cannot be conducted without mastering relevant statistical or mathematical techniques, many researchers engage in qualitative research without having the requisite knowledge and skills. This course seeks to endow prospective researchers with the insights needed to adequately perform one type of qualitative research: case studies.

It seems easy to collect and analyse cases, because information about business organisations is abundantly available and all students have a certain experience in interpreting and writing texts. However, a number of thorny issues render qualitative research a challenging task. First, how to know whether the focal research topic lends itself to the use of this type of research? Second, if qualitative research is indeed a suitable method, how to determine what data are most relevant and how to access those data? Third, once all data has been gathered, how to reduce the vast amount of data to manageable proportions and how to make sense of the data? Fourth, after the data analysis, how to report relevant findings in an insightful way? This course offers answers to these questions, which are of critical importance to anyone conducting qualitative research (such as case studies).

Five workshops. Each of the four academic sessions deals with a critical aspect of qualitative studies: research design, data collection, data analysis, and data reporting. Each session consists of an introductory lecture, group discussions, and hands-on training. In the fifth session, groups present the outcomes of their field research project.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • To create understanding when qualitative (especially case study) research methods are appropriate
• To develop the ability to select and tap into different qualitative data sources
• To develop the skills to systematically analyse qualitative data
• To develop the skills to report findings from qualitative (especially case study) research in a structured and concise yet complete way

column1: Quality and safety are very much on the agenda of health care governance throughout the world. In this course we actively engage students to explore the theoretical backgrounds to, as well as the major themes of, quality and safety governance. In general, the course takes the position that quality and safety in health care needs continuous work. We emphasize the need for both ‘top-down’ and ‘bottom-up’ approaches to quality and safety, and place particular stress on theories of the 'middle' - the level where the work of management and leadership usually resides. The course explores six challenges that come from this 'mangle of the middle'. These challenges are said to face each quality and safety improvement effort, and can be structural, political, cultural, technological, emotional and educational.

Taking these challenges and their relations as a core theme, the course invites students to explore amongst themselves, and with their tutors, several recent cases of quality and safety improvement efforts. Guided by given concepts and theories, students formulate their own questions about and answers to these cases, and while doing so they can explore strategies and instruments that can be taken in dealing with each challenge. These include processes of mediation and quantification as well as instruments related to organizational cultures and leadership.

column1: Quality and safety are very much on the agenda of health care governance throughout the world. In this course we actively engage students to explore the theoretical backgrounds to, as well as the major themes of, quality and safety governance. In general, the course takes the position that quality and safety in health care needs continuous work. We emphasize the need for both ‘top-down’ and ‘bottom-up’ approaches to quality and safety, and place particular stress on theories of the 'middle' - the level where the work of management and leadership usually resides. The course explores six challenges that come from this 'mangle of the middle'. These challenges are said to face each quality and safety improvement effort, and can be structural, political, cultural, technological, emotional and educational.

Taking these challenges and their relations as a core theme, the course invites students to explore amongst themselves, and with their tutors, several recent cases of quality and safety improvement efforts. Guided by given concepts and theories, students formulate their own questions about and answers to these cases, and while doing so they can explore strategies and instruments that can be taken in dealing with each challenge. These include processes of mediation and quantification as well as instruments related to organizational cultures and leadership.

column1: There is a booming interest in improving quality of life and happiness among individuals, organizations, and governments. The interest of individuals is straightforward: virtually everyone wants to live a happy, satisfactory, meaningful, and healthy life. Governments have become interested in quality of life to support their citizens in reaching their well-being goals and because happier citizens are considered to contribute more to society. Companies are increasingly interested in quality of life because happier employees are believed to be more productive and loyal, which may ultimately improve company results. For the above reasons, individuals, governments, and companies want to know: what makes people happy? Do people make optimal choices to achieve their happiness goal? If not, how can people be supported in optimizing their happiness? And, does happiness actually stimulate better societal outcomes and company profits?

The aim of this minor is to provide participants with an overview of research on quality of life, happiness, and health from an interdisciplinary perspective, combining insights from applied economics and other branches of social science (health studies, psychology, sociology, etc.). First, participants will be provided with an overview of research on the measurement, determinants, and benefits of a good life. Second, participants will explore how quality of life is affected by various aspects of society, such as governance and social relationships. Third, participants will study the relationship between quality of life and work and how the concept of quality of life is applied in business. Fourth, the relationship between health and well-being will be studied. Fifth, students will conduct an empirical study on quality of life and happiness economics.</body>

• Understanding and discussing theories and empirical research on quality of life and happiness economics.
• Conducting an empirical study on quality of life and happiness economics.

column1: This course gives an overview of a number of quantitative modeling techniques that can be used to support decision making processes. These techniques come from the broad area that is known as Operations Research or Management Science. This area focuses on techniques for describing problem situations in terms of quantitative models for generating appropriate or optimal solutions (“how to?”) or for evaluating problem situations under varying situations (“what if?”). Such techniques can be used in application areas such as Logistics (production and transportation), Marketing, and Finance. The application of such techniques may lead to more efficient business processes or to better service for the customers.
The techniques that are covered by this course are the following:

column2: • Markov models (during 3 weeks),
• Waiting line models (during 3 weeks), and
• Linear programming models (during 5 weeks).

column1: Waiting line models and Markov models can be used to analyze stochastic business processes. Linear Programming is a deterministic optimization technique.

column1: In many situation, making decisions solely based on intuition does not suffice. Especially in situations with uncertainty, following your intuition might lead to suboptimal decision making. A structured and systematic approach based on sound analysis of the relevant data can improve the quality of the decision making process. In addition, making decisions based on intuition makes it hard for managers to justify decisions in the future, especially when decisions turn out to have negative consequences. This course provides students with the methods and tools to make better, more responsible, decisions. The methods and tools are not only discussed conceptually during lectures and exercise sessions, but are also implemented using spreadsheet modelling software.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87048,2019,Quantitative Historical Methods,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. JC van der Vlies', 'dr. JJ Euwe', 'dr. ME Hay', 'dr. MF van Dijck']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Quantitative skills are an important asset for historians. Data can be summarised in a clear manner using statistical techniques, empirical data can be accurately analysed using statistical programs and quantitative models can form the basis for testing theories. This course will deal with the collection, description and analysis of quantitative data. Many scientific articles are incomprehensible to researchers without a thorough knowledge of some basic statistical techniques. Moreover, the popular media also refer to quantitative data to provide insight into societal phenomena. Data and numbers are so important in contemporary society that academics should be able to cope critically with this kind of material.

Students will learn to interpret and perform statistical research in this course. This course mainly deals with descriptive statistics but some basic principles of interferential statistics will also be introduced. After a brief introduction about the collection and processing of quantitative data, different methods for summarising the data will be reviewed and practiced. Students will learn to create tables, draw graphs and calculate central tendencies and measures of dispersion. Index numbers, moving averages and trend lines are also covered in this course, as these are essential tools for understanding historical evolutions. During the second part of the course, students will discover how they can determine the relationship between two variables. Finally, they are also introduced to multiple regression analysis. These skills will be practiced in tutorials using SPSS. The assessment consists of a couple of assignments during the term and a final written examination in the PC labs.
Quantitative Historical methods is a mandatory course in the bachelor history at Erasmus University.

This course is in line with the specific profile of the history programme in Rotterdam with a strong emphasis on the connection with the social sciences. Most historians rely on qualitative methods, which are dominant in the humanities, but a social science approach urges historians to use quantitative methods. This course is programmed in the first term of the second year, because this enables students to make use of quantitative methods in their papers during the second and third year. Quantitative methods are for instance essential to understand historical analyses of economic developments, social inequality and international relations.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students can explain statistical terms and use these terms correctly in their own research.
• Students can critically evaluate the use of statistical analyses in historical research.
• Students can process historical data using SPSS and interpret the statistical analysis of these data.
• Students can use the results of statistical analyses in research reports.

column1: In this course we provide students with knowledge of econometric methods which are relevant for applied economics. In particular, this course first refreshes the essentials of the standard regression model, and subsequently it covers methods for choice data. Finally, the last two parts of the course cover methods that can be useful when the dependent variable of interest is endogenous.

Students follow a hands-on approach to understanding empirical econometric methods, in this way getting the opportunity to develop experience with the application of these methods in their own field of specialization.

The course consists of lectures, exercise lectures and group practical work. The lectures present and discuss each method and relevant applications. In the exercise lectures, students are taught how to implement the methods themselves. The main student activity consists of practical empirical applications, where the methods are applied to real-world datasets in applied economics.

column2: <title></title>

• To know about econometric methods relevant in different fields of applied economics.
• To know what methods are suited for analysis of cross-sectional, panel and choice data.
• To know the advantages and disadvantages of each method.
• To know how to interpret the results obtained.
• To be able to use the statistical software Stata to analyze (large) datasets.
• To be able to apply the methods learned using Stata.

column1: This is a graduate level course on the quantitative and statistical tools that are important in applied finance. It studies financial markets and market risk from a quantitative point of view, focusing on understanding the relationship between risk and return. The course brings together three essential fields: finance, statistics and computer programming.  Students will be exposed to application of these tools and the key properties of financial data through a set of computer- based exercises. Implementing the tools in MATLAB is an essential part of the course.</body>

column1: This course provides an introduction to the field of Quantitative Finance by studying modern econometric techniques that are widely used in asset pricing, portfolio management, risk management and derivatives pricing and hedging.
The course can be divided into three parts:

column2: • In the first part, we consider models for time-varying volatilities and correlations of asset returns, which are crucial tools for quantitative risk management. We also consider concepts such as Value-at-Risk and Expected Shortfall of an asset or portfolio of assets. The most important techniques for computing and evaluating these risk measures are studied. Ample attention will be given to the practical implementation of these techniques.

• In the second part of the course, we study factor models, which are commonly applied in asset pricing and portfolio management. For example, constructing a portfolio with optimal risk-return characteristics requires an estimate of the covariance matrix of asset returns. In practice the number of assets typically is large (100+), such that the number of unknown parameters becomes too large. Factor models then are an attractive way to reduce the dimensionality of the problem. Again, ample attention will be given to the practical implementation and use of these models.

• In the third and final part, we provide an introduction to the most important derivative securities, including options, forwards and futures. Popular models for computing the fair price of these derivatives are discussed, while we also consider the use of derivatives for hedging risk involved in other assets.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• To understand modern quantitative techniques that are widely used in various financial applications such as portfolio management, risk management and derivatives pricing and hedging.
• To have a good overview of the field of Quantitative Finance.
• To be able to apply econometric tools used in the empirical analysis of asset pricing models, and for portfolio management, risk management, and derivatives pricing and hedging.

column1: This course surveys modern finance theory as well as econometric and time series techniques that are used for modeling and forecasting (the term structure of) interest rates.

column2: • Bond market concepts: bond prices, interest rates, yields, forward rates and the term structure of interest rates
• Empirical features of the yield curve
• Theories of the term structure (expectations hypothesis, asset pricing theory)
• Models of the term structure (Nelson-Siegel, Vasicek, CIR, Affine) in discrete and continuous time
• Yield curve forecasting
• Interest rate derivatives
<title></title>

• After passing the course, students have a solid knowledge of different models for the dynamic behavior of the term structure of interest rates and other fixed income products.

• Students are able to apply advanced econometric tools for modeling and forecasting interest rates. In particular, they are able to do model specification, parameter estimation and inference, specification testing, and forecasting.

column1: The course puts a stronger emphasis on interest rate derivatives.
By many measures, the market for interest rate derivatives is the largest financial market.

Exchange rates is now less a primary focus of the course, though some of the key topics discussed in this context, such as nonstationarity and VECMs, are now incorporated in the lectures on interest rates.
For all exercises there will be extensive written answers available, instead of the pencasts / videos with hand-writing.</body>

This course aims at getting students involved in quantitative research. Students learn how to formulate appropriate research questions and hypotheses, how to operationalize key constructs, and how to use an online data tool (i.e., Qualtrics) for collecting data. Furthermore, students will learn how to write the Methods and the Results section of a scientific publication which uses quantitative data. Finally, students gain the knowledge of different data analyses (i.e., factor analysis, reliability analysis, and mediation and moderation analysis using (logistic) regression) by using SPSS and learn how to interpret results.

The course has a dual structure. First, students gain a thorough understanding of a variety of commonly used quantitative research methods. Second, students engage in practicing on specific methods in-depth and analyze data using statistical analysis.

column2: <li>
Students should have completed the course Introduction to Social Science Research (CM1002) before they may enter the courses Quantitative and Qualitative Methods in Media and Communication.
<li>
Students should have completed the course Introduction to Statistical Analysis (CM1005) before they may enter Quantitative Methods in Media and Communication.

• To understand various quantitative techniques and econometric theories that are widely used in financial risk management. The course focuses on modern, quantitative methods to measure and manage the risks faced by financial institutions.
• To be prepared for the role of a risk manager in financial markets and to have necessary skills for future research in risk management.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85576,2019,Quantitative methods,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. JA Holland'],,Inhoud

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: In Quantitative Methods (organized in parallel with the practical SPSS)  you will develop your knowledge of and skills in quantitative, social-scientific research. The range of quantitative methods available to social scientists is vast—this course will teach you some of the basic tools to get you started.

In this block, you will learn how to use collected data to test your hypotheses and answer your research questions. Understanding statistics is not only useful for testing your own theories. It also allows you to understand and critically evaluate research that has been conducted by others and the mass of quantitative information in the world around you.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: By the end of the course 1.4C Quantitative Methods, you will be able to:

column2: • Explain the four levels of measurement
• Calculate measures of central tendency
• Explain how measures of central tendency describe a distribution
• Calculate the variability/variance of values
• Calculate z-scores
• Calculate probabilities
• Formulate hypotheses to match research question, and which can be tested using statistical tests
• Report research results
• Explain the differences between a sample and the population
• Calculate and compare sample- and population characteristics
• Calculate t-values
• Choose the correct analysis to test a research question: t-test, chi-square test, correlation, bivariate regression, multiple regression
• Explain the constructs of reliability and validity
• Explain the use of scale variables
• Use Cronbach’s alpha as an estimator of reliability
• Interpret correlations between two continuous variables
• Interpret the outcomes of bivariate and multiple linear regression analysis

column1: In this course students will learn how to do empirical research. The course touches upon the fundamentals of research design and quantitative research, in addition to more advanced statistical tools. In addition to the lectures, a set of video tutorials provide deeper insights into the specifics of using statistical software and running various models therein. The course is attended jointly by students from two programmes: Strategic Entrepreneurship and Strategic Management.

This course seeks to provide students with the practical tools and theoretical vocabulary required to understand conduct, and critically evaluate quantitative empirical research. During the course, students are exposed to the key types of models, their assumptions, common data collection approaches, and statistical software needed to become a successful, independent researcher.

The following key questions are addressed in the course: First, what research design is the best fit with my research question? Second, how do I measure the concepts underpinning my research question? Third, what data do I need to collect to address this question, and what tools should I use to collect this data? Fourth, what statistical models are best suited to analyse these data? And, finally, how do I report the results of my analyses in a rigorous and statistically sound manner? This course offers answers to these questions, which are of critical importance to anyone conducting quantitative research.</body>

•    Developing the vocabulary required to communicate research design choices and empirical results.
•    Developing the ability make an informed decision regarding different data approaches.

The course deals with key concepts of rationality and choice:
- preferences and their interpretation, representation, and measurement,

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course gives an advanced introduction to problems of rationality and choice. In doing so, we will encounter and analyse a number of foundational problems associated with both decision and game theory. After having completed this course, you will be able to:
(i) name, understand, and criticise key concepts in rational choice theory from a philosophical perspective and in terms of their role for the foundations of economic theory,
(ii) critically analyse philosophical and economic contributions to decision theory in terms of their arguments, and their conceptual and methodological assumptions,
(iii) critically analyse philosophical and economic contributions to and uses of game theory in terms of their arguments, and their conceptual and methodological assumptions,

(iv) critically evaluate and engage with philosophical and economic literature in rational choice theory and any literature in the humanities and social sciences that employs rational choice theory, in an independent way.</body>

column1: If there is one problem that health care systems face and share, it is making the best use of the available resources in health care. Despite growing health care expenditures, there are never sufficient resources to meet all health care needs and demands. This means that health care somehow needs to be rationed. Baily (2003) defined rationing as follows: “To limit the beneficial health care an individual receives by any means – price or non-price, direct or indirect, explicit or implicit.” Hence, we somehow decide or organise that some care, that would benefit certain patients, is not provided (timely or freely). Although perhaps necessary and unavoidable, rationing (even the word itself) has been, is, and likely will remain a contentious topic.

In this course this important topic, which is relevant in many different health care systems, is studied, mainly from an economic perspective, also linking some issues to behavioural economic insights. We will focus on rationing in general, demand side rationing (limiting the basic benefits package and using user fees), supply side rationing (focusing on waiting lists as rationing device) and principles of rationing. Moreover, you will gain insight into how different countries ration health care.
The course consists of 6 weeks of interactive lectures.

column1: <body>Real Estate Economics covers the economic processes underlying our built environment. Based on insights from Urban Economics we look at markets for residential and commercial real estate. In this course we cover land use and land pricing, hedonic pricing, implicit prices of urban amenities, land negotiations, zoning, development, valuation and real estate as a specific class of assets.</body>

column3: In dit vak wordt eerst ingegaan op de verschillende rechtsgebieden en rechtsbronnen. Dan wordt het Nederlandse staatsrecht behandeld. Daartoe worden enkele algemene thema's belicht, zoals het juridisch staats- en wetsbegrip en de leerstukken rond bevoegdheid (legaliteitsbeginsel, attributie-delegatie-mandaat).
Bij de behandeling van de Nederlandse Grondwet komen de functie van de staatsorganen en de grondrechten uitgebreid aan bod.

Bij het onderdeel bestuursrecht leert de student kennis maken met en begrip krijgen van de hoofdlijnen van het formele en materiële bestuursrecht en komt de toepassing van de Algemene wet bestuursrecht aan de orde.
Ook de verhouding tussen nationaal en internationaal recht en de plaats van Nederland in de communautaire rechtsorde van de EU worden aan de orde gesteld.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Na afloop van deze module kan de student:
•          conflicten en vraagstukken een plaats geven in verschillende rechtsgebieden;
•          de juridische opbouw van de staat en het overheidsbestuur reproduceren;
•          de juridische neerslag van staatsvormingsbeginselen als machtenscheiding en democratische rechtsstaat aangeven;
•          de definities van publiekrechtelijke leerstukken en rechtsbeginselen herkennen;
•          in een gegeven situatie de toepasselijke rechtsbeschermingsprocedures van bezwaar en beroep tegen bestuursorganen selecteren;
•          de juridische grenzen van bestuurlijk optreden aangeven;
•          beredeneren waar beginselen en (grond)rechten onderling kunnen botsen;
•          aangeven op welke wijze internationaal publiekrecht doorwerkt in het Nederlandse recht;
•             een wettenbundel hanteren, waaronder valt het identificeren van publiekrechtelijke rechtsgebieden, wetten en wetsartikelen.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87259,2019,Recht en gezondheidszorg,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['EM Linthorst, LL.M', 'mr. CA Bol', 'mr. KGM Fleetwood Bird']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze Minor maakt u kennis met rechten van verschillende partijen in de gezondheidszorg. U wordt geconfronteerd met de theorie en praktijk van dit rechtsgebied en u zult ervaren dat praktijk en theorie niet steeds naadloos op elkaar aansluiten.

Een van de functies van het recht in onze samenleving is het voorkomen van conflicten en, als conflicten al bestaan, om deze op te lossen. Dit geldt ook voor het terrein van de gezondheidszorg, waar men soms van andere regels moet uitgaan dan in andere maatschappelijke sectoren gebruikelijk is. In deze Minor staat die specifieke wetgeving op het terrein van de gezondheidszorg centraal.

We hebben te maken met een sterke juridisering van de samenleving als geheel en van het terrein van de gezondheidszorg in het bijzonder. Medisch-technologische ontwikkelingen en maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen als de vergrijzing en fraude in de zorg, werpen niet alleen vragen en dilemma’s op rond medische, juridische, communicatieve en ethische zaken, maar ook op het gebied van de kostenbeheersing binnen de gezondheidszorg en de daarmee samenhangende toegang tot de zorg.

De Minor staat allereerst uitgebreid stil bij de rechtsbetrekkingen tussen de belangrijkste partijen in de gezondheidszorg: de burger als patiënt, de zorgaanbieder (dokter, ziekenhuis), de zorgfinancier (de verzekeraar) en de burger als verzekerde.

Aan bod komen onder meer de geneeskundige behandelingsovereenkomst, het beroepsgeheim, de rechten en plichten van patiënten, de rechten en plichten van de beroepsbeoefenaars, de aansprakelijkheid voor medische missers, het medisch tucht- en klachtrecht, medezeggenschap in de zorg, (good) governance, marktwerking, rol en taak van de overheid in de sector en het zorgverzekeringsrecht. Ook de uitdijende internationaalrechtelijke dimensie van gezondheidszorg komt aan bod. Het recht op gezondheidszorg is immers een mensenrecht en ook op dit terrein wint de Europese Unie aan invloed.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In deze Minor wordt u geprikkeld om op juridisch-medisch-ethische, sociaaleconomische en communicatieve vraagstukken te reflecteren en om op grond van de geldende regelgeving en heersende morele opvattingen hier beargumenteerd over te kunnen discussiëren. De vraag op de arbeidsmarkt naar gezondheidsrechtelijke expertise is momenteel groot. De Minor voorziet wat dat betreft in deze behoefte.</body>
