column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In deze Minor wordt u geprikkeld om op juridisch-medisch-ethische, sociaal-economische en communicatieve vraagstukken te reflecteren en om op grond van de geldende regelgeving en heersende morele opvattingen hier beargumenteerd over te kunnen discussiëren.

De gezondheidszorg beslaat inmiddels meer dan 10% van de nationale economie. Het is de sector waar verhoudingsgewijs het meeste geld in om gaat en waarin, ondanks de economische recessie, een spectaculaire groei van de werkgelegenheid is waar te nemen. In de afgelopen tien jaar groeide het aantal banen in de zorg met 385 duizend. Het totaal aantal banen in Nederland nam toe met 515 duizend. Drie kwart van de banengroei in het afgelopen decennium is dus toe te schrijven aan de zorg. De gezondheidszorg is sterk in beweging en juridiseert in toenemende mate. Met gezondheid en gezondheidszorg samenhangende economische, juridische en ethische vraagstukken halen dag in dag uit de voorpagina’s van de dagbladen.

Recht en gezondheidszorg staat allereerst uitgebreid stil bij de rechtsbetrekkingen tussen de belangrijkste partijen in de gezondheidszorg: de burger als patiënt, de zorgaanbieder (dokter, ziekenhuis), de zorgfinancier (de verzekeraar) en de burger als verzekerde. Aan bod komen onder meer de geneeskundige behandelingsovereenkomst, het beroepsgeheim, de rechten en plichten van patiënten, de rechten en plichten van de beroepsbeoefenaars, de aansprakelijkheid voor medische missers, het medisch tucht- en klachtrecht, medezeggenschap in de zorg, (good) governance, marktwerking, rol en taak van de overheid in de sector en het zorgverzekeringsrecht. Ook de uitdijende internationaalrechtelijke dimensie van gezondheidszorg komt aan bod. Het recht op gezondheidszorg is immers een mensenrecht en ook op dit terrein wint de Europese Unie aan invloed.

Een van de functies van het recht in onze samenleving is het voorkomen van conflicten en, als conflicten al bestaan, om deze op te lossen. Dit geldt ook voor het terrein van de gezondheidszorg, waar men soms van andere regels moet uitgaan dan in andere maatschappelijke sectoren gebruikelijk is. In deze Minor staat die specifieke wetgeving op het terrein van de gezondheidszorg centraal.

Het gezondheidsrecht bestaat naast eigen wetten en regels die specifiek op de gezondheidszorg van toepassing zijn, ook uit leerstukken van algemeen recht. Allereerst gaan we dan ook in op een aantal algemene rechtsgebieden, zoals het burgerlijke recht, het strafrecht, het bestuursrecht en het internationale recht. Doel is het bekend worden met de aard en de functie van deze rechtsgebieden. Daarnaast staat de betekenis hiervan voor de gezondheidszorg centraal. In sommige gevallen zal dan blijken dat het algemene recht niet voor alles een oplossing heeft, waardoor er toch weer behoefte is aan specifieke regelgeving. Ook de relatie tussen algemeen recht en bijzondere wetgeving is dus een punt van aandacht. Omdat deze Minor toegankelijk is voor studenten van verschillende studierichtingen, zullen afhankelijk van de beschikbare voorkennis, (aspecten) van te bespreken onderwerpen bekend, minder bekend of nog totaal onbekend zijn. Binnen deze Minor is dan ook een van de doelstellingen dat studenten elkaar bevragen, elkaar zaken uitleggen en zo van elkaar leren.

column1: Dit vak beoogt een verdieping te geven van het onderdeel bestuursprocesrecht van het verplichte vak Bestuursrecht.

De verschillende procedures, te weten de bezwaarschriftprocedure, het beroep bij bestuursorganen en bij de bestuursrechter, de voorlopige voorziening en procedure en het hoger beroep zullen worden behandeld.

Er wordt ingegaan op de posities van de verschillende partijen die betrokken zijn bij een bestuursrechtelijk geschil, te weten de burger, het bestuursorgaan en de beoordelende instantie. Zowel de theorie als de praktijk van het bestuursprocesrecht komt aan de orde.</body>

column1: De doelstelling van het vak Rechtsbescherming tegen de overheid is het aanleren van een kritische houding ten opzichte van de theoretische achtergronden van het geldend bestuursprocesrecht.

Het verwerven van kennis van en inzicht in het geldende bestuursprocesrecht staan centraal. Met de verworven vaardigheden zijn studenten in staat een concrete casus te beoordelen op de procesrechtelijke consequenties en de daarbij behorende strategische keuzes.

column1: Het overkoepelende thema van dit vak is ‘recht, staat en samenleving’. Onderwerpen die onder meer aan bod zullen komen zijn theorieën van het sociaal contract, democratie en rechtsstaat, grondrechten, de problematiek van multilevel legal orders en global legal pluralism, de grenzen van contractsvrijheid, de belangrijkste ethische theorieën (utilisme, deontologie en deugdenethiek), het debat over legal moralism, strafrechtstheorieën, theorieën van verdelende rechtvaardigheid, juridische beroepsethiek en het debat over universalisme versus relativisme. De relevantie van de vaak abstracte theorieën zal inzichtelijk worden gemaakt door middel van terugkoppeling naar actuele casus.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: De algemene doelstelling van het vak valt in twee delen uiteen. Het eerste doel is om de studenten kennis en inzicht te laten verwerven in de normatieve grondslagen en de achtergronden van het recht en de vier grote rechtsgebieden: privaatrecht; staats- en bestuursrecht; strafrecht; internationaal en Europees recht. Het lezen van rechtsfilosofische teksten – moderne én klassieke – is een van de methoden hierbij. Het tweede doel van het vak is om de studenten te trainen in de schriftelijke vaardigheid om filosofisch te reflecteren op het recht en een beargumenteerd normatief standpunt in te nemen. In het onderwijs worden vaardigheden, kennis en inzicht zoveel mogelijk op elkaar betrokken. Een belangrijk onderdeel van het vak vormt de onderzoeks- en schrijfvaardighedentraining in de vorm van twee schrijfopdrachten. Studenten moeten in week 2 en week 4 van het blok achtereenvolgens een rechtsfilosofische onderzoeksnotitie en een rechtsfilosofisch essay schrijven.

column1: <body>Het vak Rechtsgeschiedenis geeft een kennismaking met het Romeinse recht en met de receptie van het Romeinse recht – inclusief de politieke achtergrond daarvan. Verder laat het de rol van de rechtswetenschap zien in de bestudering van het leerstuk van de ‘onrechtmatige daad’ (art. 6:162 BW) door de eeuwen heen. Het leerstuk van de onrechtmatige daad laat goed de verschuiving tussen publiek- en privaatrecht zien. Tijdens de hoorcolleges staat de geschiedenis van de rechtswetenschap centraal. Naast de hoorcolleges en het bestuderen van literatuur en het discussiëren daarover in de tutorgroepen, zijn er practica, zoals het oplossen van Romeinsrechtelijke casusposities, het lezen van rechtshistorische bronnen en het analyseren van rechterlijke uitspraken en teksten over de onrechtmatige daad.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Het vak Rechtsgeschiedenis heeft tot doel de student inzicht bij te brengen in de historische ontwikkelingen van de rechtswetenschap en de politieke en economische factoren te beschrijven die op de rechtswetenschap en in het verlengde daarvan op de rechtspraktijk hebben ingewerkt. De student verwerft kennis van en inzicht in de hoofdlijnen van de ontwikkeling van de rechtswetenschap; hij/zij kent de contouren van de uitwendige geschiedenis van het Romeinse recht en is in staat eenvoudige casusposities op het gebied van de onrechtmatige daad op te lossen.
Het onderwijs in dit vak laat zien dat de huidige oplossingen in het recht niet alleen zaligmakend zijn. Daardoor wordt een kritische houding ten opzichte van het geldende recht bevorderd.</body>

De rechter moet achterhalen of de verdachte schuldig is aan het tenlastegelegde feit. Dat doet hij door te bekijken of er in het dossier voldoende wettige bewijsmiddelen zitten die hem overtuigen van de schuld van de verdachte. In deze minor wordt ingegaan op wat er allemaal mis kan gaan bij dit proces. Ook wordt ingegaan op een alternatieve, rekenkundige manier van bewijsweging, de zogenoemde Bayesiaanse benadering. Bewijsmiddelen die aan bod komen zijn: getuigenverklaringen, herkenningen en bekentenissen. Verder wordt onder meer ingegaan op leugendetectie, verhoren en tunnelvisie.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Tijdens dit vak worden deelnemers bekend gemaakt met de volgende onderwerpen:

column2: • Diagnostische waarde.
• Bayesiaanse analyse.
• Tunnelvisie.
• Waarneming en geheugen.
• Getuigen- en verdachtenverhoren.
• Leugendetectie.

column4: Dit vak biedt een inleiding in de rechtssociologie, waarin de wereld van het recht centraal staat. Die wereld gaan we mede aan de hand van de actualiteit verkennen op empirische wijze. Daarbij laten we zien welke sociale (f)actoren het recht beïnvloeden en –omgekeerd– welke rol het recht in de samenleving speelt. Aandacht wordt besteed aan wetgevingspraktijken en zo wordt inzicht gegeven in de feitelijke processen die schuilgaan achter de teksten die in het Staatsblad verschijnen. Tevens worden inkijkjes geboden in de wereld van de advocatuur en die van de rechterlijke macht. Daarbij laten we zien hoe die werelden veranderen in relatie tot de algemene veranderingen die in de samenleving als geheel aanwijsbaar zijn. Een belangrijk aandachtspunt is ook het thema handhaving, waarbij wordt ingegaan op vraagstukken rond effectiviteit van wetgeving en regelnaleving.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90990,2019,Rechtsvergelijkend strafrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['prof.mr. PAM Mevis', 'prof.mr. PAM Verrest']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>

column1: Het onderwijs wordt opgebouwd in drie fasen. De eerste fase is gewijd aan het kennismaken met rechtsvergelijking (wat is dat?) (waartoe dient het?) en het leren van de wetenschappelijke methoden waarmee rechtsvergelijking kan plaatsvinden. In een buitenlands wetboek rondneuzen kan iedereen, maar hoe kan worden gekomen tot een gedegen analyse van de betekenis en werking van buitenlandse strafrechtelijke wetgeving? Kennis van een buitenlands rechtsstelsel (wel aangeduid als Auslandstudie) is bovendien nog geen rechtsvergelijking: daarvoor moeten op verantwoorde wijze vergelijkbare elementen uit het onderzochte buitenlandse rechtsstelsel en het Nederlandse recht met elkaar in verband worden gebracht. In de colleges 2 tot en met 5 wordt samen met de studenten precies dit traject doorlopen. De stappen die in dit proces worden gezet, worden in de colleges duidelijk gemarkeerd en in het kader van active academic learning in dialoogvorm besproken. De collegereeks mondt in het laatste college uit in een met de studenten samen ‘live’ uitgevoerd concreet rechtsvergelijkend onderzoek inzake een actueel vraagstuk op het terrein van het strafrecht. Tentatief kan worden gedacht aan

Rechtsvergelijking voor modernisering van het Wetboek van Strafvordering/voor de discussie over gronden voor herziening/voor de nieuwe zedentitel in het Wetboek van Strafrecht etc. Op deze wijze wordt meteen ook geoefend voor het tentamen, dat bestaat uit de opdracht om zelf rechtsvergelijkend onderzoek te verrichten naar een actueel strafrechtelijk vraagstuk.

column2: <title></title>

column1: Rechtsvergelijking speelt een steeds grotere rol in de nationale en internationale rechtspraak (denk aan Hof van Justitie EU en EHRM) en bij de voorbereiding en totstandkoming van nieuwe (inter)nationale strafrechtelijke wetgeving.
Dit mastervak laat studenten kennis maken met strafrechtsvergelijking in theorie en praktijk.
Zelfstandige beheersing van rechtsvergelijking als onderzoeksmethode, teneinde op verantwoorde wijze rechtsvergelijkend onderzoek te verrichten naar actuele strafrechtelijke vraagstukken.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86969,2019,Recognition in the Visual Arts,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['U Hahn, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This class examines recognition within the art world. As in most fields, recognition and renown can lead to various types of artistic success, from economic gain to critical acclaim. However, recognition in the arts is better understood as a social phenomenon, rather than exclusively the consequence of an artistic creator or artwork’s characteristics. Field conventions dictate what is created and ""greatness"" is evaluated according to the standards of time, place, and those professionals credentialed to offer their opinion. In this course, we will take such a sociological perspective in order to arrive at a better understanding of why certain creators are celebrated, while the majority of art and artists are largely unknown. We begin by thinking about what is recognition in the art world and what the different forms of recognition are. Next we discuss what factors contribute to differences in exposure and value. As this course is a research workshop, once we have discussed these questions, we will begin to empirically find answers. Students will conduct a small research project in which they examine recognition in the art world.
Note: It is highly recommended for entry into this course that students have completed the first year course on Methods.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>There are several objectives for this course. First, students gain insight into the sociological examination of the art world and are able to decipher how artistic recognition is formed and what social factors contribute to valuation. Second, students are able to critically read, reflect upon, and synthesize research articles and, ultimately, use them in forming their own research design. Third, students are able to conduct a small research project on recognition in the art world and report on the final work both through written and oral description.</body>

Oudijn', 'dr. J.W. van Neck', 'dr. M.J. Koudstaal', 'drs. D.C.M. Wiryasaputra', 'prof. dr. R.W. Selles', 'S.A.E. Konings, BSc']",,

column1: Staatsrecht en bestuursrecht zijn opgebouwd uit rechtsnormen en praktijken die betrekking hebben op verschillende elementen van de uitoefening van openbaar gezag door de overheid. De plaats van de Grondwet en de Algemene wet bestuursrecht verdient uiteraard centrale aandacht, maar daarnaast zijn ook de ongeschreven publiekrechtelijke rechtsnormen – vertrouwensregel, conventies, algemene beginselen van behoorlijk bestuur – van groot belang, en is er de rechtspraak van verschillende hoogste rechters die heeft bijgedragen aan de ontwikkeling van het publiekrecht.

Kwam in blok 2 het rechtsstatelijk kader aan de orde (Rechten van de mens en grondrechten, Rechtsbescherming tegen de overheid), het vak Regeren en besturen zal studenten vertrouwd maken met de organisatie van de overheid en de instrumenten die zij kan hanteren. Vragen van verantwoordelijkheid en verantwoording (accountability), machtenscheiding, checks and balances, en evenwicht van machten, behoren tot de onderwerpen die in dit vak aan de orde (kunnen) komen.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Het vak Regeren en besturen is een staats- en bestuursrechtelijk integratievak. Het beoogt de studenten vertrouwd te maken met problemen die zowel in het staatsrecht als in het bestuursrecht aan de orde zijn. Daartoe zullen ook de historische ontwikkeling van het publiekrecht in Nederland, en de internationale en Europese context waarbinnen dat publiekrecht heden ten dage functioneert, aan de orde kunnen komen.

Het doel van het vak Regeren en besturen is om studenten te vertrouwd te maken met de organisatie van de overheid en de instrumenten die zij kan hanteren. Het verkrijgen van inzicht in vragen van verantwoordelijkheid en verantwoording (accountability), machtenscheiding, en het verkrijgen van de vaardigheid om onderzoek te doen naar - en deel te nemen aan een juridisch debat over – die vragen, behoren tot de leerdoelen van dit vak.

column1: De Research Workshop strekt zich uit over de blokken 2 t/m 4 en is erop gericht de studenten voor te bereiden op en te begeleiden bij het schrijven van hun master thesis. Deze workshop omvat alle fasen van het schrijven van de thesis tot en met het presenteren van het eindresultaat. Studenten kiezen binnen het brede thema van de Research Workshop een eigen onderzoeksonderwerp. Vóór het begin van blok 2 wordt een thesismarkt georganiseerd waarna studenten een keuze maken voor één van de aangeboden Research Workshops en onderzoeksthema’s. Elke Research Workshop kent dezelfde opzet:
- bespreking van literatuur als inleiding op het thema
- individuele sessies met de thesis begeleider
- bespreking van en informatie over mogelijke onderzoeksmethoden
Blok 4: drie plenaire bijeenkomsten en tussentijdse (individuele) sessies met de thesis begeleider
- bespreking van case studies en ander work-in-progress
- presentatie van het thesis onderzoek tijdens Master conferentie juni 2015
- participatie in discussies na afloop van presentaties
Het eindcijfer met het tentamenbriefje voor de Research Workshop wordt gegeven aan het einde van blok 4.
Thema: Reizigers in tijd en ruimte: egodocumenten 1600-1940

De overtuiging dat mensen zelf vorm kunnen geven aan hun persoon en aan de samenleving waarin zij leven, won veld in de 18e eeuw. Mensen konden daarbij leren van voorbeelden en adviezen. In toenemende mate kon men zich daarover informeren in boeken, variërend van (auto)biografieën tot etiquetteboeken, opvoedkundige adviesboeken en, later, romans. Ook de confrontatie met andere volkeren leidde tot een duidelijker definitie van het eigene. Daarover kon wie niet zelf op reis ging geïnformeerd worden door reisverslagen, een steeds populairder genre. Omgekeerd werden Nederlanders en het Nederlandse volk bekeken door buitenlandse ogen. Dat beeld werd eveneens vastgelegd in reisverslagen en reisgidsen, waarvan er steeds meer verschenen dankzij de opkomst   van het moderne toerisme. Dezelfde ontwikkelingen deden zich voor in andere Europese landen. De late 18e eeuw was hierbij een cruciale periode met ook de opkomst van de moderne pedagogie en psychologie, en de groeiende populariteit van vormende kinderliteratuur en adviesboeken. Het is de periode waarin een modern toekomstgericht lineair tijdsbesef ontstond en het daarmee verbonden idee dat de geschiedenis onomkeerbaar is, dat het utopisch denken sterk stimuleerde en waarin de gedachte van een ‘maakbare’ samenleving werd ontwikkeld. Op grond van diverse bronnen - egodocumenten, adviesboeken, biografieën, kinderboeken, reisverslagen en utopieën - zal getracht worden greep  te krijgen op deze en andere mentaal-culturele ontwikkelingen in de overgangsperiode naar de moderniteit.

column1: <div>In this course we look at how religion is variously defined in relation to its content and performance as well as to the ways in which religion is organized and impacts on society. Believers rather than believes are central in our approach, religion being considered to be part of particular historical and cultural contexts and – often - wider global networks. In the lectures Christianity and Islam figure prominently, representing the two largest religious traditions on the globe, but due attention will be paid to other traditions. For their assignments and final papers students select one define their own topic in one of following fields:

column2: • Religion and colonization (missionaries, colonial policies, local responses, postcolonial developments)
• Religion, migration and citizenship (diaspora’s, transnational communities, debates and policies concerning (national) identities, including issues of gender)
• Living religion (religion as lifestyle, rituals and beliefs ordering daily life and –possibly- the hereafter)
<title></title>

column1: Students acquire knowledge of the various concepts and definitions of religion and of the changing nature of religion and religious organisation and within a global perspective. They acquire the skills to analyse specific cases of social and cultural developments in modern history in which religion is or appears to be a key element as well as the skills to present their findings in a scholarly final paper.

column1: World War II until today is an important reference point in popular historical culture, both in the Netherlands and elsewhere. Other large-scale conflicts, such as the First World War, the Cold War  and the recent wars in the Middle East, are as well appealing historical experiences with an impact on the collective memory. But the way wars are represented and collectively remembered is anything but immutable and unambiguous. The ways in which wars of the past were brought to the fore (usually outside of academia) during the 20th and 21st centuries for a variety of audiences are quite diverse: ranging from museum exhibitions to comics and novels, and from films and musicals to games and new media. In this course the focus is on the question in what kind of historical representations of war all these elements have resulted, and what meanings are assigned to it? What are the expectations of both producers and consumers regarding different ways of presenting this past, and which views exist on understanding and – in as far as possible - 'experiencing' past wars. The emphasis will be on war representations in the popular historical culture of the Western world.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 25.

column1: The aim of the course is to gain knowledge and understanding of the ways in which wars from the early 20th century to the beginning of the 21st century are represented and framed in popular historical culture. Students learn in what ways a diversity of media and other forms of historical presentation reflect memories and visions of various large-scale conflicts and how developments in these representations relate  to historical interpretations.

column1: Within a university, teaching and research are combined. At the master level, you will be brought into closer contact with the research. Ultimately, you will have to conduct scholarly research yourself (in your master's thesis). Both for research and in legal practice, certain academic and practical skills are indispensable.

The course in research & writing skills enables you to acquire these skills and to practice. This objective is reached through the writing of papers, making a presentation and through other small-scale seminar forms. The teaching takes place within a small group of students and under the guidance and supervision of one of the researchers. This way you will develop the skills necessary both for legal practice and for academic legal research.</body>

The aim of this course is to develop students’ critical understanding of how to conduct and present research in an organizational setting. Specifically, by the end of this course, students will be familiar with the philosophy that underpins the choice of research design, will gain knowledge about the main methodologies used in HRM and OB research, and will be able to provide a convincing justification for their selected methodology.  To advance the goal of developing the skills necessary to carry out and present independent research work, the course will focus on both lectures and writing exercises.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Learning goals: In this course, you will gain the following:

column2: • A thorough grounding in conducting and presenting organisational and management research;
• An understanding of the different ways of designing research studies
• An understanding of how to apply this knowledge and these skills to research questions in the areas of Human Resource Management and Organisational Behaviour;
• The skills necessary to write well-grounded research proposals, and in particular a proposal for the Master Thesis.

column1: The aim of this course is to offer the foundational considerations for starting your thesis project. Specifically, it focuses on a variety of topics around the first, theory-focused part of your thesis (rather than the empirical part)—including topic choice, research question formulation, framing, and hypothesis development. These topics will be addressed in a series of lectures, building on published work on doing research as well as the experiences and submissions of prior students.

In addition to these subjects, a key aim of the course is to provide students with practical insights with respect to writing academic work, including but not limited to: identifying relevant literature, the issue of plagiarism, writing style, referencing style, reading academic papers, organizing your notes, and using the TOP system.  </body>

column1: Research design refers to a series of interrelated decisions about the kinds of questions that can be answered empirically (and ethically) and the theoretical and social justification for those questions, as well as considerations on how data should be sampled, collected and analyzed, and on how (certain kinds of) inferences and conclusions can be drawn. In this course, students strengthen their research design skills by carefully scrutinizing successful research proposals and designing a research project (proposal) of their own. They formulate scientifically sound research questions, make and justify decisions about literature review, data collection and analysis, data management and research ethics. By presenting and discussing their work in class, they also engage in peer review processes, sharing and receiving suggestions for and from their peers. Seminar discussions pay special attention to the relationship between theory and research; alternative methodological approaches and styles/traditions of research within the social sciences, as well as the pros and cons of combining methods; personal involvement and/or bias; research ethics and data management. Practical constraints that affect research decisions are also considered.

The course is meant to advance and systematize previous knowledge and experience students already have in social scientific research in general. It prepares students for the more specialized methodological courses that follow.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

During the Master’s program, students have the opportunity to explore a professional field of interest by means of a Research Internship. Arrangements have been made with around 15-20 national and international archives, museums, research institutes, educational organizations and business companies for research projects which students may select as the subject for their Master’s thesis. Please note that this is not a policy-related internship; it involves an academic research project. The final product may be a publication, an international workshop, website, object analysis or exhibition storyline. This research activity covers 18 working days (5 ECTS). Some internships are linked to the research of a master thesis.

All internships will be announced at the end of term-1 on BlackBoard; there is also an indication whether an internship is linked to a master thesis subject. The internships will also be presented at the Master Thesis Market.

Each student formulates a working plan after consultation with the faculty supervisor and the supervisor of the internship institution. Based on that working plan, an official Agreement Research Internship Master History of Society will be signed by: the student, the supervisor of the institution and the faculty supervisor. The research internship will be completed with a report, written by the student according to the guidelines of the master. The report contains also appendixes with important outcomes and products (written or images of the products). The whole report and internship will be assessed during a final interview with the supervisors. Based on this interview the supervisor of the institution will write a general assessment. The faculty supervisor will assess whether the student
has reached the aims of this internship; there is no grade. For an explanation see the documents on the websitehttp://www.eshcc.eur.nl/english/history/mahs/current/researchinternship/.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students are acquainted with the main sectors of employment: culture, education, research, business, diplomacy
• Students are able to conduct a research internship in a professional organization
• Students are able to discern their future labour market

column1: <body>In het blok Research Lab – de Basis van de opleiding Criminologie komen vaardigheden die relevant zijn voor een criminoloog aan bod. Studenten ontwikkelen vaardigheden gerelateerd aan analyseren, argumenteren en juridiseren. Dit blok richt zich in vier modules op onderzoeksmethoden, (wetenschappelijke) schrijfvaardigheden, het toepassen van rechtsregels en het schrijven van een juridisch betoog. column1: <body>In het blok Research Lab – de Toepassing van de opleiding Criminologie komen vaardigheden die relevant zijn voor een criminoloog aan bod. Studenten ontwikkelen vaardigheden gerelateerd aan analyseren, argumenteren en juridiseren. Dit blok richt zich in vier modules op onderzoeksmethoden, (wetenschappelijke) schrijfvaardigheden en pleiten. De onderzoeksmethoden bestaan uit kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve analyses. Deze gevorderde vaardigheden worden toegepast op een criminologisch relevant en blijvend actueel onderwerp: surveillance door de overheid.</body>

column1: The course is devoted to practical and ethical issues related to the academic field of the social sciences. In these meetings, students will learn about several key aspects of this field, including aspects that are particularly relevant for PhD students and other junior researchers. Each meeting starts with an introduction/presentation  by a staff member, which is followed by an open  and informal discussions between all participants. This format is explicitly meant to leave plenty of opportunities for students to raise relevant issues themselves.

column1: This course will provide students with an understanding on the basics of qualitative and quantitative research methods, as well as the skills to design, conduct and analyze a research study. The overall aim of the course is to provide students with insights and skills to make informed choices regarding the research design to be used for their MSc thesis. The course is structured to coincide with work on the master thesis.

In this course we provide an overview of methodological principles underlying both qualitative and quantitative methods. We will cover the following topics: formulating research questions, research strategies and designs, the nature of qualitative and quantitative research, reviewing the literature, common types of data collection methods (interviewing, surveys, and experiments), sampling, data analysis, writing, and research ethics.

Note: In continuation of this course, students will do a second course (Research Methodology II) that consists of workshops that they can pick based on what methods they need for their thesis. These workshops will take place from March to May 2020.
Classes in the first part will consist of lectures, group discussions, and in-class exercises in which an application of a particular research method is reviewed.

After each session, students will have to do an assignment on Canvas and provide feedback to two randomly assigned and anonymized assignments. Deadlines for assignments are at 22h00 on the day of the session; deadlines for feedback are at 23h00 on the next working day after the session. Assignments contribute 90% to the final grade; the feedback contributes 10% to the final grade.</body>

•    Describe the qualities and limitations of various approaches to qualitative and quantitative research, including the strengths and drawbacks of different data sources
•    Reflect on the considerations inherent in designing and undertaking a research study, in the context of their own thesis.

column1: This course will be your kick-off into the world of research and will cover the fundamental principles of science, research designs, measurement, sampling, and ethics. This basic material will lay the groundwork for the more technical stuff that we will cover in subsequent courses. We will use examples from a range of disciplines, including: economy, sociology, political sciences, and psychology.

This course makes use of a blended learning format, which describes the growing phenomenon by which students learn at least in part by way of digital or online media. Here, the online component is the video lectures. Video lectures replace traditional in-class lectures and are provided by UvA through an existing Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) entitled Quantitative Methods. At EUC, weekly offline tutorials are held in which small groups discuss the course material with their tutor, and complete exercises aimed at understanding the practical side of the conceptual material presented in the video lectures. This blended learning format allows you significantly more control over the pace and style in which you learn the course material.

The different assignments in this course are aimed at (i) developing a thorough understanding of academic papers that will allow students to critically reflect on their methodology before trusting their results; (ii) applying concepts and methods that are covered in the course in order to empirically test theories from various disciplines.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The goal of this course is to equip you with basic knowledge of the principles of the scientific method and the most important methodological concepts in the social and behavioral sciences. With this knowledge and hands-on practice, you will be able to evaluate research articles in terms of their methodological quality and design your own research. The course will give you insight into the current controversies surrounding the integrity of research in the social and behavioral sciences. It will also prepare you for subsequent courses on statistics and a capstone project where you will apply all this methodological and statistical knowledge and skills in performing your own research project.

column2: • the scientific method, its principles, and criteria for evaluation
• the most important types of research and research designs
• measurement, measurement methods, and criteria for evaluation of measurement instruments
• sampling and sampling techniques
• ethics and integrity in science
• evaluating research articles in terms of their methodological quality
• identifying solutions for methodological weaknesses found within (published) academic articles
• establishing your own research question
• proposing a research design for a given research question

This module, which covers both quantitative and qualitative research methods, is an advanced sequel to Module 1 and Module 4. In particular, Module 11 encompasses case study research, design science, and survey research.

After completion of this module, participants will have developed a draft research proposal and will have developed a deeper understanding of the essential components of academic research and reporting. In particular, participants will develop the knowledge and capabilities that are required to design and execute a master thesis research project.</body>

column1: Massive Online Open Course (on Coursera): ‘Studying Cities: Social Science methods for Urban Research’

Part 1 builds on the MOOC and discusses academic research and research approaches applied in different academic disciplines. The module discusses how to conduct research, how to formulate and fine tune the problem statement, sound research objectives and questions, how to set research objectives, validity and validity. It discusses research ethics.
Part 2: Operationalization, Data Collection and Research Instruments

Part 2 comprises lectures, workshops and a practical assignment. It is devoted to the operationalization of the theoretical framework. It focuses on research strategy, data collection methods and instruments necessary to implement the research work. The course presents different research strategies, data collection methods and sampling techniques. Finally, students will learn how to construct data collection instruments, i.e. questionnaires, interview guides and protocols.

Part 3 comprises workshops on data preparation and analysis. Participants can choose between workshops on SPSS, STATA or Atlas.ti. In these workshops they will learn how to construct a data base, how to prepare the data for analysis and how to analyse and interpret the data.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Doel van het leeronderzoek is een eerste kennismaking met de sociaalwetenschappelijke onderzoekspraktijk, waarin  studenten groepsgewijs een  empirische cyclus doorlopen van een sociaalwetenschappelijk, hypothese toetsend onderzoek aan de hand van opdrachten . Dit onderzoek begint met een theoretisch zo goed mogelijk beredeneerd voorlopig antwoord op een relevante onderzoeksvraag waarvan vervolgens de houdbaarheid op een methodisch verantwoorde wijze empirisch wordt getoetst. In de conclusies wordt een helder antwoord gegeven op de eerder geformuleerde onderzoeksvraag en hypothesen. Afsluitend wordt gereflecteerd op de beperkingen en opbrengsten van hun onderzoek.

Er wordt geoefend met twee benaderingen: een kwantitatieve, hypothese toetsende benadering en een aanvullende of verdiepende kwalitatieve benadering waarbij dataverzameling en theoretische reflectie elkaar voeden. In elk van beide benaderingen voeren studenten opdrachten uit die uiteindelijk leiden tot het doorlopen van de gehele onderzoekscyclus. De opdrachten vormen de bouwstenen van een onderzoeksverslag dat door de studenten wordt geschreven.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na afloop van het vak is de student in staat om:
• een relevante en beantwoordbare centrale onderzoeksvraag te formuleren;
• een studie te verrichten van relevante literatuur die helpt bij het opzetten van onderzoek en het beantwoorden van de centrale onderzoeksvraag;
• een passend conceptueel model op te stellen met daarbij behorende hypothesen;
• op een verantwoorde manier variabelen te operationaliseren;
• een bescheiden kwantitatief onderzoek op te zetten en uit te voeren met behulp van een enquête;
• een aanvullend en of verdiepend kwalitatief onderzoek op te zetten en uit te voeren met behulp van semigestructureerde interviews;
• de vooropgestelde hypothesen te toetsen met een regressieanalyse van data uit de enquête en inhoudsanalyse van interviews;
• de bevindingen van onderzoek systematisch en helder te rapporteren in een onderzoeksverslag;
• productief te kunnen samenwerken met anderen en in een goede onderlinge verstandhouding de empirische onderzoekscylcus te doorlopen.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• The structure of a research paper;
• causality;
• null hypothesis testing;
• interpreting regression results, including p-values and confidence intervals;
• understanding bias using the potential outcomes framework;
• how to use uni- and multivariate regression to make predictions;
• why non-experimental data typically do not yield consistent estimators of causal effects;
• the internal and external validity of experimental results;
• logit average marginal effects and the linear probability model;
• interpretation of the coefficients of dummy variables and interaction terms;
• forecasting;
• using Stata.
• There will be four plenary lectures: in weeks 1, 2, 3, and 6.

• In the first three weeks, you will complete three online quizzes on Canvas, which will guide you through the learning materials: the first quiz provides information on the topic of this year’s regular assignment: equality of opportunity; the second quiz aims to improve your understanding of econometrics; and the third quiz helps you to brush up your Stata skills. Completion of these online quizzes is compulsory to pass the course and to be allowed to submit your individual homework (see the next item), but they will not count towards your final grade.

• In weeks 1 through 3, students will submit individual homework every week (3 times 5% of your final grade). These three homework problem sets will be graded individually, and form the basis of the regular assignment report that you will write together with your fellow group members (see below). If you get stuck, you may consult your team members but the answers should be your own. Guidelines on how to report your results (e.g. references, tables, figures) will be provided and these guidelines will be strictly enforced by the graders of your individual homework and your group reports.

• Together with your fellow group members, you will hand in the research proposal for the creative assignment in week 5 (10% of your final grade). During the compulsory midterm meeting with an OP team member in week 5, you will discuss this research proposal, as well as any questions you may have about the course materials.

• You will write the reports on the regular (25% of your final grade) and the creative assignment (20% of your final grade) together with your three fellow group members, to be submitted in weeks 5 and 7, respectively. These reports will be assessed at the group (and not the individual) level. There will be inspection sessions for the regular and creative assignment reports, after the lecture of week 6 and in week 9, respectively.

• We encourage all students to meet with their fellow group members (in person, or through Zoom or Skype) at least once a week, for at least two hours, to work on the assignments. Schedule tese meetings at the start of the course. This should enable you to learn from each other.

• During the optional question sessions which, depending on the week, will be held once or twice per week, your group will have the opportunity to discuss with the RP team any questions you may have on that week’s topics. You can submit your questions by email to RP team member [TBD] until 5 PM on the day before a question session, to allow the RP team members to prepare in advance. These question sessions form the core of this course, and we recommend that your group uses this opportunity to get personalized guidance approximately three times throughout the course, depending on need. Try to have all team members attend. Brief answers to the questions that came in will be published in the Q&A-thread on the Canvas discussion board.

• In week 8, there will be a compulsory oral defense of your group work (30% of your final grade, differentiation of the grade between group members is possible). You will be questioned on all of the materials that are offered in this course, and on all aspects of your group work.

column1: You will be required to actively participate from week 1. Doing and understanding research cannot be learned by cramming large amounts of knowledge in a brief period of time, right before an exam. It can only be learned by doing it. This means that for this course, you will be required to actively participate, also in the first weeks. It is therefore advisable to hit the ground running and make a flying start! to compensate for the relatively high workload in the first weeks, there will be no exam so in later weeks you’ll have a bit more time to focus on exams for other courses.

column2: • You will form a group of four students on Canvas using “People/RP group”, before the first lecture. You can discuss group formation issues in the group matchmaking thread on the Canvas discussion board of this course. Students who have not registered for a four-person will be assigned to a group by the RP team. The group member who is the first to register will be the group leader, (s)he will be responsible for registering your group for the midterm meeting, the defense, the question sessions, and for submission of the group assignments.

• Your group leader will register a slot for the midterm meeting in week 5 and the defense in week 8 through Canvas’s calendar function. Only complete groups of four students should register for these meetings. Since attendance is compulsory, please ensure that all group members are available before booking a slot. Registration will be open from the moment that the course is published on Canvas.

• The acceptable file formats when submitting materials are .pdf and .do. The names of files that are submitted as a group should start with the student number of the group leader. The names of the files that you individually submit should start with the student number of the group leader, followed by your own student number.

• Only emails to RP team member [TBD]  will be considered. Do not email other RP team members directly, and also do not send messages through the Canvas direct messaging function, unless you are replying to a message that was sent by the RP team.

column1: Increasingly, employers are looking to hire employees who know how to handle big data files, or who have the skills to use the results from data analyses as inputs for operational or policy advice. Our aim is to help you understand how to apply modern econometric methods, and to help you develop the skills that will allow you to do quantitative empirical research yourself.

In this course, Research Project, you will apply the econometric methods from the course Introductory Econometrics to several data sets. You will write two reports, in the form of research articles, describing your findings. We will refer to the assignments that will help you to write these two reports as the “regular assignment” and the “creative assignment”.

Writing these reports will help you improve your understanding of econometric methods, your Stata skills, and you will gain experience with reporting your findings in a structured manner. Each of the two reports will look like academic articles, following the guidelines that you learned during the course Academic Skills. Taken together, these components of Research Project will provide you with a solid basis for writing your Bachelor’s thesis.

This course has two major goals. First, it intends to provide students with a greater understanding in three topics in health economics which do not receive much attention in other courses of the master. Second, students will gain more in-depth knowledge by applying the econometric tools taught in the course Quantitative Methods for Applied Economics to data on each of the three topics.

The emphasis of the course is on the research angle. For each topic, a) introductory lectures will be given to set the scene; b) next, students have to read papers, and solve an empirical group assignment which will consequently be discussed in class; and c) finally, students have to do an individual econometric analysis based on real-life datasets.

column2: • ageing, health care costs (and pensions)
• the Becker-Murphy rational addiction model and unhealthy habits
• health and the labor market

column1: All students that have participated in the exam/assignments of 'Quantitative Methods for Applied Economics (QMAE)' can enroll for the course, including students that failed the exam/assignments.
The exam is composed of three individual assignments. Only the final grade will be published in Osiris
Only the final grade will be published in Osiris.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The major aim of this course is to acquire and apply economic and econometric tools to health issues. After this course, students should have a greater understanding of the three aforementioned topics in health economics, and have more hands-on experience with the tools acquired in the course Quantitative Methods for Applied Economics. More exactly, students should be able to:

column2: • define the relations between ageing populations and health care expenditures
• use the Becker-Murphy rational addiction model to evaluate public health policy in the domain of unhealthy habits
• understand the important linkages between health, health insurance and the organization of the labour market, and retirement behaviour

column1: Students should also be able to:

column2: • combine data, economic theory and econometric tools to analyze data on one of the three topics
• present research findings on each of the 3 aforementioned topics
• discuss these research findings with classmates

column1: <body>During the research traineeship in the first year of the Research master's programme, students participate in one of the Faculty's research projects or in an external research project which is led by a Faculty member or in which a Faculty Member is involved as an advisor. The traineeship results in (a substantial contribution to) a research paper or research report and familiarizes students with some of the most vital research activities: developing a research project, writing a research proposal, doing the actual research and data analysis, and presenting research findings in the form of a research paper or research report and an oral presentation. In principle, the research subject should fit within the fields that are covered in the research master's and it should fit within the Faculty's current research projects and research interests. In order to guarantee the suitability and quality of the supervision and the traineeship, a concise research traineeship proposal should be submitted to the Programme directors who need to approve of the chosen subject and content of the traineeship before the start of the traineeship. A research traineeship includes at least the following components:

column2: • Research activities
• One presentation
• Self Reflection
• Contribution to research report or research paper
• Attendance and active participation in presentations by fellow students.

<body>This research workshop introduces students to the main issues concerned with doing cross-national comparative research in communication and media, while it also offers them advanced training in writing a comprehensive literature review on a research topic of their own choosing. It is a practical course that introduces students to a number of important steps in the choices to make when carrying out cross-national and/or comparative research.</body>

column2: • The main theoretical principles and methods of cross-national comparative research in the field of media and communication;
• The possibilities and limitations of conducting a literature reviews.
• Conduct a systematic analysis and critical evaluation of the secondary literature on selected issues or topics in the field of communication and media;
• Write a clear and balanced literature review as a team, presenting the state of knowledge regarding their chosen cross-national and comparative research topic;
• Work collaboratively on small and large international teams while profiting from and reflecting on the diverse input this entails;
• Manage a team project

We will study selected aspects of methodology (what is research?) and empirical research methods (how do we collect and analyze data?). These topics will be applied to the students' research questions. During the course, students gradually expand the research proposal for their master thesis. Students first choose a topic and develop a possible research question, a preliminary draft of their research proposal will follow. Then they explore different ways of investigating their topic in order to decide on the most promising way forward and to improve the clarity, coherence and feasibility of their project. At the end of the course, the research proposal is assessed and successful participants move on to execute their project in Terms 3 and 4.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>From Hobbiton to Graceland to 221b Baker Street, media tourism – visiting places in the wake of popular media texts and objects – is a growing industry. While connected to traditional forms of sightseeing, media tourism asks different questions about the relationship between the mass media, its audiences, and physical places. What are tourists looking for? How are these attractions marketed and managed? And what about the locals, who see their home suddenly becoming a fictional location swarming with tourists? What does the increased prominence of this kind of tourism say about the relationship between imagination and reality in an era characterized by an increasing omnipresence of the media and global mobility? These are the sort of questions asked in this course. Students will explore different aspects of media tourism, from its origins and history, its connection to other parts of the tourism industry, its relationships to audience- and fan-practices, managerial aspects, and tourist experiences in order to foster a sophisticated understanding of this multifaceted phenomenon. Starting from this, students will create their own small research project on an aspect of media tourism that interests them. Students will use research techniques and methodology from cultural studies and qualitative sociology, hence it is advised to be familiar with these before partaking the course.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This research workshop will introduce students to the key issues in media tourism: that is, tourism inspired by (popular) media, such as films, TV-series, music, literature and video-games. Students will be able to identify the current themes within the studies of media tourism and related fields to orient themselves within the relevant theories and methods. Students will practice critical analysis of sociological empirical research in the field of media tourism in order to learn the way research is done in practice and reported in publications. Students will extend this knowledge through small qualitative research and hands-on experience of collecting and analysing data, developing a research design and reporting on their findings.</body>

column1: Within a university, teaching and research are combined. At the master level, you will be brought into closer contact with the research. Ultimately, you will have to conduct scholarly research yourself (in your master's thesis). Both for research and in legal practice, certain academic and practical skills are indispensable.

The course in research & writing skills enables you to acquire these skills and to practice them. This objective is reached through the writing of papers, making a presentation, debates and through other small-scale seminars. The teaching takes place within a small group of students and under the guidance and supervision of one of the researchers. This way you will develop the skills necessary both for legal practice and for academic legal research.</body>

column1: In this course students will explore the legal dimensions of cooperation at the level of the European Union and at the international level. This course will give a foretaste of topics, which will be revisited and dealt with in greater depth during subsequent courses of the master programme. This course serves a dual purpose: (1) it provides an introduction to master level studies and (2) it provides training for the acquisition and development of research, writing and presentation skills. The sessions will cover three main parts, which are reflected in the structure of the course: substance, methodology and skills.

The substantive theme of this course focuses on European Union (EU) and international law and the interactions between these two legal orders, with significant attention devoted to processes of economic integration. During the course, students will acquire active working knowledge of essential international and EU law principles, rules, institutions and decision-making processes. Students will have the opportunity to practice their research, writing and presentation skills by considering some of the following broad themes: the evolution of the international and EU legal orders; the roles of various international and EU actors and the interplay between them; the mechanisms for and intricacies of decision-making in a multilevel context; market integration within the EU and economic cooperation on the international plane; the role of courts and compliance bodies in international and EU law. Throughout the course students will be challenged to consider the socio-economic and political context in which international and EU law instruments and actors operate. Furthermore, they will consider how international and EU law may impact societal values related to the rule of law democracy, human rights and the protection of the environment. This also entails taking into consideration ethical concerns in the development and application of EU and international law.

In this process, students will acquaint themselves with both primary sources (i.e. the relevant legal framework) and with relevant academic literature. Students will develop their research, writing and presentation skills by analyzing relevant legal developments and by placing these developments in the critical context offered by academic literature. By combining substantive knowledge with academic skills students will develop their own critical analysis of the role that law plays within the EU and at the international level. In order to develop these skills, several sessions will be devoted to both research methodology and different legal methods (e.g. case analysis, comparative and empirical legal research). Students are also encouraged to examine the relevance of other disciplines, such as economics, political science, public administration, ethics and sociology, for a better understanding of the context and dynamics of the European and international legal orders.

By developing their research, writing and presentation skills, students will at the same time be preparing for the subsequent courses of the master programme, in which active academic learning is key. Moreover, students will be developing a solid basis for enhancing their knowledge and ability to work with EU and international law. In essence, this course provides students with transferable knowledge and skills, including the capacity to identify legal problems and develop solutions thereto, research a given legal topic, frame a research question, work with large volumes of legal information and select relevant legal sources, conduct rigorous legal analysis, synthesize their findings in a well structured and written paper, and orally present their findings. These skills are essential for the successful completion of the IEUL master, including the finalization of the master thesis.

column1: As a result of this course students will be able to independently:

column2: • Conduct research on a specific legal topic by critically analyzing and assessing legal sources with a view to offer a substantiated account based on this research (learning objectives 1, 4 and 9);
• Identify and analyze the relevant legal questions pertaining to European and international law (learning objective 5);

• Identify the multifarious effects of legal institutions of international and European Union law, by considering insights from other disciplines, such as political science, sociology and economics (learning objective 3);
• Work better with others, especially through a peer review process (learning objective 7);
• Present academically sound legal research in a clear and structured manner (learning objective 11).

column1: The research clinic prepares the student for writing the thesis proposal. The clinic will provide insights into types of research questions and their requirements. It will provide an overview of research strategies and the appropriateness of these related to various types of research questions. Furthermore, various forms of data collection and analysis techniques – related to the research strategy – are discussed. As students follow a ‘master in management’ students will learn how to discuss and think about the managerial relevance of their research question.

To properly discuss and learn about types of data collection and data analysis the research clinic is organized in various tracks running in parallel for different groups of students depending on their choice of a thesis topic and the exact research question. Students will participate in one of the following tracks:

column2: • Track for students who want to write their thesis in Finance
• Track for students who want to conduct a quantitative analysis
• Track for students who want to conduct a qualitative analysis

column1: These tracks provide hands-on exercises to help students to collect their data adequately and conduct their analysis in the thesis autonomously. The thesis proposal is conditional for the thesis.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course is designed to strongly support the individual thesis projects. It focuses both on the various thesis research methodologies and more practical skills to carry out the thesis project. The most important methodologies for thesis research on innovation management are qualitative case studies, surveys and archival data analyses, and experiments. The more practical issues address formal administrative procedures, managing the project with coach and co-reader, how to do a literature scan and literature review, etcetera.

The final part of this course is a one-day workshop in which an assignment is done on the research methodology meanwhile selected by the students for their thesis project. This means that students are divided into sub-groups on a specific methodology (see also thesis project).

In addition to the regular thesis objectives, this course aims at providing research skills general to all students and thesis topics in this Master Programme.

column1: The Research Methods in Finance course gives students the opportunity to acquire the

skills needed to work with data, conduct an empirical analysis, and write an academic paper. These skills are essential for the successful completion of the Master Thesis. Students will attend lectures and workshop sessions, work on empirical assignments, and present the results of these assignments. Students can choose between two tracks: Corporate Finance or Asset Pricing.

Each track consists of assignments on key topics in that field. However, the skills students train in both tracks are the same (e.g., processing data, implementing empirical methods using statistical software, and interpreting results).

Students must have a basic background in finance at the level of the core course Investments. Students are also expected to have a basic understanding of regression analysis. Students who lack this knowledge are strongly recommended to catch up prior to the start of the course by reading chapters 1 up to 5 of Brooks (2014).</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87005,2019,Researching Cultural Tourism,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['N van Es, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students will first be introduced in the field of cultural tourism, as an increasingly important subfield or niche of tourism in general. Cultural tourism has a long history, with roots reaching back to the Grand Tour in the 18th Century. Since then cultural tourism has been booming. Due in part to globalisation and postmodernism the character of concepts such as 'culture' and 'local identity' has become more fluid, with changing meanings to different groups in society. The ways in which tourism, visual culture and local identity are intertwining is the central theme and starting point of this research seminar. Next to that, several important qualitative research methodologies will be touched upon, familiarizing students with doing qualitative research towards cultural tourism by means of content analysis, participant observation, in-depth interviewing and ‘netnography’, amongst others. After this, students will be sent out into the field, explore how issues related to cultural tourism are acquiring significance in practice and engage hands-on in applying their methodological as well as theoretical knowledge in this field to engage with a small-scale empirical research project in line with their own interests.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students will be made familiar with a wide range of qualitative research methods, which will prepare them for conducting an independent research towards the way(s) in which place, culture and tourism intertwine and intersect in empirical reality. In order to do so, students will practice critical analysis of sociological empirical research in the field of cultural tourism in order to learn the way research is done in practice and reported in publications. Following this, students will apply their knowledge in a small-scale qualitative research, developing a research design and acquiring hands-on experience of collecting and analysing data in addition to presenting findings amidst peers.

column1: This course further elaborates the theoretical issues related to historical scholarship discussed in Rethinking History 1. It does so by studying key issues and currents in the philosophy of the  humanities in general and in the philosophy of history (the philosophical reflection on the nature and study of history) in particular.

In our treatment of the philosophy of history, we will study both the 'speculative' philosophy of history and the 'critical' philosophy of history. While speculative philosophers such as Hegel and Spengler pondered over the grand schemes of history, 'critical' schools of thought, such as positivism, hermeneutics and post-modernism raised various questions about the extent to which we can know, study or represent the past. What is the meaning of history and what is the nature of historical truth? How can we justify historical explanations? To what extent can we understand the intentions of historical actors? Is historical objectivity desirable or even possible? How do historical narratives represent the past and what are the limits of historical representation?
This course will strongly challenge the purported truths of historical scholarship.</body>

column1: This course reflects on world history from the perspective of various revolutionary moments that have shaped, or are perceived in hindsight to have shaped, the historical trajectories of human civilisations and societies, and have influenced how we live our daily lives today. Reading materials will delve into the concept of ‘revolution’ and look into key moments throughout world history and across geographical regions through the lenses of various technological, scientific, political and/or social revolutions. Topics include, but are not limited to, the shift from oral- to literate cultures, the rise of agricultural societies, the emergence of cities, the circulation of money, the professionalisation of armies, technologies of planetary exploration, and the scientific revolution. Reading materials are selected from multiple disciplines, including global history, anthropology, and philosophy.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: •           A critical understanding of the various theories of the historical Jesus and Muhammad and their methodological foundations
•           A capacity to analyse the strengths and weaknesses of such theories, based on both the evidence and the methodological issues.
•           Identify, interpret, and evaluate a range of images and source materials
•           Developed knowledge of the classical themes in Christian-Muslim polemics and their influence on current interreligious debates
•           Developed knowledge of select examples of the cultural reception and reworking of the traditions of Jesus and Muhammad
•           Profound insight in the relation between religion and media and the way the transcendent has been portrayed in the visual arts
•           Insight into the debate on aniconism in both religious traditions
•           A critical understanding of the use of religious imagery in film and other modern media

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87464,2019,Rhetoric for managers,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. JPJM Essers'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In ancient times leadership education consisted mainly in training pupils in the trivium, the three liberal arts (out of seven) dedicated to grammar, logic and rhetoric. Thus leaders, whether in politics or business, were primarily trained to become excellent communicators. Communication skills, and rhetoric specifically, were not seen or treated as a ‘bag of tricks’. They were considered essential ingredients in the character formation of the leader and the exercise of good reason. For to be a good and virtuous leader, one first of all had to become a good and virtuous person.

Today communication skills of leaders still are of crucial importance to their performance. The ability to motivate people, to maintain the reputation and public image of a company, to portray a credible organizational identity and strategic direction, to lead change or to navigate organizations through periods of crisis critically hinge on the persuasive talents of managers. Knowing your audience, framing your message creatively, and choosing the appropriate channels are decisive for effective communication. The language of management provides a plethora of examples of how issues are rhetorically framed to fit specific courses of action. Nowadays, however, as is evident in the use of social media and advertising, it is not only through words but also through the use of visual imagery that persuasive performance is determined.

This course will explore several terrains of rhetorical competence, from the classical canons of rhetoric and the use of tropes through to the latest developments in visual rhetoric. The course will take both an analytical perspective, helping students to recognize rhetorical techniques of persuasion, and provide a training ground to develop skills in compiling convincing communicative strategies and expressions.
This elective is built up around weekly lectures and accompanying workshops in which we will explore various aspects of rhetoric.

column2: <li>
Language, logic and rhetoric
<li>
The classical canons of rhetoric
<li>
Rhetoric and ideology in/of science
<li>
Errors of thought and rhetorical fallacies
<li>
The effective use of tropes and figures of speech
<li>
Presupposition and conversational implicature
<li>
Visual and multimodal rhetoric

column1: Workshops will focus on several prominent ‘fields’ of rhetorical expression and competence in everyday management discourse. Which rhetorical techniques does the contemporary language of management employ to conceptualize aspects of organizational life such as: organizational identity and power, issues and risk management, change and crisis? Illustrative examples of these aspects will be elaborated to learn how to recognize the force of rhetorical moves in organizational communication. In a group assignment students will train their leadership skills by designing a rhetorically justified strategy on a relevant issue of organizational communication.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
Offer students relevant insights into the structure and scope of rhetoric in managerial discourse and organizational life
<li>
Enable students to recognize and analyse aspects of rhetoric in examples of organizational communication
<li>
Explore contemporary forms of visual and multimodal rhetoric next to textual expressions of rhetoric in management practice
<li>
Provide a training ground for students to practice their leadership skills through persuasive and effective communication

column1: After the course students are able to:

column2: <li>
Recognize relevant elements of rhetoric in concrete examples of organizational communication
<li>
Critically evaluate practical everyday expressions of managerial discourse through their use or abuse of rhetorical techniques
<li>
Apply their acquired rhetorical skills to a relevant situation of organizational communication

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Globalization and urbanization are interconnected processes. The maritime expansion of the sixteenth century enforced the growth of a new global urban system. Early-modern European expansion undermined the Asian centered world economy and laid the foundations of a global system controlled by European urban elites and western state structures. This global order was turned upside-down in the second half of the twentieth century due to the rise of the Asian Tigers, and BRICS countries a few decades later.

This course discusses the results of these recent global transformations on urban life. The rise of global cities since the 1970s was – for instance – accompanied by a major increase in the urban population. More than half of world population is living cities after 2000, but the majority of these people does no longer live in the rich centers, but in the slums of the urban periphery. The classical Weberian picture of the city as a place of freedom and development has been turned upside-down by these developments. Cities are still centers of economic growth, but they face problems such as growing inequality, poverty, violence and pollution. Students learn how a combination of socio-scientific and historical methods can help to analyze these challenges.

</style>

column1: This core course deals with the management of financial risk and return. This theme is discussed from the viewpoint of financial institutions, international investors and corporate firms. Various potential sources of risk are studied, including market risk, credit risk, liquidity risk and operational risk, as well as alternative approaches to measure and control risk. The course teaches you how to apply risk management in an organisation, using the concepts of hedging, insurance, risk budgeting, and risk adjusted performance measurement. Particular attention is paid to the application and valuation of derivative instruments, such as futures and options. During the course, we analyse a number of cases where risk management failed in practice.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

</style>

column1: After having followed this course, students should be able to

column2: •     explain why and under which conditions risk management is valuable;
•     understand and calculate standard measures for market risk, such asValue-at-Risk;
•     hedge trading positions using standard derivatives and spotmarkets;
•     understand and use standard measures of creditrisk;
•     understand the concept of operationalrisk;
•     understand the concept of liquidity risk and be able to correct market-risk VaR for liquidity risk;
•     understand the use and issues of risk management and economic capital in particular in the process of maximizing the value of a financialinstitution;
•     link recent crises to the material introduced in the course and analyze the potential benefits and problems of newregulations.
