column1: Financiële ondernemingen opereren in een sterk juridische omgeving. De diensten die zij verlenen en de producten die zij aanbieden zijn onderworpen aan een complex toezicht- en handhavingsregime.  Financiële ondernemingen lopen het risico bestuurs(straf)rechtelijke sancties opgelegd te krijgen door de toezichthouder, waarbij kan worden gedacht aan de zaak Delta Lloyd vs DNB. Zij kunnen ook worden vervolgd op civielrechtelijke gronden door gedupeerden, waarbij kan worden gedacht aan het Safe Haven-arrest en de renteswapzaken. Daarnaast is het mogelijk dat een financiële onderneming en haar leidinggevenden worden vervolgd op strafrechtelijke gronden. Deze juridische risico’s kunnen onder meer tot reputatieschade leiden en worden daarom door financiële ondernemingen ingeschat en gekwalificeerd.

In dit vak komen de verschillende soorten procedures waarin een financiële onderneming kan worden betrokken aan de orde. Hierbij wordt onder meer aandacht besteed aan de afwegingen die een onderneming maakt tussen procederen en het aangaan van een schikking en de verschillende risico’s die daaraan zijn verbonden.

Vanwege deze brede benadering is ervoor gekozen niet het Nederlandse woord ‘procederen’ te gebruiken, maar het Engelse woord ‘litigation’. In lijn met deze keuze is aan het vak de Engelstalige titel Risk, reputation & litigation gegeven. De meeste literatuur en alle colleges zijn in het Nederlands.

Aan het eind van dit vak wordt de studenten gevraagd in groepsverband een toegewezen korte juridische casus op het gebied van het financieel recht te beoordelen en juridische argumenten en tegenargumenten te presenteren ten overstaan van rechters die een eindoordeel vellen.
Dit vak is uitermate geschikt voor juristen, economen en bedrijfskundigen die geïnteresseerd zijn in de juridische litigation-risico’s die financiële ondernemingen lopen.

Dit vak is relatief nieuw in het curriculum en uitgebreid geëvalueerd met studenten. Het vernieuwde vak hanteert een explicieter uitgangspunt, namelijk de juridische risico’s en reputatierisico's die (met name) financiële ondernemingen lopen en de beheersing van die risico's. De naam benadrukt tevens de meer interdisciplinaire aanpak van dit vak waarbij het vak ook van toegevoegde waarde zal zijn voor studenten die niet de advocatuur of een juridische functie ambiëren, maar een andere functie in het (financiële) bedrijfsleven of bij de overheid (inclusief de toezichthouders). Naar aanleiding van positieve feedback van studenten zal de tussentijdse opdracht behouden blijven. Ook zullen gastsprekers uit de praktijk blijvend worden ingezet.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Inzicht in de rol en functie van bestuursrechtelijke en strafrechtelijke instrumenten in de context van het financiële toezichtrecht en de toepassing van bestuursrechtelijke dan wel strafrechtelijke handhavingsmogelijkheden.
• Kennis en begrip van risicomanagement in de financiële sector, waaronder normen met betrekking tot een beheerste en integere bedrijfsvoering.

• Inzicht in en begrip van privaatrechtelijke en publiekrechtelijke handhaving van gedragsnormen uit hoofde van financieel(toezicht)recht en de mogelijkheden om financiële ondernemingen en/of hun bestuurders aansprakelijk te stellen.
• Toepassing van zorgplichtnormen uit hoofde van de Wft respectievelijk het BW.
• Kennis van en inzicht in de handhavingsmogelijkheden van toezichthouders DNB en AFM.

• Begrip van strategische overwegingen aangaande de mogelijke reputatierisico’s in verband met juridische geschillen en het belang van goede verhoudingen met toezichthouders en regelgevers op nationaal en internationaal niveau.

• Aanleren van vaardigheden om juridische voor- en tegenargumenten te formuleren en te analyseren, (daarmee verband houdende) relevante juridische problemen in kaart te brengen en op te lossen respectievelijk daarover een juridisch relevant standpunt in te nemen.

column1: In Europe, from the late Middle Ages onwards the concept of ‘race’ was used in order to distinguish different kinds of people. As a rule the distinctions drawn between human races were accompanied by clear cut moral hierarchies. Most early modern Europeans appear to have considered racial differences the result of a variety of external circumstances, but during the Enlightenment as a result of taxonomical attempts to classify man within the wider context of nature a modern, allegedly scientific racism arose, according to which these distinctions had a biological basis.

In this course we will concentrate on the way in which European authors active prior to Darwin, who denied the reality of different human ‘species’, and to such 19th- and 20th-century racists as De Gobineau, Chamberlain, and Rosenberg, tried to meet the challenge implied by the discovery of peoples and cultures that looked fundamentally different from the ones early modern Europeans had been accustomed to, born as they were into a world which only recently had started to globalize. Some of the texts involved take the superiority of the inhabitants of Europe for granted. Other early modern authors, however, reveal an evident fascination sometimes coupled with genuine admiration for indigenous ‘natives’. One of the crucial issues to be addressed in this course concerns the novelty of early modern racism.

We will start with a number of introductory lectures on proto-racist attitudes in Classical Antiquity, (early) Christianity, and the Middle Ages, focusing on the Greco-Roman notion of ‘barbarians’ and biblical accounts of human diversity. Next, the outlines will be drawn of some of the major early modern strands of thought on race. Finally, we will read a number of texts, from Montaigne to Kant, which students will be expected to present and discuss in class.

column1: In deze cursus maken studenten kennis met geschiedenis van voormalige Nederlandse koloniën en  de impact daarvan op de postkoloniale samenleving, met name de Rotterdamse. Speciale aandacht zal er zijn voor de geschiedenis van Suriname, de Nederlandse Cariben en Indonesië. Dit betreft met name omstreden of vergeten stukken uit hun geschiedenis, diametraal verschillende perspectieven,   de migratie van die geschiedenis en haar dragers naar Nederland en hedendaagse erfenissen van die geschiedenissen. Hoe wordt het koloniaal verleden beleefd door inwoners van Rotterdam? Wat  waren de koloniale modellen van etnisch-culturele diversiteit daar & toen en hoe verhoudt zich dat  tot postkoloniale modellen van diversiteit in het hier & nu.

Daarnaast is deze cursus een –voor sommigen verdere– kennismaking met het fenomeen mondelinge geschiedenis. Dit is meer dan alleen maar een methode, het gaat ook over herinnering en over een ander soort geschiedenis. Hierin staat het individuele perspectief centraal van (de nazaten van) gekoloniseerde mensen, eventueel ook kolonisators. Het gaat meer om het verhaal, de hedendaagse beleving daarvan en de ontmoeting tussen onderzoeker en nazaat, dan om zoiets weerbarstigs als historische waarheid.

En ten slotte gaat deze cursus ook over Rotterdam en de relatie die deze stad onderhoudt met het koloniaal verleden. Studenten gaan daarvoor zelf postkoloniale Rotterdammers interviewen en daarmee nieuwe bronnen creëren. De centrale vraag van deze interviews is wat Rotterdammers met een  achtergrond in het koloniale Suriname, de Nederlandse Cariben of Indonesië hebben meegenomen van dat koloniaal verleden in hun huidige leven in Rotterdam. Hoe hebben ze hun migratie ervaren; hoe ervaren ze hun Nederlanderschap nu? Nog meer toegespitst: Hoe heeft dat koloniaal verleden hen al of niet geholpen een plek te vinden in de Rotterdamse samenleving en hoe gaat die samenleving –in hun beleving- met die plek c.q. met henzelf om?

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Studenten zijn bekend met de (post-)koloniale geschiedenis van Nederland en kunnen het verschijnsel kolonialisme en de hedendaagse impact daarvan duiden en verklaren
• Studenten kunnen de methoden van oral history toepassen en hier schriftelijk en audio-visueel verslag van doen
• Studenten kunnen een weloverwogen standpunt innemen in contemporaine debatten over culturele diversiteit en omstreden geschiedenis

column1: De cursus Russisch voor beginners 1+2 is een dubbele cursus: aan het eind van het traject is de stof van twee cursusniveaus behandeld. De cursus bestaat dan ook uit 20 lessen van 2,5 uur. Voordeel is dat je tussendoor geen examen hoeft te doen. Je stroomt dus automatisch door van niveau beginners 1 naar niveau beginners 2.
Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Russisch?

Tijdens deze cursus leer je de beginselen van de Russische taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op de vaardigheden lezen, luisteren, spreken en schrijven in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

column2: • kennis maken en jezelf voorstellen;
• familie;
• stad;
• de weg vragen en wijzen;
• vliegveld, hotel, restaurant;
• een afspraak maken of een mening geven.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Aan het einde van de cursus ben je in staat het Cyrillische alfabet te lezen en te schrijven en een eenvoudig gesprek te voeren en te begrijpen. Je beschikt over een woordenschat van 700+ woorden zodat je in veelvoorkomende en alledaagse situaties kunt communiceren. Het eindniveau van de cursus is beginners 2, vergelijkbaar met het A1.2 niveau van het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR).

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Het Language & Training Centre organiseert eenmaal per jaar cursussen Russisch in de periode februari-juni.
• Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
• De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Russisch gesproken.
• Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 45,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
• Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
• De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 10 en maximaal 16 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 10 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.

• Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.
• De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
• Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 5,5 of hoger.
• Lees ook onze voorwaarden.

SCM students have the opportunity to combine the writing of their thesis with an internship with a company (minimum of 168 hours) and replacing an elective course. The internship should be solely related to the thesis research and the selection of the internship should be in consultation with the thesis coach or thesis coordinator. The Company Based Research Project will be assessed separately from the thesis (on a pass/fail basis) by the thesis coach and a company supervisor.
THIS ELECTIVE COUNTS AS A FREE ELECTIVE FOR SCM STUDENTS ONLY. IN OTHER WORDS: in order to graduate you MUST complete at least two other SCM programme electives!

column1: The students will already be familiar with various Supply Chain Management disciplines through course work; however, the use of this knowledge and the capacity to translate it into practical solutions for a real life and actual problem is a new challenge. The Business Consultancy Project (BCP) permits students to combine theory and practice. The learning objectives of the BCP can be summarised as follows:
1.    Define the research problem of the company, which exactly includes the question that the company would like to see addressed.

2.    Discuss the current state of research in the relevant Supply Chain Management topic for your project, both method-wise and content-wise, in a literature review, that is included in your final report;

3.    Present the current state of research in the relevant Supply Chain Management topic for your project, both method-wise and content-wise, in a seminar for your peers, which results in new insights for your analysis.
4.    Complete a consultancy project in which you:
•    Deliver the final report before the deadline that satisfies the client.

<body>The organisation of this large event is in the hands of a small committee, consisting of seven senior members of STAR. The positions within the committee are presented below:

column2: • Chairman: end-responsibility for the total event; guiding and leading the committee; being in contact with the RSM
• Treasurer: managing the budget and bookkeeping of the entire event
• Commissioner of Marketing & Public Relations: creating and realising the marketing for the entire event
• Commissioner of Speakers (2x): responsible for recruiting all speakers and managing relations with these speakers
• Commissioner of Commercial Relations (2x): responsible for the acquisition of the event and maintaining relations with corporate partners
• Events: responsible for the planning and organization of the event itself

column1: Next to these positions, the modules Vice-Chairman and IT are available next to the common positions within the committee.
From all committee members it is expected that they:

column2: • are able an willing to bear total responsibility for the project
• will be able to maintain professional relations with all stakeholders (corporates, speakers, suppliers, STAR, RSM, students)
• will be able to successfully plan and schedule the project

column1: Essentially, functioning as a member of the committee involves ‘learning by doing’. At the same time, becoming a member is only possible when you fulfil the requirements set by STAR. Within the project, your starting qualifications will be brought to a higher level. The learning goals for the activity are such that committee members should already posses certain knowledge and skills which will be enhanced by the end of the project. The following starting qualifications and learning goals have been formulated. In brackets, courses that are part of the BSc BA or the BSc IBA have been indicated that clearly contribute to the required knowledge, skills or attitude.
Being considered for this committee, you should:

column2: • be able to work in a team (Introduction to Business/Inleiding Bedrijfskunde, Organisational Behaviour/Gedrag in Organisaties, Methodology, Effective Business Communication/Bedrijfskundige Vaardigheden, Strategic Business Plan/Strategisch Ondernemingsplan; Organisational Theory & Dymanics)
• have basic knowledge of how to communicate with different (international) stakeholders (Effective Business Communication; Strategic Management; Cross Cultural Management)

• have basic knowledge of bookkeeping and budgeting (Foundations of Finance & Accounting/Financiële Processen; Management Accounting, Corporate Finance. Having completed Financial Accounting is an asset)
• be able to rationally argue (financial) decisions to the supervisor/board (Organisational Theory & Dynamics)
• have a basic understanding of how to communicate and work together with businesses (Effective Business Communication/BKV)
• have a basic understanding of how to come up with a marketing plan in order to sufficiently promote the project (Marketing Management; (International) Marketing Research)

column1: After finishing the project, you should be able to:

column2: • work strongly and professionally in a team
• make far-reaching decisions based on valid argumentation
• effectively deal with stress
• professionally conduct the bookkeeping and budgeting of encompassing projects
• professionally communicate and work together with businesses
• professionally develop, apply and evaluate the marketing of large projects
• show strong endurance and perseverance
• act responsibly when dealing with large projects

<body>The STAR Management Week is the largest off-campus business and recruitment event of the Benelux and one of the highlights of the year at the Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University (RSM). During this event the students will get the opportunity to enrich their student life by participating in various activities. They will be inspired by keynote speakers during the Academic Seminars, or by participating in discussions with well-known guests during the Honorary Discussions. The SMW also gives students the opportunity to get in contact with many companies during multiple recruitment activities. Whether students have just started their studies or are already close to graduation, during the STAR Management Week they will be offered a broad range of professional and exciting activities to participate in. The organisation of SMW is a challenging task for which only senior members of STAR are recruited who meet a range requirements, both in the field of content and in the field of skills and attitude.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Why do all professionals engage in ""selling""?
• What actually entails ""selling"" in a knowledge intensive economy?
• What does it mean to be a ""persuasive professional""?
• How can you read the intentions of other people?
• How can you become a better team player in a company?
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Knowledge about the roles, functions and tasks of sales and account managers who are operating in different knowledge intensive industries as banking sector, fast moving consumer goods firms or marketing research firms etc..
• Knowledge that sales and account managers operate as knowledge brokers which requires that they both possess a high IQ and social quotient (SQ).
• Knowledge about how people can improve their SQ using different insights from social neuroscience, psychology and behavioral economics.

• The student foremost will be able to use the vocabulary used in the area of selling which focuses on how salespeople develop relationships with people who operate by the customer (“not companies do buy but people do”).
• The student concrete learns to apply concepts as buying centers, persuasion techniques, theory of mind, empathy, motivation/perseverance to selling situations.

• The student engages in a competitive game during which he discovers both his leadership and team player abilities as well particular personality traits -- especially attachment styles and endocrine responses.
• The student learns to create and present persuasive messages for customers based on insights from behavioral economics and psychology.

column1: <body>Adequate inrichting van de sanctionering van onwenselijk, strafbaar gedrag is al enige tijd één van de hoofdthema’s van politieke en maatschappelijke aandacht en daarom ook een kernonderdeel van het curriculum van de strafrechtelijke mastervariant. Het mastervak Sanctierecht zich op de inrichting van het strafrechtelijk sanctiestelsel in brede zin. Dit wil zeggen: het geheel van regels over, de beginselen achter en de actualiteit bij zowel de oplegging als de tenuitvoerlegging van strafrechtelijke sancties. In het kader van de tenuitvoerlegging wordt uitdrukkelijk ingegaan op vrijheidsbenemende straffen en maatregel. Er wordt niet alleen aandacht besteed aan wet- en regelgeving, maar ook aan rechtspraak en uitvoeringspraktijk. Om nader inzicht te verkrijgen in die uitvoeringspraktijk worden in het kader van dit vak praktijkexcursies georganiseerd. Ten slotte wordt in dit vak ook het Europees- en internationaalrechtelijk perspectief betrokken.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• het geldende sanctierecht en de bijbehorende grondslagen en systematiek van de oplegging en tenuitvoerlegging van strafrechtelijke sancties beschrijven, doorgronden, analyseren, uitleggen en beoordelen;
• inzien hoe de wet- en regelgeving in het kader van het sanctierecht nader vorm krijgt in rechtspraak, beleid en uitvoeringspraktijk;
• het geldende sanctierecht bezien en doorgronden in relatie tot de (uitgangspunten van) sanctionering op Europees- en internationaalrechtelijk niveau;
• actuele juridische vraagstukken aangaande het sanctierecht doorgronden, analyseren en beoordelen in hun nationale, Europese en internationale context;
• zelfstandig een kritische visie vormen op de maatschappelijke rol van het sanctierecht

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87936,2019,"Schenk-, erf-, overdrachtsbelasting en Estate Planning",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,"['JE Kreukniet, LLM', 'JHP Anastacio Teixeira - Stigter', 'mr.dr. E Boomsluiter', 'W Verstijnen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het erfrecht en het huwelijksvermogensrecht worden op hoofdlijnen behandeld. De student maakt voorts kennis met de Wet op belastingen van rechtsverkeer 1970 en de Successiewet 1956. Van de Wet op belastingen van rechtsverkeer 1970 wordt alleen de overdrachtsbelasting behandeld. Bij bespreking van de overdrachtsbelasting wordt ook ingegaan op de samenloopproblematiek met de omzetbelasting en wordt tevens stil gestaan bij de cumulatie met de schenkbelasting. Bij de behandeling van de Successiewet 1956  wordt vooral ingegaan op de begrippen: 'al wat krachtens erfrecht of schenking wordt verkregen' en 'fictieve verkrijging’. Er wordt uitgebreid aandacht besteed aan de bedrijfsopvolgingsfaciliteiten. Estate Planning wordt vanuit diverse invalshoeken bezien, zowel nationaal als internationaal.

<body>Tijdens dit blok ga je aan de slag met het schrijven van een wetenschappelijk literatuuronderzoek. Het leren schrijven van een literatuuronderzoek is zeer nuttig, bijvoorbeeld in het kader van leeronderzoeken en scripties, daar het vertrekpunt van al het sociologische onderzoek gevormd wordt door de grondige bestudering van eerder onderzoek. Tijdens de eerste bijeenkomst wordt uitgelegd waar een goed geschreven literatuuronderzoek aan moet voldoen. De daarop volgende bijeenkomsten staan in het teken van het opzetten, schrijven en verbeteren van het literatuuronderzoek; te beginnen met het opstellen van een goede probleemstelling en eindigend met het doen van aanbevelingen voor vervolgonderzoek.</body>

<body>Tijdens dit blok ga je aan de slag met het schrijven van een onderzoeksvoorstel. Het leren schrijven van zo’n voorstel is zeer nuttig, bijvoorbeeld in het kader van de leeronderzoeken en scripties, maar ook wanneer je na je studie wetenschapper wilt worden. Dit blok staat in het teken van het indienen van een (fictief) onderzoeksvoorstel bij het NWO, één van de instellingen die in Nederland wetenschappelijk onderzoek aan universiteiten financiert. Gedurende dit practicum wordt voortgebouwd op de kennis die is opgedaan tijdens het schrijven van een literatuuronderzoek. Tijdens de eerste bijeenkomst wordt uitgelegd waar een goed voorstel aan moet voldoen. De daaropvolgende werkgroepen staan in het teken van het opzetten, schrijven en verbeteren van het voorstel; te beginnen met het opstellen van een goede probleemstelling en eindigend met het maken van een planning voor je onderzoek.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87141,2019,Science Fiction and Media,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. EF Augé'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, students will be introduced to science fiction as a major genre in cinema and  literature, but also in video games, music and other media. Science fiction has the ability to invent and prevent the future, but also to provide extremely precise analyses of societies. By studying its different past representations, we will try study how science fiction contributes to the understanding of our present, but also the shaping of our future.

Science fiction and media (A History of the Future) is the first course organized by CHIFT (Community for histories of the future), the platform based at Erasmus University aiming at studying and stimulating the production of science fiction in the Netherlands.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 60. This course has mandatory lectures.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Introduction to film studies
• Introduction to science fiction as a media genre
• Use of science fiction to develop academic skills
• Use of science fiction to broaden media studies

column3: <div>

column4: De kinder- en jeugd GGZ maar ook het werkveld van de schoolpsycholoog heeft grote behoefte aan goed gekwalificeerde ‘scientist practioners’, dat wil zeggen psychologen die in hun dagelijks klinisch handelen oog hebben (en houden) voor recente wetenschappelijke inzichten en ontwikkelingen en van daaruit gebruik maken van ‘evidence-based’ diagnostiek en behandeling.

column3: <div>
<div>

column4: In dit derde blok in de Master Kinder- en Jeugdpsychologie zullen de studenten leren zich op te stellen als echte scientist practitioners. Ze zullen geconfronteerd worden met klinische en leerproblemen, waarvoor ze een wetenschappelijk gefundeerde oplossing moeten bedenken. Voorbeelden zijn: het selecteren van goed gevalideerde diagnostische instrumenten voor specifieke problematiek, het zoeken van de optimale (evidence-based) behandeling voor een kind met een bepaalde stoornis, het bekijken van evidence-based preventieprogramma’s, het onderbouwd kunnen adviseren van collega-psychologen. Tevens wordt er aandacht besteed aan de professionele attitude.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: <body>The course consists of three sessions, built around three key elements:

column2: <li>Providing information:
<ul>

column3: • “ERIM Values”; what attitudes and behaviours do we expect from ERIM PhD students and members,
• Codes of Conduct, such as the Erasmus University Code of Conduct, and the code of the Association of Universities in the Netherlands (VSNU)

column2: <li>Experiencing dilemmas:
<ul>

column3: • As part of a pre-programmed game/simulation, you experience important issues and dilemmas involved in questionable research practices. You will play the role of a PhD student who just started and runs into a number of problems and challenges, including a supervisor who is being accused of fraud. It’s your role to find out what really happened.

• In an interactive setting, you will be discussing concrete integrity dilemma’s with your fellow students, in order to understand, develop and discuss arguments for choosing a course of action when facing integrity dilemma’s.

column2: <li>Assignment – enhancing a culture of scientific integrity;
<ul>

column3: • You will have a choice of an individual or team assignment to conduct a brief exploration and write an essay on selected topics within the general theme of “enhancing a culture of scientific integrity”.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Like in any profession, scientists are routinely faced with integrity dilemmas: Can I exclude particular observations from my research? Can I leave out certain statistics from the analysis I report? Can I use the same data set, or “idea”, in multiple papers? Can I agree on a colleague being a co-author on a paper to which (s)he has not made a significant contribution?

This course aims to expose you to such integrity dilemmas, and to support you in developing and honing your own “moral compass”. We do this partly by discussing the context of the principles, values and rules such as they apply to the field of management research in general, and to our university and research institute in particular.

As such, the course serves as a foundation for other courses, in particular the various research methodology courses and the course on Publishing Strategy, during which you will discuss in more detailed terms the various dilemma’s you will be facing in your PhD studies and possible further academic career.</body>

Het schrijven van een scriptie van 12 000-16 000 woorden (10 ects) is een verplicht onderdeel van de masteropleiding Fiscaal recht. Voor de studenten van de variant Directe belastingen geldt dat het onderwerp van hun scriptie betrekking moet hebben op directe belastingen; voor de studenten van de variant Indirecte belastingen zijn dat de Indirecte belastingen.

Het schrijven van de masterscriptie Fiscaal recht is alleen mogelijk met deelname aan het door ons aangeboden scriptietraject. Indien u de wens heeft om in het collegejaar 2018 – 2019 af te studeren, dan dient in ieder geval uw scriptie vóór 26 juni 2018 goedgekeurd te zijn door uw scriptiebegeleider. Indien de scriptie vervolgens wordt goedgekeurd door de tweede lezer, kan de scriptie worden verdedigd tijdens de afstudeerbijeenkomst van eind augustus 2019.

column2: • Aanwezigheid tijdens de scriptievoorlichtingsbijeenkomst inweek 38;
• Themaregistratie in week 40;
• Goedkeuring scriptieonderwerp en aanmelding in het scriptievolgsysteem vóór 25 januari 2019;
• a. Studenten variant Directe belastingen: eerste afspraak met scriptiebegeleider vóór 8 maart 2019.

column1: b. Studenten variant Indirecte belastingen: deelname inleidende discussiebijeenkomst 6/7 februari 2019.

column2: • Deelname aan Fiscaal Confrontatievak (Start in week 12)

column1: Let op: U kunt alleen aan het Fiscaal Confrontatievak deelnemen als u aan de verplichte onderdelen 1 t/m 4 hebt voldaan. Dit zal voorafgaande aan het Fiscaal Confrontatievak actief worden gecontroleerd.

Het is aan te raden op tijd met de scriptie te beginnen. Uit ervaring is bekend dat vooral de eerste fase van de ontwikkeling van een scriptie (bestaande uit de keuze van het onderwerp, de literatuurverzameling en het inlezen) veel tijd kost. Met nadruk zij hier vermeld dat een eventueel in het bachelorwerkstuk behandeld onderwerp niet mag worden 'uitgewerkt' tot een masterscriptie. Het onderwerp van de scriptie dient tijdig aangemeld te worden door middel van het invullen van het 'Aanmeldingsformulier scriptie (Master) Fiscaal Recht'. Na goedkeuring van het onderwerp door de sectie Fiscaal Recht ontvangt u bericht met daarin de naam van de toegewezen scriptiebegeleider. Na goedkeuring ligt het onderwerp vast.

Met nadruk zij hier vermeld dat niet eerder aan een scriptie kan worden begonnen dan nadat het aanmeldingsformulier is ingeleverd en u bericht heeft ontvangen over het toewijzen van een scriptiebegeleider.

Uw scriptie moet binnen twee collegejaren na aanvang van het masterscriptietraject door uw scriptiebegeleider zijn goedgekeurd. Daarna vervalt uw scriptieonderwerp. U dient dan opnieuw het gehele scriptietraject te doorlopen. Dat geldt niet voor het Fiscaal confrontatievak, indien u dat vak al met een voldoende heeft afgesloten. Indien u in het collegejaar 2018/2019 start met uw scriptie dient uw scriptie dus uiterlijk aan het eind van collegejaar 2019/2020 goedgekeurd te zijn door uw scriptiebegeleider.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
1.         De student kan zelfstandig een fiscaal juridische probleemstelling formuleren;
2.         De student kan zelfstandig een onderwerp op het gebied van het belastingrecht, de systematiek en de methodologische aspecten ervan, beschrijven, analyseren en beoordelen;
3.         De student kan de voor het onderzoek relevante bronnen verzamelen, ordenen, analyseren, beschrijven en verantwoorden;
4.         De student kan een fiscaal juridisch vraagstuk plaatsen in een bredere context, waarbij in elk geval een van de volgende aspecten wordt betrokken:

column2: • Een (een multi- of interdisciplinair) vraagstuk of case uit de beroepspraktijk
• Een of meerdere juridische deeldisciplines
• Europees en/of internationaal recht
• De maatschappelijke rol van het recht
• Andere wetenschappelijke disciplines
• Ethische perspectieven

column1: 5.         De student kan op basis van aantoonbare kennis van en inzicht in de wetenschappelijke discipline op een gevorderd niveau een originele bijdrage leveren aan de wetenschappelijke kennis;
6.         De student kan zelfstandig op zijn leerproces reflecteren, nieuwe nationale en internationale ontwikkelingen in het fiscale recht signaleren en zich eigen maken; en

7.         De student kan zelfstandig zijn wetenschappelijk fiscaal juridisch onderzoek, onderzoeksuitkomsten en –voorstellen, zowel schriftelijk als mondeling, presenteren aan een juridische en aan een niet-juridisch onderlegd publiek, en deze bovendien ook beargumenteerd verdedigen.

column1: <body>In een aantal bijeenkomsten van november tot Kerst wordt een technische instructie gegeven voor het schrijven van een bachelor thesis en wordt collectief gewerkt aan eenieders concept voor de thesis. Dat concept dient uiterlijk 1 januari, goedgekeurd door de begeleider, aan de Examencommissie te worden voorgelegd. In minimaal vier bijeenkomsten tussen januari en juni, die in overleg worden geroosterd, worden in kleine groepjes tekstgedeelten van de verschillende theses in wording besproken. Deze bijeenkomsten zijn bedoeld ter ondersteuning van het schrijfproces. Voltijd studenten die in 2019-2020 hun bachelor examen willen afleggen dienen deel te nemen aan de bijeenkomsten. Zonder deelname kan geen bachelor examen worden afgelegd.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This is an advanced course in international relations with a specialization in the study of international security. The aim of the course is to equip students with concepts and tools to analyse and understand contemporary security challenges. During the course, the students will discuss major issues in the study of international security, including interstate wars, civil wars, and terrorism. They will also study possible responses to such security issues, both political and military. In seminars, we will aim at applying the theoretical knowledge to a practical policy issues at hand. On one hand, we will look at how global security challenges are tackled locally in a city like Rotterdam; on the other hand, we will discuss the application of theoretical concepts to current situations. By the end of the course, the students will have both knowledge of the state-of-the-art theories, and will be able to apply these to topics featured in evening news.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Identify different conceptual approaches to security studies
• Illustrate and explain the most relevant themes of the international security
• Compare different challenges faced across various fields of security
• Apply theoretical concepts to practical security policy situations at hand
• Frame their arguments coherently and substantively

column1: The course starts by introducing the Semantic Web, and ontologies as the cornerstone of the next generation Web. After that, the most relevant Semantic Web data representation languages (XML, RDF, and OWL) and data query/transformation languages (XPath, XQuery, and XSLT) are presented. Some applications of the Semantic Web for building Web Information Systems for finance, marketing, logistics, or information retrieval are also given.

The students will work in teams on several assignments related to the application of the Semantic Web for developing Web Information Systems. The students will write a report describing the proposed solutions.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Know what the Semantic Web technologies are.
• Understand what a Semantic Web ontology is.
• Be aware of the usefulness of Semantic Web technologies for developing Web Information Systems.
• Be able to develop a Semantic Web ontology.
• Be able to query a Semantic Web ontology.
• Propose Semantic Web solutions for current problems that Web Information Systems face in finance, marketing, logistics, or information retrieval.

column1: <body>Corporate governance analyzes two conflicts of interest that arise in the financing of the firm.

column2: • The first is the conflict between shareholders and the firm's management. While shareholders usually want to see a high return on their investment, managers might have a different agenda. They could try to use the firm's funds for their own interests, or to build an empire that is big but unprofitable. We will discuss this problem and its two main solutions: monitoring by a big shareholder and incentive contracts that give the managers a share in the value they created for the firm.

• The second conflict of interest emerges between controlling shareholder and minority shareholders. The controlling shareholder might try to ""tunnel"" money from the firm into her own pocket and thereby to expropriate minority shareholders. Depending on the legal environment, there might be many ways to do this. We will discuss the relevance of this problem and its implications for the ownership structure of the firm and for a firm's ability to obtain outside financing.

column1: Against this background, we will discuss corporate governance laws and codes, the role and composition of the board of directors, executive compensation, the design of financial securities, mergers and acquisitions, and shareholder activism.

This seminar provides you with an opportunity to gain a deeper understanding about what good corporate governance is and why it matters. The course covers some theoretical and legal issues, but its main focus is on empirical research and insights. Therefore, we will analyze, discuss and criticize the methodology used in the empirical research. Hence, this course also aims at building a critical view on any empirical results presented to the student. In two group assignments, you will apply your knowledge and your skills to two different types of tasks.

Active participation in and a strong commitment to this course are a prerequisite. You are expected to present pieces of the literature and to prepare for in-class discussions. You will also present your own results, ask questions, mention doubts and express your ideas in the class discussion. Hence, learning group dynamics is a positive (and important) side effect of this course.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students have knowledge of and insight into the theory of conflicts of interest within a firm.
• Students have knowledge of different corporate governance standards currently in use and why they matter.
• Students have knowledge of state-of-the-art techniques to resolve problems of endogeneity in empirical settings of corporate governance.
• Students are able to critically discuss in class other authors’ empirical results.
• Students are able to confront alternative empirical findings and evaluate their respective strengths and weaknesses.
• Students are able to design and execute in groups a small scale empirical study.

column2: <title></title>

column1: This seminar introduces students to the methods and tools used in Empirical Corporate Finance. By reading and discussing seminal papers in Empirical Corporate Finance, students will also get in touch with major results and contributions to the field.

The aim of the course is to provide an understanding of basic econometric methods (panel data and OLS) and performance evaluation techniques (short-run and long-run event studies) used in Empirical Corporate Finance. Furthermore, the course will introduce students to the major financial databases. As such, this course is an excellent preparation for students who intend to write their master thesis in Empirical Corporate Finance.
The course consists of two parts: Paper presentations and discussions, and a group replication project.

The latter will require groups of students to choose from a menu of research projects (by Sjoerd van Bekkum, block 2) or replicate parts of a major article in Empirical Corporate Finance using STATA (by Stefan Obernberger, in block 3).

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students have knowledge of and insight into important research topics in corporate finance that have strong real-world implications, which may help them to identify possible dissertation topics.
• Students have knowledge of the empirical techniques used in the majority of empirical studies in corporate finance (regression analysis, event study methodology, and panel data analysis).
• Students are able to derive and identify potential thesis topics from the corporate finance papers discussed in class.
• Students are able to independently conduct research in the form of a ""mini-thesis"", in order to understand and answer empirical research questions in a statistically sound way.
• Students are able to analyze other students' work on how they understand and answer empirical research questions.

column1: This seminar aims to provide insights in groundbreaking developments in economic and financial academic research that may have its impact on private equity investment decisions. The recent advancements in game theory, option theory and behavioral economics, have each been honored with Nobel Prices in economics, are the theoretical pillars of this seminar.

Together with financial executives we focus on how to use corporate finance theory to improve actual strategic management practice. The course is structured in two modules. A briefly summary of the modules in the course is as follows:

column2: • The first module ""Private Equity Valuation"" considers the interactions between private equity investors and the acquisitions that they finance. In addition to the traditional valuation methods for targets, we consider dynamic valuation models and bidding contests (e.g., real options and game theory).

• The second module ""Private Equity Performance"" starts by considering behavioral pitfalls which may occur in the acquisition process and how private equity firms are able to shield themselves against these common pitfalls. Also, we consider the recent performance, governance implications and risk in private equity transactions.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students have knowledge of and insight into fundamental economic theories in corporate finance (real options, game theory and behavioral theory).
• Students have understanding of application of the theoretical perspectives to practice.
• Students are able to make a thorough valuation of a firm using different valuation methods, drafting an investment proposal (in collaboration with an investment bank).
• Students are able to critically asses different scientific articles and be able to understand the limitations of private equity research.
• Students are able to understand, evaluate and discuss different perspectives towards private equity raised in academic articles.

column1: This seminar covers several topics in the domain of Money, Credit and Banking and will provide a macroeconomic perspective on finance. Therefore the course is relevant for students pursuing a career in, for example, the financial services sector (banking, asset management). The origins of the banking crisis will be discussed as well as the credit risk of bonds (loans) and monetary policy in the euro area. During the seminar students will apply both analytical and empirical skills to analyze financial markets. Tasks include the presentation of scientific papers as well as the quantitative evaluation of economic data through software package EViews. The assignments are empirical in nature and students therefore need basic econometric skills.

• Students have knowledge of and insight into: determinants of sovereign credit risk.

column1: Behavioural economics models systematic deviations from the standard economic model. This seminar will show how to take into account these deviations to improve the predictive power of economic and financial theories. Improving the design and implementation of business strategies and public policies will be dealt with through case studies.

The first part of the course (5 weeks) will consist of guest lectures and case studies in partnership with companies and public organization. The second part of the course (3 weeks) will be dedicated to a research project.

column1: <body>This course consists of three parts: (1) Introduction to audit, (2) Audit and ICT, and (3) Auditing Research. ""(1) Introduction to audit"" provides an insight into the history and the basic principles of auditing, and covers the main steps of the audit approach. ""(2) Audit and ICT"" covers various IT related topics. ""(3) Auditing Research"" covers 12 academic papers to understand core research topics such as audit quality.</body>

column1: In the seminar Behaviour, Health and Wellbeing students will learn to combine the knowledge and skills obtained in the major courses to analyse and possibly influence behaviour related to health and wellbeing. In particular they will work on two themes: (i) healthy behaviour, (ii) wellbeing; with four possible angles
(a) Measuring and analysing behaviour and well-being (e.g., Why do people procrastinate going to the gym?)
(b) Understanding the role of people’s own responsibility (e.g., Should overweight people pay more health insurance premiums?)
(c) Making policy recommendations (e.g., How can we incentivize or nudge healthier behaviour?)
(d) Evaluate the impact of policies (e.g., Can we test whether the incentives work using a field experiment?)

column1: <body>The purpose of this seminar is twofold. First, it covers the most important papers from the behavioral finance literature, with a focus on the recent ""hot topics"" in the field. Second, it gives you the opportunity to engage in academic research. In particular, you will work with data from a Dutch online broker, Binck Bank, to analyze the performance of its clientele, and with aggregate financial and macroeconomic data, to write a short academic paper. Note that the seminar entails both individual and group work.</body>

column1: This course aims at improving our understanding of financial markets and asset returns, by applying insights from psychology and other behavioural sciences. Traditionally, the finance paradigm seeks to understand financial decisions by building on optimal acting investors and market forces that correct mispricing; that is, it assumes people behave rational. However, abundant evidence, reveals that this paradigm is too restrictive and in many circumstances gives a poor description of people's behaviour. We (being people) do not always act in the best way possible. In fact, in many decision situations we make mistakes that result in non-optimal behaviour.

Using interactive sessions, the first part of this course will examine various influential behavioural biases and their implications for financial markets and decisions. The second part of the course will consider how behavioural principles can turn into a profit by studying how behavioural biases affect the behaviour of market participants and prices. Finally, the course will learn you how trading strategies can be developed based upon various behavioural pitfalls.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Students have knowledge of trading strategies can be developed based upon various behavioural pitfalls.
• Students learn how to build trading strategies on behavioral biases and to limit their impact on your investment behavior.
• Students develop a skillset to empirically evaluate various investment strategies.

column1: <body>Students work in small groups on a specific theoretical or empirical econometric problem. Topics stem from international macro-, financial, and micro-econometrics. Each group has its own supervisor(s). Groups meet with their supervisor(s) on a weekly basis, to discuss the progress of the research and relevant issues and questions. During the end of the term, each group writes a report about its research. A plenary session is scheduled at the end of the term, in which the research project is presented by members of the group and discussed by a member of another group, followed by a plenary discussion.</body>

• The student learns to apply his econometric knowledge to do proper econometric inference.
• The student learns to use estimation output resulting from an econometric analysis to answer the research question and to report his research in a scienfic report and a presentation.

column1: The students are divided in small groups. Each group works on a research question. Usually this research question is put forward by a company. First, the relevant literature is studied. Next, the research question is translated in one or more models. To estimate the parameters of the models, (company) data is used. Much attention will be paid to the selection of the best possible model, given the research question. This model can be any model dealt with in the various courses, but it can also be a model that needs to be developed by the students themselves. The model parameters are estimated, and the model results are interpreted within the light of the research question. The final results will be presented in a scientific report and a presentation.

• Learn how to use the outcomes of an analysis to answer the research questions.
• Reporting of academic research in the form of an article.
• Reporting of academic research in the form of a presentation.
• Work in a team.

column1: In this seminar, students will solve real world management problems that are typically put forward by companies. These case studies start with the proper formulation and conceptualization of the research question by studying available literature. After acquiring the relevant data, students will determine and apply the appropriate method of analysis. The final deliverable of this seminar will be a report and a presentation- usually at the company headquarters - that provide an answer to the management problem that is well grounded both theoretically and empirically.
The specific topics will be driven by the company cases, but they are always connected to generating business relevant insights from data.
What students say about this course:

column2: • Challenge ourselves with a real-life case from a well-known company under demanding conditions.
• The seminar was for us the ultimate test of applying those methods we learned during the previous courses using a real-life dataset.

column1: <body>During the seminar you learn about different ways to conduct policy research, using recent cases in policy evaluation. Examples are:

column2: • What can we learn about the impact of unemployment policies using quasi-experimental research designs?
• Can we measure the effect of additional funding for schools with a regression discontinuity design?
• How to set up a fiel experiment to analyze the effects of teacher performance pay?
• What does social-cost benefit analysis tell us about the costs and benefits of the Olympic Games?

column1: Guest lecturers will be invited to tell about their recent policy research. Furthermore, students are expected tot discuss and present policy research during the seminar. Finally, students are expected to write a policy research proposal, do research assignments, and write a policy research paper.</body>

• To understand the underlying assumptions of the main models and the differences with the standard approaches as linear regression and matching models.
• To understand the main techniques of social cost benefit analysis.
• To be able to assess the credibility of policy evaluation by applying the knowledge of the main models and their assumptions.
• To be able to assess the quality of a social cost benefit analysis.
• To be able to present the scientific evidence for a specific policy cases and assess the credility of this evidence.

column1: The goal of the seminar is to increase your knowledge and understanding of the relevant issues in commodity trading from a Finance perspective. This means that we’ll investigate how commodities can be traded and which factors influences prices of the physical product and derivatives, and how the above relates to investments in assets connected to the commodity trade.
The seminar will benefit from a strong cooperation with Glencore Agricultural Products BV, and will therefore focus on agricultural commodities in particular.

Commodities will be studied from 2 directions: the ‘trade-perspective’ who has to find a way to formulate a view on the market, and act accordingly; and the ‘risk manager's perspective’ where one has to judge if the trades do not combine to excessive risk for the company. As always, these topics will be tackled both through the analysis of empirical data and cases, as well as literature study.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The seminar 'Competition Policy' mainly deals with theories of competition and public competition policy. Few people would dispute the importance of markets for our (material) welfare. But if these markets are important, then it also matters whether they function well. This is why we study competition theory and policy.

We will consider the nature of market power by firms and the strategic interaction (competition) between them. We will look at which strategies firms may use to be better off themselves and what consequences those have for consumers. And even when such practices would be harmful per se, it remains the question whether it can and should be forbidden. During this course we will gain insight into the factors that the answers to these questions depend on and why that is the case.
In this course we will discuss the four main topics of Competition policy. These are:

column2: • Market power, and the measurement thereof;
• Collusion between firms;
• Mergers between firms;
• Predation, Entry deterrence and other abusive behavior by firms.

column1: We will analyse these topics using game theoretic tools. Moreover, we will relate our insights to the actual competition laws and policy.</body>

column2: <title></title>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85960,2019,Seminar Consumer Channel Dynamics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr.ir. BGC Dellaert'],,Inhoud

<body>Increasingly firms and consumers work closely together in the value creation process. For example, more and more firms allow customers to tailor products to their own taste (e.g., Nike). Other firms rely heavily on consumers to provide information and also actual services to other consumers (e.g., Uber, Airbnb). To be successful, these new business models typically use many different (digital) marketing channels and strongly integrate information technology in their interactions with consumers. This course analyzes how best to support individual consumers across different channel functions, and how to find ways to activate consumers to become value creators in their own right. To better understand recent trends, the course also activates students to review current examples of firms' usage of information technology to support consumer value creation.</body>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: • Students will develop a better understanding of how firms and consumers interact to create greater consumer value. In particular, students learn to define and analyze different stages in the value creation process in which consumer-firm interactions take place.

• Students learn how to analyze consumer decisions in the different consumer-firm interaction stages. The course focuses on the following stages: consumer information search and choice, consumer purchase decisions, consumer product use, and consumer product evaluations.
• Students practice how to analyze real-world innovative marketing approaches using academic research on consumer-firm interactions and consumer enhancement.
• Students practice creatively developing new marketing value creation ideas based on richer consumer-firm interactions and consumer enhancement. They also practice critically assessing these ideas.
• Students practice team report writing skills.
• Students practice team presentation skills

column1: <body>In this seminar we discuss the key topics in corporate finance, with particular attention to practical applications. The subjects include investment and capital structure decisions by businesses. During the seminar, students will present and discuss academic papers and case studies, including a company valuation where we try to arrange a guest lecture of a valuation expert or company CEO/CFO. The literature mainly consists of articles from the reputable academic journals, as well as chapters from the leading practitioners books and internationally acclaimed finance textbooks. Students are expected to solve the cases and actively study the assigned literature, that is, read and present the articles/chapters, write discussion points related to the readings, and actively participate in group discussions.</body>

• Learning how capital structure decisions are made.
• Understanding the difference between price and value.
• Knowledge of the techniques in which investment decisions are made.
• Having first-hand experience with valuing a company and/or a investment project.

column1: In this seminar several data science/machine learning methods are treated sequentially. First, students acquire the basics behind various machine learning techniques after which they deepen their knowledge and understanding of the methods by implementing and applying the methods to real data.

We discuss and apply several ""state-of-the-art"" machine learning methods.  Students are asked to critically assess, present and discuss the material. Reviewing state-of-the art methods and their application in business settings will help students to assess whether (and how) data can be used to help answer real world business problems.
What students say about the course:
Exhaustive coverage of the main state-of-the-art machine learning techniques, from students to students learning approach""
“The best way to learn something, is by trying to explain it to others. You are forced to know every part and detail of the subject.”

We build on your general knowledge in the marketing area and let you apply it via the extensive discussion of case studies and through other (case-based) assignments.</body>

column1: The definitive decision on the main topic(s) will be made before the start of the course. During the course, students will get an in-depth theoretical and empirical background into the economics of main topics of the course. Guest lecturers with strong expertise in the main topics and policy makers will be invited. Students are expected to prepare lectures well. During the lectures one (or more) student(s) will present the main findings of the required reading to the whole class. Active student participation in the course will be rewarded.

During this course, each student will be writing a policy paper on an important aspect of the main topic(s) of this course. Students will provide a theoretically sound and empirically founded policy advice to solve the policy problem under consideration. Since policy questions will generally be very broad, different students will analyze different sub-questions in their papers. The lecturers provide assistance with writing the papers. Students need to defend their analysis in a class presentation.</body>

• To understand a discussion of the policy question, to understand relevant theoretical literature, to weight theoretical arguments based on their empirical validity, and incorporate practical considerations.
• To weigh theoretical arguments using empirical research.
• To formulate a sound policy advice based on sound economic reasoning, backed up by solid empirical evidence.
• To defend the analysis of a policy question in a presentation.
• To use economic reasoning and logic to understand an economic policy problem
• To write an economic policy advice that contains i) theoretical analysis, ii) empirical evidence of theoretical arguments iii) weighing various arguments iv) formulating a policy recommendation.

column1: This course provides students with an overview of the latest empirical work in the fields of international trade and economic development.
Students will become acquainted with the most recent empirical methods used to uncover the determinants of international trade flows, and (long-run) economic development.

The aim is to give students the basic tools to read and understand the latest empirical work that claims to uncover the role of international trade or globalization in general on countries' or regions' overall level economic development, as well as the role of trade as a driver of income inequality. Upon finishing this course students are able to critically evaluate these studies and judge their validity.

The seminar starts with a brief crash course on the most recent econometric methods used to identify the important factors determining trade and development patterns around the globe. Subsequently, we will critically discuss some of the most influential recent empirical contributions in the fields of international trade and economic development. </body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• This course provides the students with the basic tools to read and understand the latest empirical work that claims to uncover one or more important factors determining countries’ participation in world trade, or their overall level of economic development.
• Upon the completion of this course, students will be able to critically evaluate modern empirical studies  n the fields of international and development economics and judge their validity.
• This course provides students with a thorough understanding of the issues faced by any empirical researcher that aims to establish causal effects using non-experimental data.
• A brief crash course/introduction is given in the use of the statistical package STATA.

column1: The energy market has changed from a monopolistic, fossil fueled sector into a competitive and more sustainable environment. Companies and customers can now produce and trade (renewable) power and gas on exchanges and among themselves.

Energy is a basic human, but it has special characteristics. It is difficult to store power, there transport issues, geopolitics influence prices of commodities, transport and storage. As a result economic factors cleary drive energy prices. From a financial economics perspective: these prices are no random walk.
In this seminar students work on three practical cases with which they obtain insight in how energy markets work, what drives energy prices and how to value energy investments.</body>

• Students are able to apply quantitative financial models to support business decisions in the energy markets.
• Students are able to structure a research project starting from an abstract research question.
• Students are able to make a report for companies about advises on energy finance issues.

column1: <body>The purpose of this seminar is to prepare students with the knowledge, skills, and mindset to advise on FinTech subjects. The program emphasizes both the academic understanding and the applications of recent financial innovations. The program starts with an overview in the FinTech industry from both academic and industrial perspectives. Then, it discusses two heated topics in FinTech, namely, blockchain and financial innovation in the banking sector. Students will also learn to translate academic criticism into business strategies. Activities in this seminar involves paper presentation, group discussion, case studies, and empirical data analysis. Note that the seminar entails both individual and group work.</body>

column1: This course introduces students to commonly studied topics in the field of empirical financial accounting research, teaches them how to develop a research question based on sound argumentation and how to empirically investigate this question. Furthermore, the course prepares students for writing a high quality master thesis through the development of a research proposal and an empirical data assignment. This course is given in a seminar format: small groups of max. 24 students, in which the students and lecturer actively discuss the papers and final research proposals.

In the first four weeks of this course, the students will discuss several papers in each session. Students should be able to identify and explain the research question, contribution, research design, findings and conclusions, as well as critically evaluate all of these aspects. The lecturer will typically introduce the topic and lead the discussion of the first paper, followed by student presentations of the remaining two papers. Students should actively contribute to the discussion and also be able to relate the discussed papers to each other. There will be a final exam in the last week of this course, which covers the material discussed in the first four weeks.

In the second part of this course, students will replicate an existing research study with recent data, in teams of 4. Students are required to hand in a write-up of how they collected and analyzed the data and present the findings in neatly formatted tables and/or figures. Each table should have a footnote which explains the contents of the table.

The students will also write an individual research proposal of no more than 5 pages. This can be used as a basis for the master thesis if deemed sufficient. Students should start by identifying a research topic of interest and searching for literature on this topic. Based on these efforts, they should identify a clear research question which fills a gap in existing literature. Students will present their research proposals in weeks 6 and 7 of this course.
The final grade for this course consists of their participation in the lectures, presentation of the paper, replication assignment, research proposal and final exam.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students can identify and discuss mainstream topics in financial accounting research.
• Students can describe and evaluate theoretical arguments in accounting research.
• Students can describe and explain the main incentives for and consequences of financial reporting and disclosure decisions.
• Students can identify unanswered research questions through careful examination of existing research.
• Students can evaluate whether the empirical research design of a paper can provide an answer to the posed research question.
• Students can describe and draw your own conclusions from the empirical findings (tables/graphs) of a paper.
• Students can develop and present their own arguments founded in good reasoning.
• Students can specify a research design to test a particular research question.
• Students can conduct simple data analyses to answer a research question.

column1: <body>This seminar is one of the most important parts of the bachelor program; it will take a large part of your time: 12 ECTS in 8 weeks is 42 hours of work per week on average. During the seminar a broad array of subjects will be presented dealing with recognition, measurement, presentation and disclosure of financial information. Subjects that are discussed are among others:

column2: • General aspects of financial reporting, such as conceptual frameworks, information needs of users, international developments, accounting policies and earnings management;
• Recognition and measurement of specific items in the balance sheet and profit and loss account, such as tangible, intangible and financial assets, equity, provisions, and liablities;

• Special subjects, such as consolidation, mergers and acquisitions, foreign currency, accounting changes, financial instruments, leasing, segment reporting, environmental/sustainability reporting, cash flow statements, management discussion and analysis;
• Analysis of the annual financial statements of a public company.
• Students have to present papers, solve cases, prepare presentations and take part in the discussions.
<title></title>

• Obtain insight in the recent law and standards concerning external financial.
• Obtain the differences between Dutch GAAP and IFRS.
• Understand the purposes of the annual financial statement.
• Obtain knowledge in which way assets and liabilities and income and expenses in the annual financial statement need to be presented.
• Be able to write papers of different subjects concerning the annual financial statement.
• Based on recent literature students should be able to perform an presention during the course.

column1: Students work in teams of 4 on specific (theoretical or empirical) financial econometric research projects, which are supplied by firms in the financial industry (including asset managers, hedge funds, insurance companies, and pension funds). Examples include problems in asset pricing, portfolio management, risk management, and derivatives pricing.

Each group has its own supervisor(s). Groups meet with their supervisor(s) on a weekly basis, to discuss the progress of the research and relevant issues and questions. Each group writes a report about its research.  A plenary session is scheduled at the end of the course term, in which the research project is presented by a member of the group and discussed by a member of another group, followed by a plenary discussion.</body>

• Learn how to use the outcomes of an econometric analysis to answer the research questions.
• Learn to report about the research project in the form of a (scientific) report and a presentation.
• Learn to collaborate on a research project in a team with fellow students.

column1: The course examines specific issues involved in developing and executing brand strategy on an international (pan-regional or global) scale as opposed to a domestic scale. The course is intended to provide a thorough understanding of global brand strategies, including (i) pitfalls and challenges of entering other countries, (ii) ways to design effective global brand strategies, (iii) key issues in the implementation of global brand strategies.

Most traditional market boundaries have disappeared. Successful firms in sectors as diverse as consumer packaged goods, consumer durables, industrial goods, and services have discovered that traditional rules of competition - such as focusing only on the competitive interplay in each country separately - have changed dramatically in today's globalized markets. New strategies are determining who are the winners and the losers. Firms which respond proactively to the challenges of a globalized world outperform firms who are unable to adequately respond to a changed world. Firms cannot ignore this trend to globalization. Even if they decide not to be involved in the global or pan-regional (ASEAN, EU, Mercosur, NAFTA, etc.) marketplace, companies still face increased competition in their home markets because of nimble foreign competitors reaping the benefits of global strategies.

The course will help you achieve your career goals as virtually all of you will work in or with companies that are active in the international marketplace as well as domestic companies that face international competitors.

A book, a packet of readings and cases, and a computer-based international marketing simulation game, CountryManager, will be used. The simulation will entail selecting a new international market for entry, establishing a brand presence in that market, and expanding into additional foreign markets.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Knowledge of factors and criteria that determine foreign market attractiveness, and the appropriate entry mode.
• Knowledge of how to design and implement effective global marketing strategies.
• Writing a marketing plan for foreign market development.
• Managing international expansion activities as a country manager in a real-world setting (simulation game).
• Analyzing and presenting business strategy & performance at national and regional level.
<title></title>

column1: Asset management helps individuals and organizations prepare for the future. This seminar will analyze pension funds that encompass millions of retirement accounts, endowment funds that sustain major educational institutions, and sovereign wealth funds that benefit a whole nation. The goal of this course is to develop a broad perspective on the asset management business.

An array of different developments has been affecting the international asset management industry in recent years. In particular, the strong volatility in equity markets, interest rates falling to unprecedented low and even negative levels, extreme moves in oil prices and currencies, the availability of new asset classes and the ongoing aging of populations in many countries. Meanwhile, the amount of assets managed professionally has multiplied in the last decade and the institutions have become a major player in international capital flows.

The seminar is structured around three main topics. First, the course starts with analyzing the largest category of institutional investors based on assets under management, defined benefit and defined contribution pension funds. We will also study endowment funds and sovereign wealth funds, and compare the asset and liabilities of these institutional investors.

Second, the seminar will focus on the asset allocation policy implemented by institutional investors. We will answer two key questions. How do institutions decide on the level of capital to allocate to individual asset classes? How to implement the asset allocation? The seminar will discuss in detail the issues of diversification, portfolio optimization, trading costs, passive and active strategies. We will discuss not only traditional investments in equity and fixed income, but also investments in alternative assets, like private equity, hedge funds and real estate. The students will also work on a quantitative assignment that analyzes the added value of alternative assets for the current portfolio of a pension fund.

Third, the seminar will cover in-depth the governance and organizational complexities surrounding institutional investors. This part of the course will discuss the fiduciary responsibilities of institutional investors and study the role of socially responsible investing and institutional shareholder activism. An important question is whether investing in this type of funds has (positive or negative) consequences for institutional investors because of the inherent restriction of the universe of stocks.

We will also work on a case study of All Pensions Group (APG), the largest Dutch institutional asset manager. In this assignment, the students benefit from working under the supervision of Dr. O.W. Steenbeek, who is Managing Director of Strategic Portfolio Advice APG, in addition to his affiliation with Erasmus University.

This seminar will be of great interest to students aiming for a career in mutual fund, pension fund, or private wealth management. A fundamental understanding of the issues in institutional portfolio management will also be beneficial for students focused on other areas of financial economics such as investment banking, corporate finance, governance, accounting, insurance and household finance. In addition, students will learn how to better manage their future personal wealth. To succeed in finance industry, you need to master the quantitative skills of a portfolio manager. To be a leader in this field, you also need a thorough knowledge of how markets and organizations function across countries.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Insights in the way a specific asset manager works by doing a case study and visiting the company.
• Students will learn how to work in groups, participate in a discussion, critically read academic articles, present to an audience.

column1: This seminar covers several topics on interest rates and stock markets.
In particular, we discuss term structure of interest rates, interest rates modeling, cross-sectional stock returns, investor recognition hypothesis and financial crisis.
Students are expected to study and present the literature from renowned academic journals, lead and participate in group discussions. There are two assignments on empirical asset pricing.
In addition, you will present your own ideas and write a research proposal.
