column1: This course aims at providing exposure to relevant topics on international financial markets. Five main topics are covered: (1) sovereign default models, (2) international transmission of shocks, (4) the international transmission of monetary policy, (4) international risk sharing and the home bias puzzle, and (5) the effect of international capital flows on economic activity. We will cover both theories and empirical studies. This is a master course appropriate for students with previous knowledge on macroeconomic theory and/or econometrics and/or finance. The evaluation includes participation and presentations in class, homework and an essay.

• Students have knowledge of models of international risk sharing, home biases, and sovereign default.
• Students have knowledge of the international transmission of shocks through financial markets.
• Students are able to interpret findings in academic papers.

column1: <body>Following the most recent trends in empirical research, this seminar will take a firm-level approach to the study of international trade. To have a firm grasp in understanding the empirics, we will start off with the “new” trade theory of international trade, its extension with heterogeneous firms, and the related gravity model of trade. We will then focus on the empirical research on heterogeneous firms and trade by studying and discussing frontier academic papers. The topics covered will include: self-selection into exporting, learning by exporting, multi-product firms, intermediaries in trade, and most importantly, the impact of trade policy shocks on different firms.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>The purpose of this seminar is to provide students with an understanding of the role of firms in international trade. By completing this course, students will be able to answer questions such as: Why only a few firms export? How are they different than other firms? How do multi-product firms engage in international trade? What is the role of intermediaries in facilitating trade? What is the impact of trade policy shocks on different firms? Upon the completion of this course, the students will be able to critically evaluate empirical research, especially in identifying causal effects using micro-data to answer policy-relevant questions.</body>

column1: This seminar focuses on the design and use of accounting information for decision making and decision influencing. The emphasis will be on understanding how managers can design and use accounting information to help the organisation achieve its objectives. Some of the topics that will be discussed are Performance measurement, Incentives, Earning Management,Value-Based Management and Accoutning for non-profits. In this seminar learning will occur trough active participation, class discussion, and self-discipline. To enhance this, the professor will assign each student to a team consisting of 2-4 students. Each team has to write a paper on one of the topics of the seminar, assigned by the professor. Each team will present their paper in the session on that specific topic. One of the other teams  has to be the discussant team, and still another team is responsible for chairing the session and stimulate the discussion in class. Each team has to fulfill each of the different roles at least once. The professor will make a schedule at the beginning of the seminar that lists when each team has to perform a specific role. Please note that this seminar is one of the most important parts of the bachelor program. It will be very time-consuming: 12 ECTS  in 8 weeks is, on average, 42 hours of work per week.

• Students are expected to actively participate in the class discussion, to present pieces of the empirical literature, to chair meetings, critically analyse research paper, and to write a paper based on corresponding group assignments.

column1: <body>In this course we discuss the various formal mechanisms that can be used to influence the decision making of people in organizations. The focus is on understanding the antecedents and consequences of the design and use of controls in organizations. Some questions that we will deal with are:

column2: • How should we measure the performance of managers and business units?
• How, if at all, do managers use accounting information in making business decisions?
• How tight should control systems be?
• When and how do monetary incentives increase performance?

column1: The seminar is taught in a workshop format with a strong emphasis on student participation and interaction. Class size is limited to a maximum of 24 students. We will discuss and analyze recent research papers to provide a ""state-of-the-art"" overview of the academic knowledge in this area. The seminar provides a broad view on the subject, offering insights from economics as well as the behavioral sciences.

Students will be asked to critically assess, present and discuss research papers in a selection of topics related to control problems. This will help students develop a critical mind-set toward research and help them develop their own research skills. These skills are further developed through the writing of a research proposal.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the various formal mechanisms that can be used to influence the decision making of people in organizations.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the antecedents and consequences of the design and use of controls in organizations.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the “state-of-the-art” in the academic management accounting literature.
• Students are able to: understand the various decisions that need to be made when designing management control systems.
• Students are able to: read and understand academic management accounting research papers and write their own research proposal.
• Students are able to: analyze accounting and control system design from a number of different theoretical perspectives.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: There are some changes of this course this year compared to the last year.

1. To pass the course, the grade for the written exam should be at least 5.0. In this way, students can be better motivated to read the required literature and thus have a good understanding of the topics.

2. Students will not lead the group discussion this year, but the lecturer will do so to guarantee the quality of the discussion. Students then need to complete another assignment. So this year, students have two assignments, either write a research proposal or a referee report.
3. Students are required to find real-life cases that can reflect the issues discussed in the academic papers. Therefore students connect the theories with practice.
4. We will add case analyses this year, so that students can apply theories and solve real-life control problems.
5. Students also need to lead the discussion of each assigned literature.</body>

column1: The objective of this course is to show you the benefits of using a systematic and analytical approach to marketing decision-making, and to build your skills and confidence in undertaking such analyses and decision making. An analytical approach will enable you to acquire research techniques that provide more detailed insights into customer behavior. You will learn how to link changes in marketing activities of the firm to alter customer behavior and to assign a monetary value to these shifts in customer behavior. By completing this course, you will be well on your way to making the ROI case for marketing expenditures that companies are increasingly asking of their executives.

The course is designed for students who have extensive background in or understanding of marketing research and marketing principles, and who know or are prepared to learn to use statistical software such as MEXL or STATA. Using market related exercises tied to PC-based computer software, students will develop marketing plans in varying decision contexts.
Specifically, the course objectives are to:

column2: • Provide students with an understanding of the role that analytical techniques and computer models can play in enhancing marketing decision making in modern enterprises.
• Expose students to numerous examples demonstrating the value of the analytic approach to marketing decision making.
• Provide students with the software tools that will enable them to apply the models and methods taught in the course to real marketing problems.
• Improve students' skill in viewing marketing processes and relationships systematically and analytically.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• After this course the students should be able to explain the construction of the statistical models used to describe consumer behaviours.
• After this course the students should be able to identify the right context of the real life problem where these statistical models can be applied.
• After this course the students should be able to calibrate the introduced statistical models on real life dataset.
• After this course the students should be able to utilize different statistical computer software to estimate the introduced statistical models.
• After this course the students should be able to communicate the results to the general audience in an intuitive and practically relevant way.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students should be aware that the course is a merge between a CRM course and a Marketing Analytics course, which means the analytics part will have a clear CRM focus.
• There will also be the addition of a ""Google Trends"" exercise in replacement of the interview assignment.

column1: <body>The unprecedented growth of capital flows over the last decennia and the substantial share of multinational enterprises (MNEs) in world production, trade, and investments make it relevant to dedicate a course to the behavior and consequences of multinational enterprises. This course aims at analyzing problems of trade policy, of competition, and of global financial markets. The field is alive with great practical problems:

column2: • Why multinationals?
• How important is international production, and what are the channels through which it affects the real economy?
• What are the tools for competition among governments to attract capital from the limited pool of international investments?
• How important is transfer pricing, and what is the role of taxation and exchange rates in this regard?
• What are the characteristics of footloose companies?
• Is increasing global financial integration affecting the nature and international propagation of MNEs?
• How do firms use capital investments to gain strategic advantages?
• What is the use of foreign exchange and option markets?

column1: These are issues that interest policymakers, business people, researchers, and students alike. It is no wonder that these issues command the attention of the world press.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Thorough knowledge of the impact of multinationals on financial markets and economic activity.
• Thorough knowledge of reasons why multinationals exist and grow.
• Establish links with other parts of theoretical and empirical economics (uncertainty, pricing behavior of firms, taxation, etc.).
• Focus on the ability of solving problems and presenting them to a large audience.
• Achieve a high standard in writing skills (term paper); focus on own contribution.
• Importance of teamwork (term paper).
• Master analytical skills pertaining to the field (problem solving; exam with 5.5 as passing grade).

column1: The seminar is organized around several key papers (and background reading) in the economics of organizations. Topics covered include the theory of contracts, theory of the firm, incentives and productivity, and vertical integration. Topics vary from year to year depending on the interests of the students.

column2: <title></title>

• To learn about the state of the art in the economic theory of organizations.
• To learn about the data and methods required to test the theory, and more specifically how field experiments can be used to glean insights about organizational theory.

• To be able to assess inefficiencies relating to incentive problems and organizational design more generally and to evaluate alternative pay schemes and organizational structures that purport to alleviate such efficiencies.

column2: <title></title>

column1: <body>The seminar has a theoretical and an empirical part, both of which try to confront insights from macro models with real-life problems faced by policy makers and central bankers. Ample attention is given to the challenges posed by the financial crisis to the macroeconomic profession. The theoretical part of the seminar takes stock of the current theory of macro and monetary economics and reviews a number of technical issues, such as solving a rational expectations model with forward looking agents. The analysis of DSGE (Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium) models and their linearization. We also study some of the recent developments. The empirical part of the seminar is devoted to estimating and experimenting with small scale macroeconomic models to be developed by the students in small groups. At the end of the seminar, students present policy recommendations based on simulations with their estimated models.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Know how to estimate and simulate a small scale macro model.
• Are able to analyze and manipulate modern macro models.
• Estimate a self fabricated small scale macro model. Simulate the estimated model and investigate its stability properties. Make dynamic forecasts on basis of the model.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Cities and regions are going through a constant process of economic, social and spatial change. This applies to the most successful global cities but also to those cities that had to go through (or are still going through) a process of economic restructuring because their dominant industries collapsed. This continuous economic, social, and spatial development of cities can strengthen its competitive position but for cities struggling to reinvent their economies, it can be (and possibly still is) a painful process for these cities and for individuals within these cities. Hence, the economic development of cities is a topic that is high on the agenda of both academics and policymakers.

Companies and citizens increasingly face problems in terms of accessibility and mobility. Due to congestion and internalisation of external costs, transport and mobility become (too) expensive. Accordingly, transport and mobility management rank high on the agenda of many companies as significant cost savings can be realized. An increasing number of consultants specialize in advising companies and governments in this respect.

Also the competiveness of urban regions is at stake, which explains the high interest of politicians and policy makers in addressing problems in relation to the attractiveness of cities as a location for companies and citizens. Transport and mobility is one concern, but other important aspects relate to image, quality and affordability of housing, area regeneration and tourism.

In this seminar, the objective is to develop the ability to give strategic advice to stakeholders in order to increase their competitiveness. Students learn to use different research methods (i.e. data analysis, case study, surveys etc.) in order to come up with intelligent solutions to the most common transport and mobility problems.

Each year topics are selected with high relevance for improving mobility and urban development. Among others some of the following topics will be analyzed: land use and transport, transportation demand management, accessibility and attractiveness of urban shopping areas, the economics of (re)development of sporting infrastructure (i.e. football stadiums), the structural economic change in cities, innovation in cities and the economic regeneration of city districts.

These topics are discussed based on the latest scientific insights and real life case study. Students are stimulated to use a variety of research tools to analyze actual challenges. The seminar includes guest speakers’ presentations and/or field visits. It is an intensive course that combines interactive group discussions, the writing of weekly individual essays, (field) assignments as well as empirical group work and assignments.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• To deepen the knowledge on specific regional and transport problems by advanced scientific readings.
• To develop the ability to apply research and methodological tools to analyse contemporary regional and transport challenges.
• To develop accurate and sound economic strategic advice for stakeholders.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Each year this seminar focuses on some ""hot issues"" in regional and transport economics.
At least two of the six seminar sessions will focus on new themes compare to the program of last year.
For example, this year we will focus on the theme of 'floating mobility' (i.e. bike- and scooters-sharing systems).</body>

<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The globalization of business paired with rapid technological changes and increased volatility in the financial markets have changed the risk profiles of many companies dramatically. At the same time, derivative markets have grown accordingly, and the routes to managing market and credit risks have expanded. As a result, many firms have embraced the concept of risk management. However, applying derivatives for risk management requires a deep understanding of their characteristics, their pricing, and, last but not least, of the markets on which they are traded. In addition, because of the interplay of various risks at the aggregated firm level, risks should be analyzed and managed in a coherent and consolidated way.

This seminar is devoted to the firm-wide analysis and management of risks and complements the course Financial Innovations and Institutions (FEM11023). The seminar covers a range of derivative contracts, including forwards, futures, and options. It explains arbitrage arguments, trading strategies, the use of binomial trees, Black & Scholes valuation, and volatility modeling. You will learn about derivatives markets and how derivative instruments can be used for risk management. We will study in detail how risk management applies to both banks and non-financial companies. Finally, we will discuss novel types of risks associated with the advancement of fintech. Through group assignments, various theoretical and practical topics in derivatives, risk analysis, and integrated risk management are explored in depth.
The objectives of the seminar are:
-            to provide insight into the theoretical and practical aspects of financial engineering and risk management;
-            to enhance the skills necessary to analyze case assignments, conduct empirical research, and report and present research findings.</body>

• Students are able to value futures and options using various methods.

• Students are able to use GARCH models to measure and manage risk and to price derivatives.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85959,2019,Seminar Strategic Marketing,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. NM Almeida Camacho', 'P Gorji']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Marketing has become an important integral part of today's business activities. However, the process through which strategic marketing decisions should be taken is not always clear. In particular, in many firms there is a tension between short-term (tactical) decisions aimed at improving financial returns versus long-term (strategic) decisions aimed at increasing the firm value in the long term. Moreover, marketers are increasingly required to make evidence-based decisions and to be able to integrate their decisions with the overall firm strategy (i.e. to deliberate on the financial and operational consequences of marketing decisions). All these issues make strategic marketing a top concern for firms and a fascinating topic. In this seminar we discuss the important role of strategic marketing and its impact on the long term value of a firm.

We will build upon theoretical insights obtained from academic research with the more practical marketing decision environment (e.g. the role of marketing intelligence in strategic decisions).  Students will also be exposed to stressful decision-making situations which require deep collaboration and teamwork and sharp usage of marketing intelligence and strategizing skills, in line with the situations students will face as professional marketers. These goals will be achived by playing an exciting and sophisticated marketing strategy simulation game (StratSim) and working on several assignments related to strategic decisions taken in this simulated environment.

Furthermore, we will also pay attention to the development of soft skills as well as analytical marketing and presentation/reporting skills. Specifically, during the marketing strategy simulation game, students will be exposed to the need to interpret output from marketing analyses and use their marketing knowledge to make decisions that will have market and financial consequences for their simulated firms. In the end, the students, role-playing as company managers, will need to present the rationale and lessons from their strategic decisions to a board of shareholders (the rest of the class).</body>

column2: <title></title>

column1: The content of the seminar is fourfold. Two group assignments:
1. Solving a business case on a strategy issue using relevant insights from the academic literature and available data to the best extent.

2. Collecting and summarizing research papers to give an overview of relevant research on a topic related to firm strategy Providing a critical assessment of the literature to identify a relevant research question for further research.
3. Presenting a research paper in class to give an insight in relevant research on a topic related to firm strategy. Answering questions from fellow students and moderating a class discussion.
4. Writing a summary on each of the research questions discussed in class with critical assessment of the presented papers.
1. Can successful management practices be transferred across countries and firms?
2. What is the impact of top managers on the performance of firms?
3. Can firms acquire new technology by hiring workers?
4. What is the effect of entry regulation on economic performance?
5. Why are firms using other firms to produce their output?</body>

• Search and analyse firm data in a group project to solve a business case related to entry strategy.
• Write an informed opinion on current topics in industrial dynamics and strategy research based on relevant literature.
• Conduct an in-depth literature review and define a relevant research question on a specialized topic in industrial dynamics and strategy.

column1: <body>This seminar gives an overview of important developments in supply chains, and the management thereof.  It gives a tool-box in terms of research skills (Excel skills and finding data) and methods in order to be able to analyze and optimize supply chains, focusing on costs as well as value added.  We focus on a case for importing white goods from China to Europe.  The case serves to get hands-on experience in the considerations for choosing between different transport modes (what to ship and what to fly), cost structures, selection of distribution network, port choices and locations of distribution centers. Finally we also evaluate environmental issues relating to supply chains. The required theory will be given in five courses at the start of the seminar.</body>

• To be able to apply simplified supply chain design and transport chain models.
• To develop the research skills and methods necessary to analyze and optimize supply chains.
• To develop computer skills (spreadsheets) to do supply chain calculations and visualising.
• To write a report.
• To present.

column1: This course concentrates on exchange-rate theory and policy. The seminar has five parts. It begins with a review of important concepts related to foreign exchange markets. This is followed by a discussion of different models of exchange rates and their policy implications. In the third part, we will discuss what constitutes an optimal currency area and implications for the EMU. The fourth part looks at the efficiency of foreign exchange markets and the predictability of exchange rates.  In the last part of the seminar, we will study the currency crises.  We ask students to actively read up on the financial press such as the Economist, the Wall Street Journal and Financial Times. Topics and emphasis may differ per semester depending on the actuality.

• Improve analytical skills (solving problems; exam with 5.5 as passing grade).

column1: <body>In previous years, the seminar consisted of lectures and problem set sessions. This year, the time allocated to lectures has been reduced, and sessions of student presentations have been added. The new format with student presentations can better stimulate active participation. Furthermore, the new format provides students the opportunity to read and discuss academic papers by themselves and prepare them for writing their bachelor thesis. The new format is thus more compatible with the aim of a seminar. The content of the lecture has been modified so it is less theoretical but still provides students the necessary knowledge of the field.</body>

column1: This seminar covers recent topics in International Trade. Among others, the following questions are explored: Can international trade help countries grow rich? Does international trade cause inequality? Who is for and against trade in politics, and why? Why do countries have trade surpluses/deficits, and to which extent are such imbalances problematic? What are the causes and effects of trade wars?
The seminar combines economic theory, quantitative empirical evidence, and historical case studies to throw light on these topics.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86034,2019,Seminar in Firm Location Strategy,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. B Karreman', 'dr. S Stavropoulos', 'dr. Z Wang', 'prof.dr. MJ Burger', 'Z Csafordi, MA']",,"Inhoud

<body>The choice of location has a profound influence on firm performance in terms of productivity, profit, and innovation. For example, the availability of a large pool of skilled labor or access to an excellent transport infrastructure may considerably enhance a firm's productivity. This makes multinationals very selective in choosing locations (for offices, distribution centers, production, etc.). There are many types of foreign direct investments, and each type has different requirements in terms of location. Due to a globalizing world, the choice set of multinationals becomes larger, which makes the investment decision increasingly challenging. Given the high commercial stakes, location choices are prominent in the strategy of multinationals. Investment decisions are also a game with several competing local and regional governments. Politicians and policy makers are willing to offer facilities in terms of tax cuts, subsidies, and public amenities as foreign direct investments are thought to boost the economic performance of a region. The aim of this seminar is to gain understanding about the location decisions of multinationals and to what extent these decisions are influenced by local and regional governments. During the first half of the course, students are expected to present and discuss recent articles related to foreign direct investments by multinationals. In the second half of the course, students have to conduct an empirical study in which they combine econometric techniques with theories on multinational strategy and foreign direct investment.</body>

column1: Skill Seminars are training seminars in practical skills. They are essential to kick-starting an effective professional career and fundamental to adjusting easily to an international management environment. Topics include:

column2: • Personal Development
• Intercultural skills
• Project Management
• Group work abilities
• International negotiation techniques
• Presentation skills
• CV building and Job Application preparation
• Business Communication (BCSS, for which participation is mandatory)

column1: Small groups ensure an interactive dimension. Skill Seminars are offered by the CEMS member schools, very often in close cooperation with companies.

Students must attend minimum four Skill Seminar days in total (2 ECTS) (1 day = 8 hours = 0.5 ECTS), of which at least two days must consist of the MBC skill seminar. The other two skill seminar days are of the student's own choice.
Company training sessions or other practical external seminars can substitute CEMS Skill Seminars if validated by the home Academic Director.

column1: The small business is the most common type of business in every modern economy, and is not just a scaled-down version of a large business. The course ‘Small Business Economics’ is about the differences between small and large businesses, new business formation, and the role of small businesses and entrepreneurs in markets and economies. Parts of the textbook 'Small business and entrepreneurship' by Storey & Greene (2010) will be covered (this book is also used in the course 'Introduction to Industrial Dynamics and Strategy') as well as some seminal journal articles in the field of entrepreneurship. During the course, students are required to complete two assignments.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Introduction to the role of small businesses, startups and nascent ventures in the economy.
• Introduction to the differences between small and large firms both from an external perspective (economics, market, industry) and from an internal perspective (management, governance).
• Introduction to the specifics of small business finance.
• Combining a handbook with more scientific style publications.
• Mining a large dataset for stylised facts using standard and simple statistical tools.
• Applying theory to case studies.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Literature: Journal articles instead of a book.
• 2 PC tutorials to work on assignments (with teacher present for questions).

column1: Wetenschappelijke kennis over ziekte en gezondheid vormt de basis van de medische praktijk in onze westerse samenlevingen. Deze kennis over ziekte is, met het huidige biomedische model als uitgangspunt, van betrekkelijk recente datum: het eind van de 19e eeuw. In dit vak bestuderen studenten deze biomedische kennis, onder meer aan de hand van een aantal in Nederland veel voorkomende gezondheidsproblemen. Aan de hand hiervan zal tegelijkertijd duidelijk worden dat de huidige wetenschappelijke kennis het resultaat is van sociale en culturele factoren. Kennis is dan ook veelal historisch bepaald. Door middel van deze meer (medisch) sociologische visie krijgen studenten inzicht in de ""constructivistische"" zienswijze op wetenschappelijke kennis over gezondheid en ziekte.

Gezondheidsproblemen komen niet in dezelfde mate voor in verschillende bevolkingsgroepen. Zo zijn er verschillen naar geslacht en leeftijd, maar ook naar sociaaleconomische positie en etnische herkomst. Om dit te bestuderen is demografische en epidemiologische basiskennis nodig om gezondheidsproblemen en deze relevante factoren te meten en om de onderlinge relaties vast te stellen.

Bovendien worden basale modellen ter verklaring van dergelijke verschillen in gezondheid geïntroduceerd, evenals modellen ter verklaring van verschillen in het omgaan met ziekte (gezondheidspsychologie) en in het zoeken van hulp. Een belangrijke factor hierbij zijn de zogenaamde ""lekenopvattingen"" van ziekte en gezondheid. Immers, de wetenschappelijke kennis over ziekte wordt ook vandaag niet door alle bevolkingsgroepen in dezelfde mate gedeeld. Inzicht in deze ""lekenopvattingen"" is belangrijk vanwege de invloed op de omgang met ziekte en het zorggebruik, waaronder bijvoorbeeld de therapietrouw.

Uit voorgaande beschrijving wordt duidelijk dat de sociaal medische wetenschappen bestaan uit verschillende disciplines. Studenten maken daarom kennis met de biomedische geneeskunde, (medische) sociologie, demografie, epidemiologie en gezondheidspsychologie.

De beoogde doelstellingen worden bijgebracht aan de hand van hoorcolleges en werkgroepen. In de hoorcolleges worden de basisconcepten, -modellen en relevante theorieën toegelicht. In de werkgroepen worden deze inzichten toegepast aan de hand van een aantal geselecteerde gezondheidsproblemen. Daarbij wordt gekozen voor voorbeelden van uiteenlopende aard: infectieziekten, chronische gezondheidsproblemen en psychische problematiek.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86226,2019,Sociaal wetenschappelijk onderzoek in de praktijk,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. JA Holland', 'dr. JFA Braster', 'dr. TMIC Stam']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: Deze cursus introduceert diverse sociale wetenschapsonderzoeken perspectieven en methodologieën. Door deze cursus wordt jouw begrip van filosofische, theoretische en ethische kwesties die van belang zijn voor het doen van onderzoek verbreed, en krijg je meer inzicht in de relatie tussen theorie en onderzoek in de praktijk.

Om meer inzicht in het onderzoeksproces te krijgen—van idee tot onderzoeksdesign tot de productie van nieuwe kennis— volgt de cursus twee afzonderlijke, doch aan elkaar verbonden, paden. Het eerste pad betreft het aanleren van methoden van data verzamelen, data analyse en de interpretatie van de analyses. Het tweede pad bestaat uit het tonen van voorbeelden van onderzoek te tonen die gebruik maken van: kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve methoden, innovatieve dataverzamelings- en analysetechnieken, ‘natural experiements’, en creatieve vergelijkingen van verschillende hypotheses.

Deze cursus bestrijkt algemene onderwerpen zoals: wetenschappelijke integriteit, epistemologie, ethiek, ‘mixed’ methoden en ‘big data.’ Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan een reeks (zogenaamde) kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve onderzoeksmethoden.

Daarnaast geeft deze cursus je een methodologische basis voor de verdere ontwikkeling van je methodologische gereedschapskist en draagt de cursus bij aan de ontwikkeling en het management van je eigen onderzoeksprojecten (in het bijzonder je masterscriptie). De geleerde onderzoeksvaardigheden zijn niet alleen binnen, maar ook buiten de wetenschap (zowel in de publieke als private sector) van belang voor een socioloog.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Na de voltooiing van deze cursus kun je:

column2: • De basale wetenschapsfilosofische componenten van diverse methodologieën in de sociale wetenschappen uitleggen (bijv. naturalisme, constructivisme).
• De principes van ethiek, privacy en wetenschappelijke integriteit in sociaal onderzoek uitleggen en toepassen;
• Weten waar te starten met het uitvoeren van een sociaalwetenschappelijk literatuuronderzoek naar een bepaald thema;
• Beantwoordbare sociaalwetenschappelijke onderzoeksvragen formuleren, alsmede aangeven welke data en analyses het beste bij dergelijke vragen aansluiten;
• De principes van ‘sampling’ uitleggen;
• Verslagen van empirisch sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek evalueren en onderzoeken in hoeverre zij antwoorden bieden op de gestelde onderzoeksvragen;
• De belangrijkste benaderingen in kwalitatief onderzoek begrijpen (participerende observatie, etnografisch onderzoek, interviewen);
• De belangrijkste procedures voor de analyse en interpretatie van kwalitatieve data begrijpen en toepassen (grounded theory, coderen, memo-en);

• Verschillende technieken om kwantitatieve data te analyseren en interpreterenbeschrijven en toepassen (verschillende regressie-analyses, factor analyse, betrouwbaarheidsanalyse, and multi-level analyse;
• Uitwijden over de beloftes en uitdagingen van big data analyses voor sociaal wetenschappelijk onderzoek;
• De basisprincipes achter traditionele en geautomatiseerde benaderingen van tekstanalyse begrijpen (denk aan krantenberichten, beleidsrapporten).

column1: Na de voltooiing van deze cursus heb je de volgende vaardigheden ontwikkeld:

column2: • Een codeerschema ontwikkelen (met als doel het analyseren van interviewtranscripten, andere teksten, observaties, etnografieën) met behulp van Atlas.ti;
• Bi- en multivariate associaties tussen variabelen verkennen met behulp van SPSS
• Multivariate analyses met behulp van SPSS regressieprocedures uitvoeren en de resultaten interpreteren;

column1: Moderatie en mediatie analyses uitvoeren met behulp van de PROCESS applicatie en de resultaten interpreteren.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87476,2019,Social Entrepreneurship,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. P Versari'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In the spirit of Muhammad Yunus, this course makes you explore the kind of world you can create as a social entrepreneur. We will motivate and inform you about how social entrepreneurs leverage the power of business solutions to overcome social and ecological challenges. Through various teaching cases we will discuss how social entrepreneurship could be defined, how hybrid organizations strike a delicate balance between social and economic objectives, and how social entrepreneurship unleashes the promise of business for social impact. Because this course is not limited to theory, you will also get to develop a mind-breaking solution to a social problem yourself as part of a real world assignment for a renowned social enterprise.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The course will provide students with knowledge that allows them to:

column2: <li>
understand how social entrepreneurs manage to simultaneously create social and economic value.
<li>
understand and reflect upon the nature and challenges of social entrepreneurship.
<li>

develop a broad understanding of selected topics on social entrepreneurship, including: the hybridization movement, characteristics of social entrepreneurs, social opportunities, and social return on investment.
<li>
apply their newly gained knowledge to a real-life situation by using the principles of design thinking.

column1: What are dimensions of inequality? How unequal are societies we live in? Is it getting better or worse? What factors determine these trends? In this course, students will develop the tools necessary to critically evaluate such questions. Students gain an overview in the many dimensions of inequality in contemporary societies (e.g. economic, ethnic, gender, spatial). Special attention is given to the mechanism through which these inequalities are produced and reproduced in social institutions like the family, school, neighborhood and workplace. Furthermore, we will focus on the consequences of social inequalities in terms of individuals’ wellbeing and health. Students will learn how researchers study these processes in national and international contexts. They will learn about the challenges facing scholarship, and participate in key debates that animate contemporary inequalities research.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Explore central concepts through which sociologists investigate inequality.

2. Develop a descriptive and analytical understanding of how class, gender, ethnicity and other dimensions of inequality impact interactions, institutional placements, choices, and social policy in contemporary societies.
3. Become familiar with key debates that animate contemporary research on inequality.
4. Consider and critique competing explanations for social stratification and social mobility.
5. Learn about how these concepts are applied in quantitative, qualitative and mixed-methods empirical research
After successful completion of this course, students will also have developed the following skill:

column2: • Be able to write an academic paper on patterns, causes and consequences of social inequalities

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Social media campaigns is a research workshop with a deceptively simple goal—to understand how organizations (may) use social media for strategic benefit—and to apply that understanding to a small-scale empirical study. Guiding questions include: To what end/for what purposes are organizations using social media, how organizations may realize the benefit/ROI from using social media, what are the parameters for ‘success’ in such campaigns, the (theoretical and pragmatic) differences among various social media, what motivates audiences to participate and interact with brands, and how organizations might invite such identifications.

The primary methods of learning in this course will be in-class discussion, cases, and individual or group empirical research. By examining and evaluating campaigns/cases, participants will construct and generate collective understanding of social media campaigns—their goals, strategies, and specific tactics—and apply these understandings for their own empirical study.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 16. Students of the MA programme in Media & Business take priority over other students.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Methods for bench-marking social media communication strategies.
• State-of the art theory and practice on the subject of the workshop.
• Goals, strategies, and tactics used in social media initiatives across different sub-disciplines of communication (organizational, political, health)
• Design and execute a small-scale empirical study for a client.
• Report on their findings in oral and written form, both academically and for the market.
• Critically reflect on the potential and opportunities of using social media for strategic gain.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87144,2019,Social Media Strategies for Business Communication,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. M Scalvini'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course offers a combination of theory and practice designed to advance student’ understanding of the cultural and social complexities of social media in business communication. We will challenge the mainstream concepts of business communication and research the strategies that companies employ online in various industries (e.g., fashion, technology, cosmetics) from a cultural and social perspective. We will also look at narrative aspects of social media advertising such as originality, creativity and storytelling. In this way, we will examine the best practices and strategic opportunities that companies can efficiently and effectively adopt online to communicate about their brands with their targets.  This approach to business communication requires the understanding of new digital research methods such as social listening through text mining, sentiment analysis and social network analysis. In our exploration of these topics, we will also examine to what extent artificial intelligence and machine learning might transform business communication.  To round off the course, we will discuss how to create a comprehensive social media campaign and execute it. We will achieve these goals through diverse readings, case studies, class discussions, creative brainstorming, research activities, in-class activities and teamwork.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • the paradigm-change in business communication;
• the importance of culture and social context when looking at business communication;
• the cultural and social implications for both marketers and consumers;
• the potential and limits of the use of social media in business communication;
• how some of the world’s leading brands have successfully applied content and digital media into their strategies;
• the concerns related to the evolving landscape of data and algorithms;
• analyse different online advertising campaigns;
• focus on emerging trends in digital culture, online consumer behaviour, and data analytics;
• analyse social media content through new methodologies such as Text & Data Mining, Computer Assisted Content Analysis, Social Network Analysis, and Sentiment Analysis;
• improve existing social media strategies;
• develop the framework for planning a digital media campaign;
• use storytelling in the scope of creating a campaign;
• create a short video, animation or meme for social media;
• work in an international team environment, both as an integral member and developing a personal leadership style.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Digitization, convergence and connectivity have enabled organizations in the cultural industries to boost the social aspect of their audience relations; users are not only just recipients of media content, but can participate and create value themselves. This participative culture impacts the way organizations in the creative industries function. But how exactly? The possibilities are endless – audiences can be brand ambassadors and aid in the viral marketing of their cultural products. They can be invited for co-creation projects through social media. They are enabled to take up distribution roles in peer-to-peer networks, create content, comment, review, publish, share, download, upload, remix and communicate by means of social networks such as Instagram, Snapchat, YouTube, Twitter or Facebook. Social media also pose challenges for organizations in the creative industries: What if your audience is not engaged? What are the motivations for people to become actively involved? What if your creative product causes a strong reaction on social media? Or how should you tell your story online?

In this research workshop, the use of social media in the creative industries will be our research domain. You are free to choose your own perspective – the producer side or the user side. By means of qualitative research methods, you will explore and analyze a self-chosen topic in more depth. You will design and execute your own empirical research, and report about your findings in our peer-reviewed academic journal: the Erasmus Journal of Social Media.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • State-of-the-art theory on the topic of this workshop.
• Current research designs and methods to examine social media use.
• Design and execute a small-scale empirical research
• Report about the results of their research both in written and oral form.
• Critically reflect on the constraints and societal implications of their research.
• Constructively work as part of a team.

</style>

column1: De opleiding Psychologie van de Erasmus Universiteit Rotterdam wordt gekenmerkt door probleemgestuurd onderwijs (PGO). Voor studenten zal dit een eerste kennismaking zijn met een onderwijsvorm waarin gewerkt wordt aan de hand van problemen binnen een kleine groep studenten (de onderwijsgroep). Om binnen dit onderwijssysteem goed te functioneren is een aantal vaardigheden, zoals het leiden van een gesprek, notuleren, informatie zoeken etc. van groot belang. Hieraan zal tijdens de training dan ook uitgebreid aandacht worden besteed. Het tweede belangrijk onderdeel van dit blok is een kennismaking met de sociale psychologie. De sociale psychologie is een deelgebied van de psychologie dat zich richt op hoe mensen elkaars gedrag, denken en voelen beïnvloeden. Je zult kennismaken met enkele klassieke thema's uit de sociale psychologie, zoals attributie van gedrag en attitudes. Een ander thema dat in meerdere problemen terugkomt, is de invloed van de groep op het individu. Groepen kunnen bijvoorbeeld een groot effect hebben op hoe goed wij presteren en hoe bereid wij zijn anderen te helpen. Ook passen wij ons gedrag sterk aan aan dat van de groep en kunnen we zelfs in een groep onze eigen identiteit verliezen. De sociale psychologie is een subdiscipline die vaak als leuk en interessant wordt ervaren. Dit is niet in de laatste plaats omdat deze zo dicht staat bij de ervaringen van elke dag en je bij uitstek laat nadenken over je eigen gedrag en dat van mensen om je heen.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Dit blok heeft de volgende zaken tot doel:

column2: • Basiskennis verwerven op het gebied van de sociale psychologie. Meer specifiek wordt kennis verworven rondom de volgende thema’s: hulpgedrag, attitudes en attitudeverandering, conformisme, sociale facilitatie en social loafing, deïndividuatie, gehoorzaamheid, sociale perceptie en attributie van gedrag, stereotypen en vooroordelen, en affiliatie en attractie.

• Kennismaking met probleemgestuurd onderwijs (PGO) en training in vaardigheden die voor PGO belangrijk zijn, maar ook in algemene studievaardigheden. Dit zijn onder meer het werken met de Zevensprong, het gesprek leiden, notuleren, luisteren en samenvatten, feedback geven voor PGO. Meer algemeen wordt er aandacht besteed aan het leren zoeken van informatie, het bestuderen en integreren van de gevonden informatie, leerstijlen en taalvaardigheid.

column1: This course focuses on the application of qualitative and quantitative research methods in the social sciences with a specific focus of arts, culture, and media. It focuses specifically on interview and survey design, but discusses a wide range of data collection methods both in quantitative and qualitative research. The course furthermore familiarizes students with the full process involved in setting up a research project. During the course, students conduct a qualitative and quantitative research proposal, including research questions, the operationalization of  concepts and variables and methods of data collection. Other course activities involve practical  assignments that lead to the development of research evaluation skills, research skills, developing  research designs, and the critical evaluation of research reports.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course aims to familiarize students with the main research designs, methods, and techniques of social science research. It provides students with the necessary theoretical and practical knowledge of qualitative and quantitative research methodologies. It furthermore thoroughly discusses the theoretical and philosophical foundations of research paradigms underlining common methodological approaches. After completing this course, the students will be able to:

column2: • Develop a basic research design
• Critically evaluate research reports
• Draw theoretical and practical conclusions based on their review of the research literature
• Present their research reviews and plans in a systematic and clear manner, both orally and in writing.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86227,2019,Social Science Research in Practice,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. JA Holland', 'dr. JFA Braster', 'dr. TMIC Stam']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course introduces a wide range of perspectives on and methodological approaches to social science research. You will broaden your understanding of the philosophical, theoretical and ethical issues that matter in research, and will gain insight in the relationship between theory and research practice.

To gain insight into the research process—from an idea to research design to the production of new knowledge—the course pursues two avenues. One is to help you develop practical skills in data collection, data analysis and interpretation. The other is to present you with exemplars of research using qualitative and quantitative methods, innovative uses of data, natural experiments, and creative comparisons of competing hypotheses.

The course content covers general topics such as scientific integrity, epistemology, ethics, mixed methods and big data. In addition, attention is devoted to a range of so-called quantitative and qualitative research methods.

The course aims to provide you with the methodological foundation to further develop a specialized methodological toolkit and to develop and manage your own (thesis) research projects, and to acquire a set of skills that are sought by government and non-government agencies, and industry.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After successful completion of this course, you will be able to:

column2: • Explain the basic philosophical components to various methodologies in the social sciences (e.g. naturalism, constructivism);
• Explain and apply the principles of ethics, privacy, and scientific integrity in social research;
• Identify how to carry out a search of the social scientific literature on a specified topic;
• Formulate answerable social scientific research questions, and identify which data and analyses best match those questions;
• Explain principles of sampling;
• Evaluate reports of empirical social science research, and assess to what extent they provide answers to the formulated research questions;
• Understand the main approaches in qualitative research, i.e. participant observation, ethnography, and interviewing;
• Understand and apply the main procedures for analyzing qualitative data and interpret the results, i.e. grounded theory, coding, memoing;
• Describe and apply techniques for analyzing quantitative data and interpret the results, i.e. various types of regression analysis, factor analysis, reliability analysis, and multi-level analysis;
• Elaborate on the promises and challenges of big data analytics for social science research;
• Understand the basic principles behind traditional and computational approaches to text analysis (newspaper articles, policy reports).

column1: After successful completion of this course, you will also have developed the following skills:

column2: • Develop a coding scheme (for the purpose of analysis of interview transcripts, other texts, observation, ethnography) using e.g. Atlas.ti
• Explore bivariate and multivariate associations between variables using SPSS;
• Carry out multivariate analyses using SPSS regression procedures and interpret the results;
• Carry out moderation and mediation analyses using the PROCESS application and interpret the results.

column1: Social and cultural history are two established disciplines in historical scholarship. Both have distinct origins in the nineteenth century. Both arose in reaction to traditional political and military histories that focused on the decisions of powerful leaders.

Initially, social history focused on the lived experience of ordinary men and women and looked beyond individual decision makers to consider the underlying and systemic sources of historical change. Cultural history analyzed cultural expression (for instance art and architecture) and collective mentalities. Since the “cultural turn” in the 1970s and 1980s, social history has been increasingly “culturalized,” yet both disciplines still have their own academic, institutional and organizational infrastructure, as well as distinct methodologies. At the beginning of the twenty-first century, cultural historians are increasingly using methods from social history.

This course offers a broad introduction into the history, methods, theories and main research topics of both disciplines. We will also study the differences and similarities of social and cultural. After an introduction to both disciplines, this course will focus on a number of central themes in social and cultural history, including travel, women, death, carnival, gender and sexuality.

column1: Students are introduced to the disciplines of social and cultural history. They are acquainted with the history of both disciplines, they can critically assess works of social and cultural historiography and they can apply main theories and methods of both disciplines in academic papers.

<body>We will study the basic concepts and theories of social and political philosophy, and more specifically of political theory, based on the conviction that social and political thought always also has to be understood from the social and political context from which it arose. Central themes will include: state, citizenship, nationalism, power, ideology, freedom, equality, governmentality, discipline, feminism, orientialism, postcolonialism, and environmentalism. Contemporary views will be discussed in relation to classic insights from the history of philosophy.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: When multiple criteria (such as the preferences of different voters) give rise to different orderings of some set of alternatives (such as candidates running for election), the following question arises: how should one aggregate the different orderings into a single ``taking-all-criteria-into-account” ordering of the alternatives? That question is the central question of Social Choice Theory. Answers to the question crucially depend on the type of information that may be used in the aggregation. In the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory, only ordinal information is allowed. In the traditional framework, answers to the central question are constrained by impossibility results such as Arrow’s theorem, which, very roughly, state that no adequate aggregation method exists.

In this course we first study different aggregations methods and their properties within the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory. We show that various desirable properties cannot be jointly fulfilled, i.e. we will discuss various impossibility results. We then discuss various ways to escape these results that all involve, one way or the other, leaving the traditional framework. Throughout the course there will be a strong emphasis on the relevance of the Social Choice Theory for voting systems and welfare economics / politics.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: 1. The student can name the basic assumptions of the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory, is able to give definitions of its central notions (e.g. preference ordering, preference profile, social ordering, social welfare function) and can explain the relevance of Social Choice Theory for voting theory / welfare economics.

2. The student is familiar with various often-used Social Welfare Functions (e.g. plurality rule, majority rule, Borda rule) and is able to apply these functions (to compute e.g. the outcome of elections).

3.  The student is familiar with various properties (e.g. monotonicity, IIA, Pareto, strategic manipulability) for SWFs, is able to discuss the desirability of these properties in a voting / policy context and is able to explain how often-used SWFs fare with respect to these properties.

4. The student is able to explain which properties for SWFs are mutually incompatible, is familiar with Arrow’s Impossibility Theorem and Sen’s Impossibility Theorem and is able to comment on the significance of these impossibility theorems in a in a voting / policy context.

5. The student is able to explain how, by giving up certain features of the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory (e.g. universal domain or transitivity of social orderings), the impossibility theorems can be escaped.

6. The student is familiar with the Balinski-Laraki framework for Social Choice Theory, able to give definitions of its central notions (e.g. grade profile, merit profile, majority judgement) and able to critically compare the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory with the Balinski-Laraki framework.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Deze cursus is de eerste van de bachelorvakken rond sociale ongelijkheid, en gaat over sociale stratificatie. Dat betekent dat je in dit vak kennismaakt met sociologische theorieën over, en empirisch onderzoek aan de hand van deze theorieën naar, de volgende drie met elkaar samenhangende vragen:

column2: • Wie, of welke groep, bekleedt welke positie op de maatschappelijke ladder(s)van hedendaagse westerse samenlevingen?
• Hoe kan dat worden verklaard?
• Wat heeft dat voor gevolgen?

column1: Hierbij zal met name aandacht worden besteed aan ‘heilige drie-eenheid’ van het stratificatieonderzoek sinds de jaren zeventig van de twintigste eeuw: ‘klasse’, ‘etniciteit’ (in Angelsaksische literatuur wordt ook wel de term ‘race’ gebruikt), en ‘gender’.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • De student maakt zich het centrale begrippenapparaat in het onderzoek naar sociale stratificatie eigen.

• De student raakt bekend met de voornaamste conceptualiseringen van de begrippen ‘klasse’, ‘etniciteit/ras’ en ‘gender’ die in de sociologische onderzoeksliteratuur worden gebruikt, alsmede met hoe deze zich tot elkaar verhouden.
• De student verwerft inzicht in de oorzaken van hedendaagse controversen omtrent verschillende conceptualiseringen en operationaliseringen van het begrip ‘klasse’.
• De student verwerft inzicht in de analytische waarde van het begrip klasse, voor zover het gaat om de verklaring van (de reproductie van) sociale ongelijkheid en sociale mobiliteit.
• De student maakt kennis met prominente sociologische debatten omtrent sociale stratificatie en sociale mobiliteit in hedendaagse westerse samenlevingen.

• De student verwerft inzicht in de sociologische theorieën die een verklaring bieden voor sociale stratificatie en sociale mobiliteit in hedendaagse westerse samenlevingen, alsmede in hun empirische validiteit.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85445,2019,Sociale risico's en instituties van beheersing,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. F Koster', 'prof.dr. HJM Fenger', 'prof.dr. RJ van der Veen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Deze cursus behandelt de sociologische analyse van instituties en hun uitkomsten. Om precies te zijn wordt dit theoretische raamwerk gebruikt voor het analyseren van arbeidsmarktinstituties en hoe deze de verdeling en de kwaliteit van arbeid beïnvloeden. We gaan daarbij in op vraagstukken rondom werkloosheid, arbeidsmarktsegmentatie, flexibilisering van arbeidsrelaties en werkonzekerheid. Dat betekent dat wij ons richten op individualisering van de arbeidsrelatie en globalisering van arbeidsmarkten en de sociale gevolgen van deze ontwikkelingen.

Terwijl de overheid de arbeidsmarkt reguleert via loonbeleid (zoals het geval is bij minimumlonen), ontslagrecht, socialezekerheidsbeleid, enzovoorts, beïnvloeden werkgeversverenigingen en vakbonden de arbeidsmarkt door onderhandelingsprocessen rondom arbeidsomstandigheden, lonen en beroepsopleidingen, die resulteren in collectieve overeenkomsten. De instituties beschermen werknemers tegen risico’s zoals werkloosheid, ziekte en arbeidsongeschiktheid, armoede en pensioen. Ontwikkelingen als individualisering en globalisering kunnen van invloed zijn op de risico’s en de mate van bescherming die de instituties bieden. Vandaar dat vraagstukken rond arbeidsmarktregulering en sociale risico’s vanuit een dynamisch perspectief worden benaderd – meer specifiek wordt aandacht besteed aan economische, sociale en institutionele ontwikkelingen en hun gevolgen voor de arbeidsmarkt.  De vraag hoe nationale overheden en de verschillende arbeidsmarktpartijen omgaan met die veranderen komt ook aan de orde.

Er wordt in het bijzonder aandacht besteed aan hoe de institutionalisering van de arbeidsmarkt kan verschillen (zoals bijvoorbeeld blijkt uit het gegeven dat de mate waarin en wijze waarop arbeidsmarkten worden gecoördineerd verschilt tussen landen). Belangrijke vragen zijn hoe de verschillen in arrangementen leiden tot verschillen in arbeidsmarktbeleid en hoe dit vervolgens het functioneren en de gevolgen van arbeidsmarkten beïnvloedt.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na het succesvol afronden van dit vak kunnen studenten:

column2: • Aangeven hoe verzorgingsstaatinstituties en arbeidsmarktinstituties de verdeling en kwaliteit van arbeid vormgeven;
• Reflecteren op de relatie tussen verzorgingsstaatinstituties en economische, sociale en politieke uitkomsten;
• Sociologische theorieën over verzorgingsstaten en arbeidsmarktcoördinatie identificeren;
• Het sociologische raamwerk toepassen teneinde sociaal beleid op het gebied van arbeidsmarkten en de uitkomsten daarvan te analyseren;
• Onderzoeksmateriaal kritisch beoordelen;
• Op een heldere en effectieve wijze schriftelijk verslag doen van resultaten.
